column2: The petitioner sought a divorce and maintenance for herself and the couple's five-year old child. The wife was working and earned a modest income; the husband a substantial one. Allowing the application, that although the wife upgraded her education during the marriage with encouragement and financial support from the husband, she was entitled to maintenance for an indefinite period. The court reviewed the means and needs of the parties and awarded spousal in addition to child maintenance. The court recognized the indirect financial consequences to a custodial parent in raising children.
column3: The petitioner sought a divorce from the respondent and maintenance for herself and the five-year-old daughter of the marriage. The parties had been married 10 years and had two children. The petitioner sought separation from the husband, who worked in the oil drilling business, for the time he was working in the industry. The husband had worked in various positions for the past 10 years, including as superintendent of an oil rig in Nigeria. The wife was a single economic unit. The respondent was working as a bar manager at minimum wage plus tips. She was interested in pursuing a career in real estate. The Husband was working long hours daily for 28 straight days during which he was confined to the oil rig and then had 28 days off. The Wife was determined to be the single economic units. The Court awarded $266,000 to the husband for the child's care. The court awarded $1,500 to the petitioner for the costs of the separation. The child was to be entitled to maintenance at the rate she was receiving. The mother was to bear the costs associated with the child. The father was to pay $1 million in spousal support. The children were to be divided equally. The marriage was to continue for a period of time. The parents were to have joint custody of the child and the child would bear the cost of the mother's care and maintenance. The agreement between the parties was not to be amended.
column4: TIDMAN, J. The petitioner seeks a divorce from the respondent as well as maintenance for herself and the five‑year old daughter of the marriage. However, based on the need of the wife and the ability to pay of the husband, the wife is entitled to maintenance. As well, as pointed out in both Moge and Mosher, the court should recognize the numerous financial consequences to a custodial parent not reflected in the direct cost of supporting a child. Under all of the circumstances, I will award the wife for the support of herself and the child, Kelly, the sum of $1,500.00 monthly. 2) that the Agreement and Minutes of Settlement entered into by the parties and dated June 10, 1994, be incorporated into and form part of the Divorce Judgment insofar as the jurisdiction of the court permits; 3) that the respondent pay to the petitioner the sum of $1,500.00 monthly beginning December 1, 1994, for the support and maintenance of the petitioner and child of the marriage;

column2: The Applicant participated in a group retirement savings plan ('GRSP') created by Crown Life for its employees. The GRSP provided for an annuity income on retirement for each participating employee. To finance her contribution to the GRSP, she secured an interest-free loan from Crown Life and pledged her interest in the GRSP as security for the loan. Subsequent to leaving her employment with Crown Life, she refused to repay her loan and requested that her contributions to the GRSP be transferred to another carrier. When Crown Life refused, she applied under s.63 of the PPSA for an order declaring that Crown Life's security interest in the GRSP offended s. 146(2)(c.3) of the Income Tax Act which prohibits the taking of security in an RRSP in certain circumstances. She also sought orders requiring Crown Life to comply with her request to transfer her contributions and restraining Crown Life from realizing on its security. HELD: Application dismissed. 1)The terms of the GRSP and the security agreement in this case did not offend s.146(2)(c.3) of the Income Tax Act. 2)If the terms of the GRSP were breached by Crown Life, damages would be an adequate remedy. The Applicant's request for a restraining order was therefore refused. 3)Under the terms of the GRSP contract, Crown Life was not entitled to collapse the Plan. 4)No amount was due out of the Plan to the Applicant until she retired or made a proper request for a transfer. In this case her request for a transfer did not comply with the terms of the Plan. There was therefore nothing to which the security interest of Crown Life could attach until a proper request for a transfer was made or until the Applicant commenced her pension.
column3: The applicant sought a declaration under s63 of the Personal Property Security Act that her interest in a group registered retirement savings plan (later defined as the 'Group Plan') was not subject to a security interest she granted to Crown Life. The provisions of s146(2)(c.3) of the Income Tax Act apply to her interest. The applicant sought an order restraining Crown Life from arbitrarily cancelling her participation in the Group Plan. HELD: The application was granted. 1)The provisions of the personal property security act do not apply to the applicant. 2)The loan agreement contains no provision enabling Crown Life to collapse the applicant's account in the group plan and thereby create an attachable pension refund. 3)The applicant has not retired and there appears to be no monetary sum current for Crown Life which could be set off unless a proper request for a transfer has been made by her. 4)The application for a restraining order was denied. 5)The provision of s 146(2) and s58 of the PPSSA does not apply. The loan agreement does not provide for the taking of security interest by way of the loan agreement contravenes s146. The provision of the Plan Contract does not prohibit Crown Life of setting off the applicant against any monetary sum due from it. Since the applicant has retired, there appears no monetary obligation current for the Crown Life until a pro-proper request is made by the applicant by her for a change in her interest to the Group plan.

Ms. Corscadden seeks a declaration under s. 63 of
The Personal Property Security Act, S.S. 1979-80, c. P-6.1,
that her interest in a group registered retirement savings
plan (later defined as the "Group Plan") is not subject to a
security interest she granted to Crown Life. 1.Do the provisions of s. 146(2)(c.3) of the Income Tax Act
apply to Ms. Corscadden\'s interest in the Group Plan? Should
Crown Life breach the terms of the Plan Contract, I am of the
view that Ms. Corscadden can be amply compensated by way of
damages. Her application for a restraining order is therefore
denied. Since Ms. Corscadden has not
retired and no pension refund exists, there appears to be no
monetary sum current for Crown Life to set off, unless a
proper request for a transfer has been made by Ms. Corscadden. Act. Crown Life is not entitled to "collapse" Ms.
Corscadden\'s interest in light of the provisions of Article
8.03 of the Group Plan. attach. Ms. Corscadden\'s application is dismissed.

column2: The Director of Labour Standards issued a certificate against the City of Regina certifying that it owed a transit employee $318.41 in wages for hours worked in weeks containing a statutory holiday in excess of 32 hours as provided in the Labour Standards Act. The City applied for a review. HELD: The City's application was allowed. Under the terms of the collective agreement in force, the employee was actually paid 4 hours pay in excess of the Act's requirements for each of the weeks in question. Pursuant to section 72 of the Act, therefore, these particular terms of the collective agreement applied since they were, when considered in light of the balance of the agreement, more favorable to the employee than the requirements of the Act.
column3: The City applied to review a certificate issued pursuant to s. 60 of the Labour Standards Act declaring that the City of Regina (the "City") owed its transit employee $511.08 in wages. The Director filed a March 8, 1994 letter reducing the assessment to $318.41 (including annual holiday pay). The City brought this application to review the certificate. HELD: 1)The certificate was issued pursuant pursuant to ss. 60 and 6(2) of the Act. The City argued that the collective bargaining agreement was more favourable to the employees than the terms of the act. 2)The provisions of the agreement should govern, and not those of the legislation. column2: This was an appeal from the decision of the Nova Scotia Utility and Review Board allowing an appeal from the decision of the Victims' Services Division denying compensation to the respondent on the basis the police had not proceeded with criminal charges for an assault which had occurred. Dismissing the appeal, that the Board had correctly interpreted its jurisdiction and made findings amply supported by the evidence arising from the de novo hearing. Failure of the police to lay a charge against the attacker did not disqualify the applicant from compensation if it was otherwise supported by the evidence.
column3: The appellant applied for criminal injuries compensation pursuant to the Victims' Rights and Services Act. He alleged that he was wrongly assaulted and that the police investigation indicated that they would not be proceeding with criminal charges. The respondent appealed. Dismissing the appeal, that the Board correctly interpreted its jurisdiction and found that the program was unable to confirm through the criminal justice system that the appellant was a victim of crime.
column4: THE COURT: Appeal dismissed from decision of Nova Scotia Utility and Review Board concerning an award of compensation pursuant to the Victims\' Rights and Services Act, per oral reasons for judgment delivered by Clarke, C.J.N.S.; Mr. Glasgow applied for criminal injuries compensation pursuant to the Victims\' Rights and Services Act, S.N.S. 1989, c. 14, as amended. Because the program is unable to confirm through the criminal justice system that you are a victim of crime, we are unable to make a compensation award. There is nothing ln the Act which suggests that a person is not a victim because the police failed to lay a charge. In our opinion the Board correctly interpreted its jurisdiction. Accordingly the appeal is dismissed. DECISION: Appeal allowed

column2: FIAT. The parties were divorced in 1995 and all issues including spousal maintenance were left in abeyance. The petitioner had agreed to pay $3,000 per month which included child support but the support was reduced to $1,000 and was irregular and late. The two children were living with the petitioner and although old enough to hold jobs, had been unable to find employment. The petitioner's income exceeded $80,000 annually but he had been suspended with pay and the status of his employment was uncertain. HELD: 1)It was premature to fix the amount of spousal maintenance as asked for by the applicant. There were too many unknowns including the future of the petitioner's future job and income and how much the applicant would require should she go to university in the fall and what the children would do about future education. 2)The petitioner was not entitled to unilaterally reduce the maintenance. 3)The petitioner was directed to pay $1,500 plus $200.00 per month until the shortfall was paid in full.  4)The applicant was awarded costs of the application.
column3: FIAT. The parties separated in the summer of 1994. All other issues raised in the divorce proceeding were left in the husband's favour. The petitioner reduced the monthly support to $1,000 per month and even those payments were irregular and not on time. The husband applied for interim spousal maintenance at the suggested guideline figure. HELD: The application was granted. 1)The uncertainty of the petitioner's future job and income was not considered. 2)The respondent was not entitled to unilaterally reduce the $1500.00 maintenance he consistently paid up to December 1995 to $2,000.00 without at least consulting with the applicant. Had these payments continued the applicant would have recovered $6,000 and recovered $8,000 at the rate suggested by the Department of Justice. 3)The court found that the petitioner was not in any way entitled to unilateral reduction of the $1 million he consistently gave up to 1995 to less than $1 per month without at all consulting with him.

In my opinion it is premature on this application to
fix the amount of the spousal maintenance that the applicant
has asked for at the suggested guideline figure. There is the uncertainty of the
petitioner\'s future job and income. On the other hand I am of the opinion that the
petitioner was not entitled to unilaterally reduce the
$1500.00 maintenance he consistently paid up to December 1995
to $1,000.00 as noted above without at least consulting with
the applicant. Accordingly I direct that the petitioner pay spousal
maintenance to the applicant commencing June 1, 1996 as
follows:

(b)$200.00 on the 1st day of each month towards the shortfall
resulting from the reduction in payent from $1,500.00 to
$1,000.00 in 1996 until the said shortfall has been paid in
full.

column22: FIAT. The parties were divorced in 1995 and all issues including spousal maintenance were left in abeyance. The petitioner had agreed to pay $3,000 per month which included child support but the support was reduced to $1,000 and was irregular and late. The two children were living with the petitioner and although old enough to hold jobs, had been unable to find employment. The petitioner's income exceeded $80,000 annually but he had been suspended with pay and the status of his employment was uncertain. HELD: 1)It was premature to fix the amount of spousal maintenance as asked for by the applicant. There were too many unknowns including the future of the petitioner's future job and income and how much the applicant would require should she go to university in the fall and what the children would do about future education. 2)The petitioner was not entitled to unilaterally reduce the maintenance. 3)The petitioner was directed to pay $1,500 plus $200.00 per month until the shortfall was paid in full.  4)The applicant was awarded costs of the application.
column23: FIAT. The parties separated in the summer of 1994. All other issues raised in the divorce proceeding were left in the husband's favour. The petitioner reduced the monthly support to $1,000 per month and even those payments had been irregular and not on time. The husband applied for interim spousal maintenance at the suggested guideline figure. HELD: The application was granted. 1)The uncertainty of the petitioner's future job and income was not a factor to be considered. 2)The petitioner was not entitled to unilaterally reduce the $1500.00 maintenance he consistently paid up to December 1995 to $2,000 as noted above without at least consulting with the applicant. Had these payments continued the applicant would have recovered $6,000. 3)The court found that there were too many unknown factors surrounding the future situation of either party to conclude that what the applicant asks for is fair and reasonable.

column27: FIAT. The parties separated in the summer of 1994. All other issues raised in the divorce proceeding were left in the custody of the petitioner. The petitioner reduced the monthly support to $1,000 per month and even those payments were irregular and not on time. The applicant sought interim spousal maintenance. HELD: 1)The petitioner was not entitled to unilaterally reduce the $1500.00 maintenance he consistently paid up to December 1995 from $2,000.00 as noted above without at least consulting with the applicant. 2)The respondent's future job and income were uncertain. There was no evidence as to what the applicant would require if she did go to university this fall. The two children were living with him and he contended that there was a scarcity of jobs to be had. 3)It was premature on this application to fix the amount of the applicant's request for $6,000 at the suggested guideline figure. There were too many unknown factors surrounding the future situation of either party to conclude the applicant asks for is fair and reasonable.

column2: After a sub-contractor failed to complete its contract work, the plaintiff, a supplier of materials to the sub-contractor sued the general contractor and the surety under the terms of a labour and Material Payment Bond for payment of a balance owing to it by the sub-contractor. The Bond contained a provision limiting the liability of the surety and the principal to make payment to any claimant not having a contract directly with the principal. Dismissing the action with costs, that there was no evidence of intention to contract, valuable consideration, or binding promise to pay between the general contractor and the supplier. With respect to the principal, as the Bond limits the liability of the surety and principal to make payment to a claimant such as the plaintiff not having a contract directly with the principal, liability is limited by the Bond to the amount which the principal would have been obliged to pay to the plaintiff if the provisions of the Mechanics' Lien Act applied to the work. As the contract was with the Crown, and the Act is not binding on the Crown, the general contractor was not obliged to pay anything to the plaintiff. Therefore, the supplier was not entitled to recover against the surety under the Bond.
column3: After a sub-contractor failed to complete its contract work, a supplier of materials to the sub-construction company sued the general contractor and surety under the terms of a Labour and Material Payment Bond for payment of a balance owing to it by the sub contractor. HELD: The claims of the plaintiff against the general contractors and London Guarantee were dismissed. 1)The Mechanics' Lien Act does not expressly state that it binds the Crown. The Act does apply to this contract or this work. 2)If the Mechanics' lien Act had been applicable, the plaintiff would not have been entitled to recover anything due to the third party statutory liens. 3)If it was not bound the Mechanics Lien act did not apply, the applicant would not be entitled to claim anything due the third parties. 4)If a Mechanics'Lien Act was applicable, Rideau Construction would not necessarily have been able to recover the holdback established by that Act. If the Mechanics's Lien was applicable the applicant could have obtained a loan from the Crown or a guarantee from the Department of Labour.

Paragraph 4 of the Labour & Material Payment Bond limits the liability of the surety and the principal to make payment to a claimant such as Hazmasters not having a contract directly with the principal. column2: The accused was charged with sexual assault and touching contrary to s.271(1) and 153 of the Criminal Code. The alleged offences occurred in the complainant's home when she was between the ages of 13 and 15. HELD: The accused was found not guilty on both counts. 1)There was insufficient confirmatory evidence for proof of guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. The evidence showed an escalating pattern of intrusive behaviour by the accused who admitted to touching her on two occasions and to have been on top of her once. His explanation that he fell on her was farfetched but the other explanations were not outlandish. None of the complainant's allegations involved alcohol nor was drunkenness alleged to be a factor. The evidence of the complainant's depression or withdrawal could have other explanations.
column3: The accused was charged with sexual assault and touching. The evidence of the complainant was that the accused often slept on the couch in the basement of the house adjacent to the room where the family watched TV. There was a couch or love-seat in the living room adjacent to where the complainant's bedroom was located. The accused often went to bed late at night. The complainant often went into the bedroom and sometimes he would get on top of her. She said that he always touched her inappropriately. She called the police. The police were called. The alleged incidents were found to be consistent with the accused’s repeated repeated assaults. The Court found that the evidence of his repeated assaults was not supported by expert testimony. The court found that his repeated repeated attacks on the complainant were not consistent with his repeated allegations.
column4: Although his explanations for touching and his evidence of the complainant’s behaviour are at odds with the Crown’s evidence, there is simply not enough confirmatory evidence surrounding the allegations for there to be proof of guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. Although I am suspicious of his evidence I have compared and contrasted it with that of the Crown’s and, having done so, I am unable to find him guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. 32. The accused is, therefore, not guilty of either count on the Information.

column8: The accused was charged with sexual assault and touching. The evidence of the complainant was that the accused often slept on the couch in the basement of the house adjacent to the room where the family watched TV. There was a couch or love-seat in the living room adjacent to where the complainant's bedroom was located. The accused often went to bed late at night. He often slept down there because he was angry with her mother for not wanting to have sex with him. The complainant said that he often came into her room and would often sleep down there. He would often walk into her bedroom and touch her breasts and sometimes he would sit on top of her. She called the police. She also said that she had been assaulted by the accused several times while she was sleeping in the bedroom. She said that the assault was so intense that she feared for her life. She testified that she was afraid that he would leave her alone if he ever said anything like that again. She was also afraid that if he said anything about the “mischievous flaunting” or the shower-watching, she would call the police and the accused would be arrested. The following evidence was found to confirm the complainant’s testimony: 1)The accused had an opportunity to sleep on the floor of the basement. Most of the incidents complained of happened in that room. The alleged assault was consistent with the accused having an opportunity. He had the opportunity to spend time with the complainant and she had the ability to report back to him. He did not have the opportunity and the evidence was circumstantial. The Court found that the evidence of both the accused and the complainant that he was involved in a sexual assault was not corroborated by expert testimony. 2)The Court found the accused guilty of both charges. The first charge was sexual assault. The second charge was assault. 3)The evidence was that he had a reasonable chance of being found guilty.

When the behaviour finally escalated to groping at her in the bedroom while she was sleeping, she called the police. HELD: The accused was found guilty of both charges. 1)The evidence was circumstantial. The complainant had no concerns about the accused and his behaviour toward her. The only concerns she had were depression or withdrawal, her sliding school performance, anger and self-consciousness and her passage through puberty into adolescent behaviour that seems to put greater emphasis on body image as opposed to brains. 2)The accused had no reasonable doubt that the complainant had been sexually assaulted. He did not have the opportunity to defend himself against the allegations of sexual assault. He had the opportunity and the evidence to prove it. He was not guilty of any of the allegations. The court found that the evidence of both the complainant and the accused was circumstANTIAL. 3)There was no evidence of any threats or threats. The Court found that although the accused had a reasonable chance of being found guilty, it was unlikely that he would be found guilty.

column18: The accused was charged with sexual assault and touching. The evidence of the complainant was that the accused often slept on the couch in the basement of the house adjacent to the room where the family watched TV. There was a couch or love-seat in that room. The accused often went to bed late at night. Sometimes he slept down there because he was angry with the complainant's mother for not wanting to have sex with him. He frequently came into the bedroom and touched her inappropriately. She called the police. An expert witness in the area of sexual behaviour testified to this evidence. HELD: The accused was found guilty of both charges. 1)The accused had an opportunity to be found guilty. He had a reasonable chance of being found guilty on all of the counts. 2)The evidence was circumstantial. The complainant had no concerns about the accused and his behaviour toward her. He was severely drunk and had a history of aggressive behaviour. The alleged incidents were consistent with his repeated repeated assaults on her. 3)The complainant's evidence did not confirm the accused’s guilt. The only evidence that he was guilty was that he had been physically abusive to the complainant and that he did not have a place to live in a house where he lived with his children. He also had the opportunity to spend time with his grandchildren. 4)Although the accused was acquitted of all charges, the evidence of his alleged victimization of his own daughter was strongly supported by expert testimony. The court found that the evidence that the complainant had been sexually assaulted by the accused in her own home did not corroborate the allegations against her.

column23: The accused was charged with sexual assault and touching. The evidence of the complainant was that the accused often slept on the couch in the basement of the house adjacent to the room where the family watched TV. There was a couch or love-seat in that room. The accused sometimes slept down there because he was angry with the complainant's mother for not wanting to have sex with him. When the behaviour finally escalated to groping at her in the bedroom while she was sleeping, she called the police. HELD: The accused was found guilty of both charges. 1)The evidence was circumstantial. The complainant had the time in the sense that the complainant went to bed late in the evening or in the early morning hours at time when most of the household would be asleep. There were also four occasions when the accused walked into her room (he said he thought she was awake) and ran out. He said that he was chasing kittens. That explanation sounded too contrived. No one had mentioned cats or kittens before. 2)The accused had the opportunity to sleep downstairs about two-thirds of the time. However, he also had the chance to sleep in the living room with his mother. The mother testified that she never had any concerns about the accused and his behaviour toward her daughter. The only concerns she had were depression or withdrawal and her sliding school performance, anger and self consciousness. 3)There was no threat to the complainant or to herself or to anyone else. The assault was escalating and the accused had a pattern of intrusive behaviour that escalated over the course of several years. The alleged incidents were consistent with the accused’s repeated repeated assaults on the complainant and his repeated threats to leave and take her baby brother with him, which would have alerted her mother if he got off on his own. Although he was severely drunk, she could only recall only one other time when he was that drunk. She said that it was rare for him to be drunk. Alcohol was not problem. It was only after the complainant called the Police that she was able to report the assault to the RCMP. She testified that he only touched the complainant when she was reaching for something above the stove and began to fall. He always used one hand. The touching only lasted seconds each time ending as soon as she said stop.

column27: The accused was charged with sexual assault and touching. The evidence of the complainant was that the accused often slept on the couch in the basement of the house adjacent to the room where the family watched TV. There was a couch or love-seat in the living room adjacent to where the complainant's bedroom was located. The accused often went to bed late at night. The complainant often went into the bedroom and sometimes he would get on top of her. She said that he always touched her inappropriately. She called the police. The police were called. The alleged incidents were found to be consistent with the accused’s repeated repeated assaults. The Court found that the evidence of his repeated assaults was not supported by expert testimony. The court found that his repeated repeated attacks on the complainant were not consistent with his repeated allegations.

column2: At issue in this sentencing appeal for breach of probation was whether or not a person can receive a second conditional discharge in relation to a matter arising out of similar circumstances in relation to a prior discharge. allowing the appeal, sentencing the offender to three years probation with conditions, that an offender may receive a discharge where he had already received one for another offence.
column3: The accused appealed his conditional discharge and three years probation. He argued that the Tan case required a second conditional discharge not be made available in relation to the matter arising out of similar circumstances in relation the prior discharge. Dismissing the appeal, that although the judge believed the Tan decision required a conditional discharge, he nevertheless, during the course of that decision, appeared to believe that the matter arose out of a similar circumstances, he nonetheless, during that decision appeared to do the requisite test in determining the use of conditional discharge.
column4: I am doing so on the basis that when I read the decision of Judge Williams, actually, his decision is ambiguous to the extent that, although he appears to believe that the Tan case requires that a second conditional discharge not be made available in relation to the matter arising out of similar circumstances in relation to a prior discharge. What is clear though, to me, is that he starts the process by indicating to counsel that he believes that he is constrained and finishes his decision with a reference to the Tan case at page 13 of the abstract that I have, where I note and I state that R. v. Tan (1974), 1974 CanLII 1608 (BC CA), 22 C.C.C. (2d)184 (B.C.C.A.) stands for the proposition that an accused may not receive a discharge where he has already received a discharge for another offence. I am going to accept the joint recommendation of counsel that was made before him, and is again made before me, that there be a conditional discharge, three years probation, absolutely no contact direct or indirect with the named victim.

column2: FIAT. The defendants sought to amend their statement of defence at the opening of trial. They applied to include accord and satisfaction as a defence, alleging that the parties had settled their differences through negotiations and the transfer of property 11 years earlier. Application opposed. Trial adjourned while motion heard in chambers. HELD: Application denied. This action extended over 4 years and was ready for trial. The applicants had no explanation for the delay in bring this matter. There was also no explanation for why the applicants' counsel did not alert the respondent's counsel before the trail or at least at a time when the matter could have been adjourned without additional cost or inconvenience. The applicants are guilty of inexcusable laches. The proposed amendments raised new and unexpected issues. It would be a significant change in the course of the action resulting in further discoveries, examinations, etc. to address the completely new questions raised by the amendments. Applicants to pay costs within 30 days. Applicants' request for leave to argue this motion by phone was refused as it was a substantive motion involving lengthy submissions by counsel.
column3: FIAT. The defendants sought to amend their statement of defence by pleading Accord and Satisfaction. The application was opposed. The trial judge directed the defendants to proceed by notice of motion in chambers and the trial was adjourned. HELD: The application must be dismissed.  1)If the amendment were granted, it would mark a significant change in the course of the action: Roles v. Royal Bank.  2)The applicants did not raise this new and substantive plea until the opening of the trial. The applicants are guilty of inexcusable laches in bringing the application.  3)The pleadings must be raised as the principal plea and in the first instance and without equivocation. The passage of time can only reflect on their bona fides in this matter.
column4: [1] The defendants sought to amend their statement of defence at the opening of the trial to plead, in effect, Accord and Satisfaction. The plea was based on the allegation that the parties had settled their differences in October, 1988, as a result of negotiations between the solicitors then representing the parties. There is no explanation as to why counsel did not alert counsel for the respondent at least before the trial and at the very least at a time when the matter could have been adjourned without any additional cost or inconvenience to the parties. [11] If the amendment were granted, it would mark a significant change in the course of the action: Roles v. Royal Bank.  It would result, as respondent’s counsel points out, in further discoveries, examinations for discoveries and presumably a further pre-trial conference to address the completely new questions raised by the amendments. I have commented already on the fact that the applicants’ did not raise this new and substantive plea until the opening of the trial, but I also need to underscore the fact that the applicants are guilty of inexcusable laches in bringing the application. [12] For all of these reasons, the application must be dismissed.

column2: Applicant applies for leave to appeal a Queen's Bench Chambers decision dismissing his application for relief under s.61 of the Queen's Bench Act. HELD: Leave to appeal denied. The respondent has costs at double Column V. The considerations to be applied in a leave to appeal application is 1)whether the issue raised by the proposed appeal is sufficiently important to the litigation before the Court or to the practice in general to warrant consideration by the Court of Appeal. 2)Whether the applicant's proposed submission to the Court of Appeal has sufficient merit to warrant the granting of leave. 3)Whether there is any delay in the proceedings which would be caused by the interjection of an appeal. Here the applicant has misconstrued the mortgage agreement. The applicant still has a right to redeem upon payment. No issue of importance was raised nor did the Court see any merit to the applicant's appeal

column2: The accused was charged with ten counts including robbery, aggravated assault, assault causing bodily harm, possession of stolen property and trafficking in narcotics. She raised s.9 and 8 of the Charter in objecting to the arrest and seizure of the duffel bag. The voir dire occupied 5 days. HELD: 1)The four requirements set out in R. v. Feeney for a warrantless search were satisfied. The arrest was lawful. The accused never asserted ownership of the bag or made any claim to any interest or right with respect to it. The gym bag constituted non-conscriptive evidence. 3)If there were any violations of the accused's Charter rights (and it was concluded there were not) they were of a minor nature and not sufficient to engage the provisions of s.24(2) of the Charter. To exclude the evidence would bring the administration of justice into disrepute.

column8: HELD: The accused was found guilty of 10 counts and a voir dire was conducted to determine whether the accused had reasonable and probable grounds. The accused had objected to her arrest and to the seizure of a duffel bag containing a quantity of narcotics. The Court found the arrest was lawful and the search of the house and seizure of the bag were incidental to the arrest and therefore lawful.  1)If there were any violations of the accused's rights under the Charter, and if there were not, they were of a minor nature and certainly not sufficiently egregious to engage the provisions of s. 24(2) of the Charter. To exclude the evidence in question would, in fact, bring the administration of justice into manifest disrepute. 2)Saskatchewan police were not unlawful with respect to either the arrest or search of a person. They were not responsible for the search or seizure of drugs seized. The search was conducted in a reasonable manner. 3)The court found the accused was arrested lawfully. The court found that the search was lawful. 4)The Court concluded that the accused’s rights were violated. If there had been any violations under the s.16 Charter, it concluded that there had not been a minor or egregious case of breaches. If such violations were of minor nature or certainly not egregious, they would not be tried in the circumstances of the arrest. The police conduct did not affect her personal right. The officer believed that this purpose will be served by the search must be reasonable one. 5)The accused had no expectation of privacy in her apartment. She was concerned that her associates would see the search and try to escape or dispose of evidence. 6)If the accused has reasonable expectations of privacy, they must be of a reasonable nature and not sufficiently extreme to engage s.24(2(2)(f) of The Charter. 7)If a party to a criminal offence is found guilty, the accused must be found guilty. 8)The police must have one of the purposes for a valid search incident to arrest in mind when the search is conducted. Further, the officer's belief that the purpose will serve by the Search must be reasonably one. 9)The only requirement is that there be some reasonable basis for doing what the officer did. If the accused is a person of interest or right, the police need not demonstrate anything more than reasonable and possible grounds. Specifically, they are not required to establish a prima facie case for conviction before making the arrest

column2: The Trustee received funds after a debtor defaulted on a consumer proposal. The Trustee sought to have its fees taxed.,fees taxed based on the funds received by the Trustee prior to default. The default is deemed to be an annulment of the proposal and all funds received post-default must be distributed to the creditors.
column3: The debtor made a consumer proposal which was accepted by his creditors and PricewaterhouseCoopers was appointed Trustee under the proposal. At some point during the proposal Mr. White defaulted. At the proposal he defaulted and PWC was appointed trustee. At that point Mr.White defaulted again and the proposal was annulled. The debtor made another proposal which he accepted by the creditors and was accepted again by his other creditors. At this point Mr White defaulting again and P&G was appointed as Trustee. At a point during his proposal Mr White was paid $3,500 per month. At which point he defaulting, PWC appointed Trustees and P &G was named Trustee of the debtor's account. At various points during the proposed payment Mr. WHITE defaulted, and P/G was given the trustee's fee. The trustee accepted payments after the deemed annulment. At one point during this proposal MrWhite defaulting and P.G. was appointed to Trustee by his creditor's creditors. The proposal was accepted and Mr. Black defaulted in April or May. The debt was in default to the extent of 3 months of payments the proposal is deemed to be annulling. There is no choice in this and there is no discretion in either the trustee or the court to relieve against the annulments. The Superintendent objects on taxation indicating that this court should review the trustee’s fee given that the trustee accepted payment after the deem annulement. The fee is taxed and allowed in the appropriate amount. The court found that PWC is entitled to fee, but that fee can only be based on those amounts received by PWC under the provisions of the consumer proposal. Those amounts received after the consumer proposals was deemed to have been annullable are not subject to a trustee”s fee.
column4: This is an application to tax a trustee’s account. Those amounts received after the consumer proposal was deemed to be annulled are not be subject to a trustee’s fee. I also opine that the excess monies should be distributed to the creditor’s, who should be advised that their original debts remain receivable.

column8: This was an application to tax a trustee's account. The debtor made a consumer proposal which was accepted by his creditors and PricewaterhouseCoopers was appointed Trustee under the proposal. At some point during the proposal Mr. White defaulted and defaulted. The debt was in default to the extent of three months of payments the proposal was deemed to be annulled. This was an action to tax the trustee's fee. The trustee accepted payments after the deemed annulment. At this point the debtor defaulted again and the trustee appointed a trustee. The creditor appealed. The court found that the trustee was entitled to a fee but that fee can only be based on the amounts received by the trustee under the provisions of the consumer proposal. Those amounts received after the consumer proposals were not subject to a trustee’s fee.

column13: This was an application to tax a trustee's account. The debtor made a consumer proposal which was accepted by his creditors and PricewaterhouseCoopers was appointed Trustee under the proposal. At some point during the proposal Mr. White defaulted and defaulted. The debt was in default to the extent of three months of payments the proposal was deemed to be annulled. There was no choice in this case and there was no discretion in either the trustee or the court to relieve against the annulment. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The amount received from the debtor after the default was not subject to a trustee’s fee. Those amounts received after the consumer proposal was considered to be null and void are not subject. 2)Taxation was ordered on the basis that the debtor did send monies to PWC with the intention those monies would be distributed to the debtor‘s creditors. To that extent the trustee acts as the debtor's agent. PWC as agent has an obligation to disburse the monies as was the intention of the debtor. 3)The excess monies should be distributed directly to the creditors, who should be advised that their original debts remain receivable.

column23: This was an application to tax a trustee's account. The debtor made a consumer proposal which was accepted by his creditors and PricewaterhouseCoopers was appointed Trustee under the proposal. At some point during the proposal Mr. White defaulted and defaulted. The proposal was deemed to be annulled and the debtor applied for an order directing the Superintendent to review the trustee's fee given that the trustee accepted payments after the deemed annulment. The Superintendent objected. The fee was taxed and allowed in the appropriate amount with leave to reapply to me to set a specific number if PWC and Superintendent cannot agree on what should be reviewed. The excess monies should be distributed to the creditor's who should be advised that their debts remain receivable. HELD: 1)The fee should only be based on monies received from the debtor while the proposal was extant and no fee can be added to those amounts received by PWC under the provisions of the consumer proposal. 2)The debtor did send those monies to PWC with the intention of receiving monies in the amount of 3 months of payments the debtor's creditors. To that extent the trustee acts as the debtor’s agent. PWC as agent has an obligation to disburse monies as was intended of the debtor.

column2: FIAT. The issue was whether costs should be assessed against the plaintiffs because the two motions served by the plaintiffs were not filed at the Court House prior to the return date as required by the Queen's Bench Rules;  the motion filed at the Court House was not served on the defendants; plaintiff's counsel advised the defendants that the two motions which had been served on them were not in fact going to proceed. HELD: Given the lawyer's representation as to the amount of stress he was under, it would not be appropriate in the circumstances to assess costs against the plaintiffs over the conduct of their counsel or against counsel directly or at this time. The matter was left to the trial judge.
column3: FIAT. The plaintiffs were heard in chambers on January 24, 2002. The defendants had not filed motions at the Court House prior to the return date as required by Queen's Bench Rules. The two motions which were served on the plaintiffs were not filed at the court house prior to their return date. The Queen's Counsel advised the defendants that the two motions had been served on them were not going to proceed. HELD: The matter was to be determined by the trial judge in the course of the action. 1) Given the representation of the plaintiff as to the amount of stress he was currently under, it was not appropriate in the circumstances to assess costs against the plaintiffs over the conduct of their counsel or against counsel directly at this time. 2) The two motion served on by the plaintiffs on the defendants returnable for January 24 2002 were not served on. 3) The plaintiff was under extreme pressure and stress lately with respect to this file and others and therefore had prepared three motions fairly similar to one another. Given the plaintiff's representation as to his stress level, it would be appropriate in this circumstances to determine costs against them over the course and effect of this action.

HELD: The matter was to be determined by the trial judge in the course of the action.  1) The two motions which were served by the plaintiffs on the defendants returnable for January 24 were not filed at the Court House prior to the return date as required by Queen's Bench Rules. 2) Given Tapp's representation as to the amount of stress that he was presently under, it was not appropriate in the circumstances to assess costs against them over the conduct or of counsel indirectly at the time.

column2: The accused was charged with a number of break and enters. After hearing evidence, the Crown advised the Court that it intended to call 'Ace' to the stand. Ace had been subpoenaed and had been sitting in the Court listening to other Crown witnesses. Defence counsel objected and claimed the Crown had not disclosed this witness. Ace was also a client of defence counsel and so defence counsel would not be able to cross-examine Ace. HELD: The Crown failed to provide proper disclosure to defence counsel, the non-disclosure had an adverse effect of the accused's ability to make full answer in defence and the appropriate remedy was to refuse to allow the Crown to call Ace as a witness.
column3: The accused was charged with break and enters of homes. He pleaded guilty to three of them but denied involvement. After hearing evidence from the home owners, co-accused, and peace officers who investigated the incidents, the Crown advised the court of its intention to call one of the accused to the witness box. The defence objected on this basis but he also argued that the Crown had ambushed him and his client. Defence counsel argued that if the Crown informed the court that it was going to call the accused, the accused would not be able to cross-examine the witness effectively or at all. HELD: The accused was not entitled to a stay of proceedings. The Crown was not permitted to call this witness. The accused's right to full answer and defence had been prejudiced only by not being told that the accused's name was mentioned as a co-defendant in the disclosure given to defence. The prejudice to the accused’s right to make full answer, defence and their ability to make defence flowed from not being informed that the witness was a Crown witness. In addition, the defence counsel would not have been able to take appropriate steps to properly protect the interests of both the accused and his clients. The court found that the defence had met the test of prejudice to accused”s right of full answer” and the prejudice to defence”d to the prejudice of the right to a full answer flowed from the not being notified that the defendant would be a Crown witnesses. The judge concluded that the court had not met the burden of establishing on a balance of probabilities that the impunged non-disclosure had prejudiced or had an adverse effect on the accused. The Court found that if it had, on a balanced of probabilities, established that the Court had established that impunge non-closure had affected the accuseds ability to answer and defend, the prejudice would flow from not knowing that the victim would be unable to cross cross-examination.

column13: The accused is charged with break and enters of homes. He pleaded guilty to three of them but denied involvement. After hearing evidence from the home owners, co-accused, and peace officers who investigated the incidents, the Crown advised the court of its intention to call one of the accused to the witness box. He had been subpoenaed by the Crown and, unknown to the prosecution, had been sitting in court listening to the other Crown witnesses. Defence counsel objected on this basis but he also argued that the Crown had not disclosed their intent to call this witness and that they should not be permitted to do so. HELD: 1)The accused's right to full answer and defence has been prejudiced only by not being told that Ace Carlos Whitecap would be a Crown witness. 2)The defence has met this test. The prejudice to the accused's rights to make full answer, defence flows from not being informed that Ace Whitecap will be a witness. 3)The Crown has met the test. In addition, the defence counsel would have been able to take the appropriate steps to properly protect the interests of both the accused and his client. 4)The Court must take into account all aspects of the failure to disclose. This includes the nature of the charge, delay, adjournments to date and at who’s request, the nature and nature of all the evidence not disclosed and the Crown explanation for the omission. The point in time at which the accused has to consider the evidence and the case before election or plea is at the beginning of a trial. Compliance must be made by the accused so that he has sufficient time to consider and be as effective as possible in the cross-examination of this witness. 5)The only remedy is to refuse to allow the Crown to call the witness to give evidence. The Crown will not be allowed to call a witness in this trial.

column23: The accused is charged with break and enters of homes. He pleaded guilty to three of them but denied involvement. After hearing evidence from the home owners, co-accused, and peace officers who investigated the incidents, the Crown advised the court of its intention to call one of the accused to the witness box. He had been subpoenaed by the Crown and, unknown to the prosecution, had been sitting in court listening to the other Crown witnesses. Defence counsel objected on this basis but Defence counsel argued that if the Crown had informed the defence that it would call this witness, the defence would not be able to cross-examine him effectively or at all. HELD: The accused's right to full answer and defence has been prejudiced only by not being told that Ace Carlos Whitecap would be a Crown witness. 1)The defence has met this test. The prejudice to the accused's rights to make full answer, defence flows from not being informed that the accused would be called. 2)The accused was disadvantaged in his ability to make his defence on the basis of the witnesses the Crown is actually going to call. The defence had met the test. 3)There was no prejudicial effect on the defence on a balance of probabilities. The accused was advantaged in the fact that he was a client of the Crown's lawyer. 4)The Crown had not disclosed that it intended to call Whitecap as a witness and that they should not be permitted to do so. It was also disadvantageous in that the defence counsel would then have been able to take the appropriate steps to protect the interests of both the accused and his client. 5)The Court was left with the option of refusing to allow the Crown to call the witness. The Court held that entering a stay of proceedings is a last resort to be taken only when all other acceptable avenues of protecting a defence are exhausted. The Crown will not be allowed to call a witness in this trial.

column2: The Agency applied for permanent care of a young child, with no access to the parents. Each of the mother, the biological father and the psychological father sought to have the child placed in their care. The child had been apprehended due to unsafe and unhealthy living conditions. The mother and psychological father no longer lived together and for the past few months, the mother had been maintaining a clean and tidy apartment and attempting to improve her education and had taken parenting courses. The psychological father, with whom the mother had ended a tumultuous relationship, wanted the child returned to his care, stating that he planned on residing with the mother who would assist him in caring for the child. The mother was against this plan. The biological father only reappeared on the scene after the child was taken into care and acknowledged that the child did not know him as her father. Child placed in the permanent care of the Agency with no access to the mother or the psychological father; access ordered to the biological father for a period of six months at which time the access order will expire automatically unless an application to vary is made; the Agency is to arrange for a parental capacity assessment of the biological father. The child continued to be at substantial risk of physical harm due to neglect if she was returned to the mother's care and the child would be at risk of exposure to violence if returned to the psychological father's care due to the tumultuous relationship between the mother and him. Although some improvements had recently been made in the mother's life, she had a history of frequent changes of residence and did not appear able put the child's needs ahead of her own. The Agency had not had an opportunity to assess the appropriateness of a placement with the biological father.
column3: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child. The agency alleged that the respondent parents had failed to cooperate in addressing the risk factors identified at previous court hearings and acknowledged by the Respondents in consenting to a protection finding. The child was placed in the care of the respondent mother and psychological father. The biological father opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to his care. The mother's sister opposed the request and requested that the child be placed with another family. The respondent parents were to have unscheduled access to the applicant's residence. The applicant's sister was to be placed in temporary foster care. HELD: The child remained in the agency's custody. The court found that the circumstances had changed since the previous disposition order and that the parties had failed in addressing risk factors. The Agency was concerned that the biological father was not prepared to cooperate with the agency in addressing their risk factors which affected the health and safety of their child. This was the basis for the application for a protection order. The father was to have access to her residence.
column4: [1] The Children\'s Aid Society of Cape Breton-Victoria (agency) applied for an order of Permanent Care and Custody, with no provision for access, with respect to the child, S.N.D., born [in 2003]. However, the mother has a history of frequent changes of residences and this period of stability only has been a few months. [53] Although the mother loves her child and wants to care for her she does not seem to be able to put her child\'s needs ahead of her own needs. Therefore, the Court finds that an Order for access is not appropriate with respect to the mother and psychological father. [70] The Court is satisfied that an access Order for a limited period of six months (to expire on April 13, 2006) is appropriate in order to have the father\'s parenting capacity and circumstances assessed. The Agency is to arrange for a parental capacity assessment and the father is to make himself available for an assessment.

column8: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child. The mother opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to her care. The biological father was residing with the mother and providing care to the daughter. The child was charged with assault in June 2005 when the agency threatened to take the child from her. Court proceedings were not pursued when the biological grandmother consented to an order transferring custody of the child back to the mother. The father opposed the request and requested that the child remain in the care of the Agency. HELD: The child remained in the agency's custody subject to the terms and conditions of the protection finding. The agency reviewed the home visits to L.A.D. and J.C.E.'s homes and found that there was a substantial risk of physical harm caused by the mother's failure to supervise the child and that the risk of harm was higher for the psychological father than for the biological mother. There was no evidence that the biological father had any contact with the child prior to the hearing.

column13: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child. The agency alleged that the respondent parents had continually breached conditions of the court order and did not cooperate in addressing the risk factors identified at previous court hearings and acknowledged by the Respondents in consenting to a protection finding. HELD: 1) The child remained in the care of the agency and was eligible to remain in permanent care. 2) There was no evidence of physical harm caused by the mother and psychological father. 3) There were no threats to her safety. The child's safety was put at risk. 4) The burden of proof in proceeding such as this is clearly on the Agency. It is a civil burden of evidence that must have regard to the seriousness of the consequences of the decision.

column18: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child. The mother opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to her care. The biological father who had minimal contact with the child was added as a party by Order dated September 15, 2005. HELD: The child was placed in the permanent care of the Agency. The agency was concerned that the respondent mother and psychological father were not prepared to cooperate with the agency in addressing the risk factors which affected the child's health and well-being. The child had been in the Agency's care for three years. The Agency had taken the child into care because of instability in the home, the mother's repeated moves, the father's failure to supervise the child, and the risk that she may suffer harm through being removed from, kept away from, returned to or allowed to remain in the care of this Agency. There were ongoing problems in relation to the prior Supervision Order, including inappropriate parenting by the mother, the psychological father, the biological mother's sister and the 17 year old youth who were in the agency's care at the time of the child being apprehended, and a lack of cooperation between the Agency and the respondent parents.

column23: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child, S.N.D., born in 2003. The mother opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to her care. The biological father who had minimal contact with the child was added as a party by Order dated September 15, 2005. HELD: The child was placed in the permanent care of the Agency. The agency was concerned that the respondent mother and psychological father were not prepared to cooperate with the agency in addressing the risk factors which affected the child's health and well-being. The child had a history of domestic violence and was in the care of her mother and a psychological father who resided in several foster and group homes. The father was considered a parent or guardian pursuant to s. 36(1)(b) and 3(1) of the Child Protection Act. The Agency received information concerning inappropriate parenting by the mother and the psychological father. At a risk conference meeting on January 19, 2005 the agency decided to seek an order for access. The Respondent mother and her biological father were to attend and complete a treatment program for alcohol, prescription medication and street drugs. The psychological father was to have unscheduled access to the applicant's residence. The applicant's application for party status was adjourned because the parental capacity assessment was not completed until September 12, which did not allow sufficient time for review prior to hearing. The respondent mother was to attend a risk management conference meeting and requested that the child be placed for adoption, compared with the merits of the child remaining with or returning to parent or, guardian.
column24: [1] The Children\'s Aid Society of Cape Breton-Victoria (agency) applied for an order of Permanent Care and Custody, with no provision for access, with respect to the child, S.N.D., born [in 2003]. However, the mother has a history of frequent changes of residences and this period of stability only has been a few months. [53] Although the mother loves her child and wants to care for her she does not seem to be able to put her child\'s needs ahead of her own needs. Therefore, the Court finds that an Order for access is not appropriate with respect to the mother and psychological father. [70] The Court is satisfied that an access Order for a limited period of six months (to expire on April 13, 2006) is appropriate in order to have the father\'s parenting capacity and circumstances assessed. The Agency is to arrange for a parental capacity assessment and the father is to make himself available for an assessment.
column27: The agency applied for an order of care and custody with no provision for access with respect to the child, S.N.D., born in 2003. The mother opposed the application and requested an order returning the child to her care. The biological father who had minimal contact with the child was added as a party by Order dated September 15, 2005. HELD: The child was placed in the permanent care of the Agency. The agency was concerned that the respondent mother and psychological father were not prepared to cooperate with the agency in addressing the risk factors which affected the child's health and well-being. The child had a history of domestic violence and was in the care of her mother and a psychological father who resided in several foster and group homes. The father was considered a parent or guardian pursuant to s. 36(1)(b) and 3(1) of the Child Protection Act. The Agency received information concerning inappropriate parenting by the mother and the psychological father. At a risk conference meeting on January 19, 2005 the agency decided to seek an order for access. The Respondent mother and her biological father were to attend and complete a treatment program for alcohol, prescription medication and street drugs. The psychological father was to have unscheduled access to the applicant's residence. The applicant's application for party status was adjourned because the parental capacity assessment was not completed until September 12, which did not allow sufficient time for review prior to hearing. The respondent mother was to attend a risk management conference meeting and requested that the child be placed for adoption, compared with the merits of the child remaining with or returning to parent or, guardian.

column2: The wife sought to have the terms of the parties' separation agreement incorporated into the corollary relief judgment following a four year marriage. The husband sought to vary the provisions of the agreement regarding spousal and child support on the basis that the particulars of the agreement did not reflect his net business income derived from self-employment. The husband argued that he had entered into the separation agreement (which provided for joint custody of their young child, gave the wife all of the matrimonial assets with the exception of the husband's vehicle, and provided for spousal support in the amount of $600 per month for 15 years) only as an attempt to have the wife stay in the local area with the child. The wife had since moved with the child to New Brunswick where she was living with her parents and attending university; she was renting out the matrimonial home. Pursuant to the current court order, she was contributing the sum of $140 per month to the husband's access costs. Husband's current income set and child support awarded; the husband shall be responsible for 50 percent of the after tax child care costs; an additional $300 of spousal support ordered per month while the child remains in New Brunswick to address the access costs in the mother's budget; spousal support is reviewable in the event that these circumstances change, and at any rate, upon the completion of the mother's current degree; the mother shall not remove the child from the Province of New Brunswick to live in any other province without the father's consent. Although the court could not interfere with the agreement under s. 29 of the Matrimonial Property Act, the spousal and child support geared at keeping the wife in the local area and ensuring that her needs were addressed had all changed and a new arrangement was necessary to reflect the access costs among other issues. The wife had chosen to move away from child care services provided by the family that were practically free, as well as significant financial support and the ability to work in the furniture business with her father-in-law; she was not now pursuing a line of education which would build on her previous skills. Her educational expenses ought not be the basis for assessing spousal support and the duration of support set out in the separation agreement far exceeded what might be imposed by a court given the years they were together and their income disparity. The court reviewed the husband's history of income and expenses in setting his income for child support purposes.
column3: The petitioner sought a variation of the provisions regarding child support and spousal support in accordance with the Separation Agreement entered into between the parties in 2004. The parties were married for six years and had lived together for six months. The petitioner had commenced divorce proceedings in 2004 and had commenced living with her parents. The husband had commenced a new business and had made significant improvements to the home. The wife had recently commenced a degree in Business Administration and was seeking a variation in the provisions concerning child support. The respondent sought a reduction in the amount of child support, spousa and costs with a division of property. The mother had been working part-time as a social worker for the past six years. She had recently completed a degree and was pursuing a career in Business Management. The father had commenced work as a truck driver. The two parties had been married for four years and the parties had lived in separate and apart for six of that time. The marriage had been going on for some time. It was clear that the parties were in a relationship and that mobility would eventually become an issue. The court found that the respondent had not made an effort to negotiate a mobility restriction clause. The agreement was not a complete and complete agreement. The applicant had not been able to obtain employment insurance and was not able to pay child support on the basis of her income. The Court found that there was no evidence that the petitioner had suffered from any obstacle or impairment.

column2: The petitioner seeks child and spousal support. The parties signed a separation agreement and interspousal contract in July 2004. With respect to spousal support the agreement provides that it is the intention of the parties that spousal support will be based on a division of income until July 1, 2011.HELD: 1) The petitioner seeks a spousal support order in which the court is asked to impute income and then apply the provisions of their interspousal contract to determine quantum. The interspousal contract does not contemplate variation of the spousal support obligation in the event of a material change of circumstance. It will be for the trial judge to determine the intention of the parties when the agreement makes reference to the adjustments which 'will consider Technologies likely future earnings based upon whether Paul's contract is renewed with the Provincial Government'. This is not an appropriate case in which to make an order for interim spousal support. The petitioner is entitled to support under the agreement and in the circumstances as they presently exist. 2) With regard to child support, there is no question that Melanie remains a child of the marriage while she is attending her educational program. Insofar at the respondent's income is concerned, the gross income to the corporation is $65,000 per year. The respondent provided a pay stub for May 2006. It is not really a pay stub, but extrapolating from that statement the court concluded that the respondent's gross taxable income from the corporation as a result of the $65,000 contract is approximately $53,000. Child support will be ordered based on $53,000 on an interim basis.
column3: The petitioner sought child support and spousal support pending trial. The parties signed a separation agreement and interspousal contract in July 2004. The agreement provided that the respondent would pay one half of the net income to the petitioner by way of equal monthly payments of spousals. The petitioner was to work part-time and the respondent was to pay $65 per month in the amount of $741 per month for the support of their two children. The respondent was not to pay any spousousal assistance. The court noted that the agreement did not contemplate a variation of spouse support obligation in the event of a material change in circumstances.

column13: The petitioner sought child support and spousal support pending trial. The parties signed a separation agreement and interspousal contract in July 2004. The agreement provided that the respondent was to pay one half of the net income to the petitioner by way of equal monthly payments of spousals. The petitioner was to work part-time for travel agency earning $1,473 per month. She may be able to gain full-time employment with her employer at the end of 2006. HELD: 1)The petitioner was entitled to support under the agreement and the circumstances as they presently existed. The interspouse contract did not contemplate a variation of the spousa support obligation in the event of a material change in circumstances. 2)The respondent was not to pay child support. The amount of his income was $65,000. There was no evidence that he had done anything to look for suitable work. 3)There were no circumstances in this case which elevate it to one of those 'rare cases' where the parties' relationship was long one (more than 25 years), the roles of the parties and the validity of their agreement was clearly disputed. 4)While Court can order interim spousAL support where there is an agreement, it should be hesitant to do so. The court on an interim application must be careful not to pre-judge the issue and thereby usurp the role of the trial judge. 5)The agreement was not intended to vary the respondent’s income. It was intended that the parties’ sousal agreement would be in substantial compliance with the objectives of the Divorce Act.  6)The parties had signed a comprehensive agreement which dealt with parenting issues, child support, child care and the division of family property. The respondent had been employed with an annual salary of $100,000 and received severance package of $74,000 from Canada Pension Plan. The husband was employed with a trucking business. In April 2004 he received a package of severance packages of $490 per month from the Provincial Government. In June 2006 he started a ten-month program in hairdressing training. During that time he received lump sum, ongoing and ongoing support until July 2001. The actual amount of the expenses may be somewhat more or somewhat less than the actual amount. 7)In the circumstances, this was not an appropriate case in which to make an order for interim support.  8)The court was not concerned with the gross income.

column23: The petitioner sought child support and spousal support pending trial. The parties signed a separation agreement and interspousal contract on July 16, 2004. The agreement provided that the parties would pay one half of the net income to the petitioner by way of equal monthly payments of support. The respondent was employed with an annual salary of $100,000. The petitioner claimed material change in circumstance due to the loss of his trucking business. HELD: The petitioner was entitled to support under the agreement and the circumstances as they presently existed. 1)The agreement does not contemplate a variation of the spousals support obligation in the event of a material change. 2)The respondent was to pay $65,000 per annum in the amount of $741 per month for the support of their two children. The amount payable shall be reduced in an amount equal to 40% of the petitioner's income that she has earned. It will be for the trial judge to determine the intention of the parties when the agreement makes reference in paragraphs 7.3 and 7.5 to adjustments which will consider likely future earnings based upon whether Paul's contract is renewed with the Provincial Government. 3)There were no circumstances in this case that elevate it to one of those 'rare cases' where the parties reached their agreement at a pre-trial conference where they were both represented by counsel and the agreement was in substantial compliance with the objectives of the Divorce Act. It was not feasible to apply Miglin, supra, analysis. 4)The petitioner is entitled to financial assistance under the terms of the agreement. It is not an appropriate case in which to make an order for interim support.  5)While the parties had signed a comprehensive agreement which dealt with parenting issues, child support, child care and the division of family property, the agreement recognized that there were risks that the respondent's contract may not be renewed and on the principles set forth in Miglin v. Miglin (2003 SCJ 21). The parties agreed that the petitioner would receive all of her net income and then apply the provisions of their interspouseal contract to determine quantum.  6)It is not possible to extrapolate net income from the parties' previous agreement to reflect the projected future earnings. If this Court was to award interim support to Ms. Palmer it would be difficult to apply the Miglin analysis. If the court finds that the agreement should be set aside, they have the power to make a retroactive spousAL support order.

column2: The respondent applies for an order varying the custody order by changing the primary residence from the petitioner to the respondent. HELD: 1) The present circumstances are remarkably similar to the circumstances in Bzowey v. Bzowey, 2005 SKQB 12. In both cases, the Court is asked to make the change based solely on the wishes of the child. There is even evidence from the custody and access report from 2005 that the children, or at least the older child, Jill, expressed similar sentiments about living with her mother. It cannot even be strenuously argued that the wishes of the child, Jill, have in fact changed. Those considerations were before the Court in the form of the custody and access report when the decision was made in 2005. 2) The Court should be loathe to make a variation order solely on the expressed wishes of a child of 11 or 12 years of age without some evidence as to why that current expression of interest has been stated. It may well be that the child truly does wish a change. It may also be that the child, as was referred to in the custody and access report, may be simply reflecting the views and therefore the pressures placed on the child by the non-custodial parent. 3) No evidence has been put forward about the negative impact of the continuation of the current order. There is no information before the Court to suggest that the current situation is no longer in the best interests of the children. No material change has been demonstrated. The application is dismissed.
column3: The father brought an application for an order varying the child support order granted by the court. The father argued that there had been a clear declaration in two separate writings of the oldest child's desire to have primary residence change from her father to her mother. Further, there was some evidence that the younger child wishes to live with her mother or live with a similar residence as her older sister. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)As no material change has been demonstrated, the court found that the application must be dismissed. 2)The court found no material difference in the circumstances of the child. The court found as no material changes had been demonstrated that this application must not be dismissed as it was not in the child's best interests.
