HELD: The appeal is dismissed with cost on double Column V. The Board acted entirely within the terms of its original order, an order in which it had retained jurisdiction, to confirm compliance with the order and which had been confirmed by the Court of Appeal. The extent of the order, that is whether it was confined to the external access of the property or to other 'facilities and services' and whether it had been complied with is the very question the Board reserved jurisdiction to determine.
column24: Appeal Dismissed: The appellant appeals contending that the Board exceeded its jurisdiction in making the order that it did. [8] On May 29, 1998, the Board ordered that the appellant “construct or renovate bathrooms for both sexes, or a single washroom provided that it can be used by both sexes in accordance with public health and building regulations, which meet all the accessibility requirements of the National Building Code”. He found that the Board did not err in adding the company HRK Collections Fine Art Limited as a party and did not exceed its jurisdiction in finding that the appellant had not complied with its original order. The appellant contended that the original order did not include a requirement that it construct washrooms which were accessible to wheelchair reliant members of the public. The Board acted entirely within the terms of its original order, an order in which it had retained jurisdiction, to confirm compliance with the order and which had been confirmed by this Court. [14] In the result the appeal is dismissed with cost on double Column V.

The original order cannot be challenged at this late date. The appeal was dismissed with costs on double column V.

column2: The mother moved for the dismissal of the pending permanent care trial, arguing that, applying the reasoning in a recent Court of Appeal decision, the court had lost jurisdiction. No trial had been held on any issue as all matters had proceeded to this point with the consent of the parties. The time for trial had been extended to allow the mother to retain counsel. Application dismissed; the court had not lost jurisdiction; trial to proceed. The Court of Appeal decision stands for the proposition that, once a trial at any stage of the Act is held, no order can have effect beyond the next statutory deadline; however, this is so only when the extensions are included in an order which follows trial. When the best interests of the child require it, an extension of a statutory deadline can be made in order to have a trial completed in respect of any stage of the Act. When the plan of care changes from reunification to permanent care close to the particular deadline, it is not in a child's best interest for the court to order a rushed trial date.
column3: The mother sought a dismissal of the matter on the basis that the trial date was after the outside disposition date provided in the Act. The Court of Appeal had issued a decision in October 2003 referred to as Nova Scotia Minister of Community Service v. B.F. that confirmed that the judge had not lost jurisdiction despite the fact that the agency had not yet made an order for permanent care. The mother also sought a stay of proceedings pending the outcome of a protection finding and disposition hearing. HELD: The Court held that it had not been lost jurisdiction to dismiss the matter. The court had not considered the issue of jurisdiction in the B.W. case. The trial date is after the date set out in the H.W.' decision. When the plan of care changes from reunification to permanent care close to the particular deadline, it is not in a child's best interest for a rushed trial date.
column4: I have before me a motion in this case under the Children and Family Services Act, S.N.S. 1990. c.5 (which I will hereinafter refer to as the "Act") by which the mother asks for a dismissal of this matter on the basis that I have lost my jurisdiction to hear the case because the trial date is after the outside disposition date provided in the Act. The Court of Appeal issued a decision, subsequent to my ruling, in October 2003 referred to as Nova Scotia (Minister of Community Service) v. B.F. at 2003 NSCA 119 (CanLII), 2003 N.S.J. 405 which I will hereinafter refer to as B.F. This morning, as mentioned, counsel for the mother made a motion that based on the rule in B.F. I had lost my jurisdiction and must dismiss the matter. When the plan of care changes from reunification to permanent care close to the particular deadline, it is not in a child’s best interest for a rushed trial date. In summary, the H.W. case stands for the following principle: when the best interests of the child requires it, an extension of a deadline to make a determination at the then stage of the proceeding by trial or otherwise is acceptable and no loss of jurisdiction occurs. In my opinion, the B.F. case stands for the following proposition: once the determination at a particular stage of the proceeding is made at trial or otherwise, and with the exception of reserving the Court’s decision, no order can have effect beyond the statutory deadline. In conclusion, the Court has not lost its jurisdiction in this matter and the trial will commence tomorrow.

column13: This was a child protection proceeding in respect of a child who was under the age of six when taken into care. There was a delay in the proceeding due to primary child protection concerns. The agency planning for the reunification of the mother and child required some psychological counselling. The trial judge had not lost jurisdiction despite the fact that the agency had not yet made a plan that called for permanent care with the child. Counsel for the mother made a motion that based on the rule in B.F. I had lost my jurisdiction and must dismiss the matter. HELD: The Court has not lost its jurisdiction in this matter and the trial will commence tomorrow. 1)When the plan of care changes from reunification to permanent care close to the particular deadline, it is not in a child's best interest for a rushed trial date. There may be need for the preparation of expert reports and other trial preparation and to ascertain whether ongoing further services would have resolved the problem. 2)There was good reason for the Court to be faced with the dilemma of either taking the drastic step of an immediate reapprehension and consolidation of the various initial proceedings from interim hearing through protection finding and then to disposition in order to preserve the existing trial dates. In the H.W. decision the proceeding had been approaching the first disposition deadline under s. 41(1) of the Act and it was done after ruling that it was in the child’s best interests to do so. The Court of Appeal issued a decision in October 2003 referred to as Nova Scotia (Minister of Community Service) v. B. F. at 2003 NSCA 119 (CanLII), 2003 N.S.J. 405 which the Court will refer to as BCF. 3)The Court had no jurisdiction to dismiss the motion. It was not in its jurisdiction to make an order after the trial because the trial date is after the outside disposition date provided in the Act.

column23: The mother sought a dismissal of a motion under the Children and Family Services Act by which she asked for a dismissal on the basis that the trial date was after the outside disposition date provided in the Act. The Court of Appeal issued a decision in October 2003 referred to as Nova Scotia (Minister of Community Service) v. B.F. at 2003 NSCA 119 which confirmed the trial judge had not lost jurisdiction despite the fact that the agency was moving toward a hearing which was designed to decide the overall best interests of the child and therefore the type of disposition order that should best protect the child. HELD: The Court has not lost its jurisdiction in this matter and the trial will commence tomorrow. 1)When the plan of care changes from reunification to permanent care close to the particular deadline, it is not in a child's best interest for a rushed trial date. There may be need for the preparation of expert reports and other trial preparation and to ascertain whether ongoing further services would have resolved the problem. 2)There was good reason for the Court to be faced with the dilemma of either taking the drastic step of an immediate reapprehension and consolidation of the various initial proceedings from interim hearing through protection finding and then to disposition in order to preserve the existing trial dates. In the H.W. decision the proceeding had been approaching the first disposition deadline under section 41(1) of the Act and the agency planning for the reunification of the mother and child required some psychological counselling for the mother. She made a number of changes in the counselling providers over a period of time. The agency had not yet been able to offer the needed protection and pursue the primary and ultimate goal of reunification with the parents. 3)Reapprehension will expose the child to the very delay the deadlines are designed to avoid since each of the stages set out in the act (interim hearing, protection finding, at least one disposition hearing) will run their course in the absence of consent to consolidation under s40(2)of the act. If time line extensions can never be given in those rare cases, the Court has only one remedy and it is very rough one, not always the best one. 4)The Court can only order the agency to reapprehend. Although protection concerns may have been insufficient to justify an order for permanent care, they nonetheless may require intervention by the court.

column2: The accused was charged with operating a motor vehicle while impaired by alcohol or drug (Code ss.253(a) and 255(1)). The accused admitted to consuming one vodka cooler before driving but argued the signs of impairment were manifestations of his panic attack. No .08 charge was laid, as his readings were .07 and .06. HELD: The accused was found guilty of impaired driving. The evidence did not support the argument that he was in the throws of a panic attack. The blood-alcohol readings show he was below the legal limit but the signs and symptoms of impairment by alcohol proved beyond a reasonable doubt his ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol. As stated in McCallum, the fact that the effects of alcohol may have been exacerbated by the accused suffering from fatigue does not provide a defence to the charge.
column3: The accused was charged with having the care or control of a motor vehicle while his ability to operate a motor car was impaired by alcohol or drugs. The accused was found guilty of driving while having the ability to drive while his blood alcohol content was over the legal limit. The Court found that the accused's evidence raised a reasonable doubt as to his guilt. HELD: The Court held that the evidence was not supported by the evidence. The blood alcohol level was below the legal threshold and the evidence together with the other evidence did not support the accused’s diagnosis of a panic attack. The court found that evidence togetherwith the other factors involving consumption of alcohol and the signs and symptoms of impairment by alcohol did not prove beyond a reasonable limit that the officer’d ability to operating a motor vehicles was impaired. The defence position was that the signs, symptoms of impaired displayed by the accused were the result of a Panic Attack. The evidence did support the officer who testified that he was in the throws of a “panic attack”. The officer who was driving the police vehicle testified that the symptoms of a possible panic attack were the symptoms consistent with a panic assault. The police officer testified that they were focused on impairment by the presence of alcohol because they had been told by their dispatcher that the operator of the two-toned brown Ford pick-up might be drunk. The officers testified that this focus blinded the police from seeing any other possibilities. The test results did not provide a reasonable suspicion as to the accused being in the 'palladium court' as the accused was driving a truck that swerved into the left-hand side of the road more than four times. The breath test was performed to determine whether the accused had a panic disorder. The results of the breath test were negative. The alcohol was not involved in the test results. The tests were negative and the blood alcohol was found to be within the legal definition of a 'possible' panic attack, which is a severe form of alcohol intoxication. The symptoms of the accused when he testified that his panic attack was consistent with one were: a panic, a generalized anxiety disorder (G.A.D.), severe fatigue, shortness of breath, short shortness in breath, and shortnessness of air. The medical evidence did raise a reasonable question as to whether the officer was impaired in any way. The trial judge also found that there was no evidence of impairment in the accused.
column4: [1] The accused is charged that on the 24th day of September, 2001, at the Prince Albert District in the Province of Saskatchewan, he had the care or control of a motor vehicle while his ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or a drug. The defence position is that the signs and symptoms of impairment displayed by the accused were the result of, or were equally consistent with, a panic attack. [20] The blood-alcohol readings testified to show that the accused was below the legal limit but in my view that evidence together with the other evidence involving consumption of alcohol and the signs and symptoms of impairment by alcohol prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused’s ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol: [21] I find the accused guilty as charged.

The accused was found guilty of driving while having the ability to drive while having a panic attack. HELD: The Court found that the accused's evidence raised a reasonable doubt as to his guilt. The Court considered the evidence of the RCMP officer who had responded to the scene of an assault and found the accused to be suffering from generalized anxiety disorder (G.A.D.). The Court also found that evidence of impairment displayed by the accused was not supported by the evidence. The blood alcohol content of the breath test was at.08. The court found that there was no evidence of a panic disorder. The evidence of an RCMP officer and the signs and symptoms of impairment were the same as those of the accused when he testified that he was in the throws of the panic attack and that his evidence and that of the doctor raise a reasonable suspicion of his being in such an attack.

[20] The blood-alcohol readings testified to show that the accused was below the legal limit but in my view that evidence together with the other evidence involving consumption of alcohol and the signs and symptoms of impairment by alcohol prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused’s ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol: [21] I find the accused guilty as charged.
column27: The accused was charged with having the care or control of a motor vehicle while his ability to operate a vehicle was impaired by alcohol or drugs. HELD: The accused was found guilty. The court found that the signs and symptoms of impairment displayed by the accused were the result of a panic attack not from the consumption of alcohol. The Court found that evidence of impairment did not raise a reasonable doubt as to his guilt.

column2: The deceased was a master's student who also worked as a student assistant at the University of Saskatchewan. He became ill while teaching a class. His students helped him to the faculty lounge. He was found in the faculty washroom unconscious and not breathing approximately 30 minutes later. Emergency medical technicians were not able to resuscitate him and he was pronounced dead at the Royal University Hospital. An application for dependants' benefits was submitted over 3 years later. The Workers' Compensation Board denied the claim finding that the deceased was not found dead at work and because of the delay in bringing the claim. The applicant brought an application for an order of certiorari pursuant to Queen's Bench Rule 664 and mandamus pursuant to Queen's Bench Rule 674. HELD: 1) The Board acted outside of its jurisdiction in denying dependant benefits to the applicant based upon a determination that the deceased was not found dead within the meaning of s. 30 of The Workers' Compensation Act, 1979. The case law clearly precludes an analysis of s. 30 of the Act as in any way representing a rebuttable presumption. 2) The Board acted outside its jurisdiction in not applying the presumption in s. 30 of the Act in favour of the applicant. 3) The Board waived the right to rely upon the delay in bringing the claim after the Board participated in a variety of levels of proceeding, including two hearings, and only raised the issue of delay at the final hearing. 4) The application was allowed with costs to the applicant on a party and party basis.
column3: The respondent Board refused to grant the applicant dependants' benefits on the basis that it had not received notice of the applicant's death and that the applicant had not applied for benefits within the six month period contemplated in the Workers' Compensation Act. The respondent Board applied for the application under s. 45 of the Act and found that the deceased spouse was not found dead within the meaning of s. 30 of the act. The applicant applied for dependants’ benefits under s45 of the legislation. Application denied; the respondent Board did not act within its jurisdiction to deny the applicant’s claim. The Board did have jurisdiction to determine the cause of death of the deceased and did not have the power to make a determination on the merits.
column4: [1] The applicant, by way of notice of motion seeks the following relief: a. An Order by way of certiorari, pursuant to Rule 664 of the Queen’s Bench Rules of Court, to quash the decision of the Workers’ Compensation Board dated November 20, 2002; b. An Order by way of mandamus, pursuant to Rule 674 of the Queen’s Bench Rules of Court, remitting the matter of the Applicants’ claim for benefits back to the Workers’ Compensation Board of Saskatchewan to be dealt with according to law; [13] Ultimately, an application for dependants’ benefits was submitted to the Saskatchewan Workers’ Compensation Board by a representative, Mr. Alex Taylor, on behalf of the applicant, on July 16, 2001. The applicant thereupon notified the Board on October 14, 2001 that she wished to appeal the September 18, 2001 denial of her claim, and on October 29, 2001, the Board issued a formal written decision, denying Gloria Truitt’s appeal because “Mr. Truitt was not found dead at his place of employment on March 2, 1998.” Based upon the foregoing application of Sections 45 and 47, or in the alternative Section 30, the appeal is denied. The appeal should be accepted. Accordingly, I am of the view that the Board did act outside its jurisdiction in denying dependant benefits to the applicant based upon a determination that the applicant’s deceased spouse was not found dead within the meaning of s. 30 of the Act. The majority decision in Henry v. Saskatchewan (Workers’ Compensation Board), supra, clearly precludes approaching an analysis of s. 30 as in any way representing a rebuttable presumption. [36] For the fundamental reasons set forth in the above analysis, I am of the view that the Board did act outside its jurisdiction in not applying the presumption in favour of the applicant. The appeal is denied. [46] I am of the view, for the foregoing reasons, that the Board has waived the right to rely upon the delay in bringing the claim. Here, the Board participated in a variety of levels of proceeding, including two hearings, and only raised the issue of delay at the final hearing. [53] The applicant has demonstrated an entitlement to an order by way of certiorari, pursuant to Rule 664 of the Queen’s Bench Rules of Court, quashing the decision of the Workers’ Compensation Board dated November 22, 2002, and further for an order by way of mandamus, pursuant to Rule 674 of the Queen’s Bench Rules of Court, remitting the matter of the applicant’s claim for benefits back to the Workers’ Compensation Board of Saskatchewan to be dealt with according to law, and so order. Further, there shall be an attendant order of mandamus compelling the Board to perform its statutory duty to apply the presumption set forth in s. 30 of The Workers’ Compensation Act, 1979, supra, in the applicant’s favour. [54] The applicant shall have her costs of the motion, on a party and party basis, to be taxed.

column8: HELD: The application for dependants' benefits was denied. The Court held that s. 45 of the Workers' Compensation Act was not appropriate. The provisions of s. 30 of the Act did not apply to the application. The court reviewed the relevant provisions and found that the respondent Board acted outside its jurisdiction in denying the applicant's claim for benefits based upon its finding that the deceased spouse was not found dead within the meaning of the act. The respondent Board did not make an application for benefits to the applicant. The applicant did not submit an application to the respondent board.

column13: HELD: The application for dependants' benefits was denied. Ultimately, an application for benefits was submitted to the Saskatchewan Workers' Compensation Board by a representative on behalf of the applicant. The notice of motion set forth the following grounds: 1) the respondent Board acted outside its jurisdiction in denying the applicant's claim for benefits based upon its finding that the deceased spouse was not found dead within the meaning of s. 30 of the Act; 2) there was no uncertainty as to the cause of the deceased's death as neither the employer nor the applicant believed that the death was related to his employment; and 3) there were no compelling reasons for the delay that would warrant waiving the six-month limitation period. The applicant had become aware of the potential rights in early July 2001 during a casual conversation at her workplace. It was suggested to her that because the deceased did not apply for benefits within the six month period contemplated in s. 45, it was assumed that he died in the course of his employment. The respondent Board did not notify the Board of its decision regarding the death of her husband. The Board considered the privative clause found in s22 of the legislation and, in light of that, considered it to be patent unreasonableness. It concluded that the Board had made an error in its interpretation of the legislative provision limiting the tribunal's powers. Accordingly, the appeal is denied.

column18: HELD: The application for dependants' benefits was denied. Ultimately, an application for benefits was submitted to the Saskatchewan Workers' Compensation Board by a representative on behalf of the applicant. The notice of motion set forth the following grounds: 1) the respondent Board acted outside its jurisdiction in denying the applicant's claim for benefits based upon its finding that the deceased spouse was not found dead within the meaning of s. 30 of the Act; and 2) there was no uncertainty as to the cause of his unfortunate demise. column2: The Crown elected to proceed summarily and the accused entered a plea of guilty to a charge of assault under S.266 of the Code. He was sentenced to 6 months imprisonment, 18 months probation and a 10 year fire arm prohibition was imposed. He appealed his sentence. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)Because the accused had no related record and given the circumstances of the assault, the sentence of imprisonment was reduced to time already served (15 days). 2)The trial judge erred in imposing the 10 year fire arm prohibition under S.100 of the Code. S.100 requires a conviction on an indictable offence involving violence against a person where the maximum sentence available is 10 years imprisonment or more. 3)The maximum sentence for assault under S.266 is 5 years if the Crown proceeds by indictment and 6 months if, as here, the Crown proceeds summarily.
column3: The accused was convicted of an assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to a term of 6 months imprisonment and to enter into a probation order for a term 18 months on certain specific conditions. A ten-year firearm, ammunition and explosive substance prohibition order was made against the appellant pursuant to s100(1) of the Code. The accused appealed the sentence and reduced the term of imprisonment imposed at trial from 6 months to "time served" and maintained the 18 month probation order subject only to amending the time within which the appellant was to report to the chief probation officer as therein provided. HELD: The appeal was allowed and it was set aside. 1)The sentencing principles of protection of society, deterrence, general and specific deterrence, reformation and rehabilitation and the need to maintain the public's confidence in the administration of justice were applied. 2)The sentence imposed was too severe. The appellant had now served 15 days of the sentence. He had now completed 15 days already served. The sentence imposed ought to be reduced to time already served by the Crown. 3)The prohibition order for firearms, ammunition, explosives and prohibited substances was reduced to a probation prohibition order subject to amend time within the appellant's report to chief probation officers as therein. 4)The appellant was convicted for an indictable offence in the commission of a violent offence. The firearm prohibition order did not exist. 5)The accused had already served 15 months of the probation order. 6)The sentences were reduced to 18 months.
column4:
On August 4, 1994, the then presiding judge of
the Provincial Court of Saskatchewan sentenced the accused to
serve a term of six months\' imprisonment and to enter into a
probation order for a term of 18 months on certain specific
conditions. As well, a ten-year firearm, ammunition and
explosive substance prohibition order was made against the
appellant pursuant to the provisions of s. 100(1) of the
Criminal Code, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-46. This is an appeal against (1) said six-month term
of imprisonment and (2) said s. 100(1) prohibition order. In these circumstances, having regard for the
applicable sentencing principles of protection of society,
punishment, general and specific deterrence, reformation and
rehabilitation, and the need to maintain the public\'s
confidence in the administration of justice, and, after
applying thereto the various applicable factors as discussed
by and with both counsel during the hearing of this appeal, I
allowed the appeal against sentence and reduced the term
imposed at trial from six months\' imprisonment to "time
served" and maintained the 18 month probation order (against
which no appeal was taken) subject only to amending the time
within which the appellant was to report to the chief
probation officer as therein provided. As earlier observed the appellant was charged and
on his plea of guilty thereto was convicted of an offence
contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code which provides as
follows:

266. Every one who commits an assault is
guilty of

(a) an indictable offence and is liable to
imprisonment for a term not exceeding five
years; or

(b) an offence punishable on summary
conviction. more. In the particular circumstances, as the requisite
two pre-conditions did not exist, the Provincial Court judge
erred in making the noted s. 100(1) prohibition order.

HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)Because the accused had no related record and given the circumstances of the assault, the sentence of imprisonment was reduced to time already served (15 days). 2)The trial judge erred in imposing the 10 year fire arm prohibition under S.100 of the Code. S.100 requires a conviction on an indictable offence involving violence against a person where the maximum sentence available is 10 years imprisonment or more. 3)The maximum sentence for assault under S.266 is 5 years if the Crown proceeds by indictment and 6 months if, as here, the Crown proceeds summarily.
column8: The accused was convicted of an assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to a term of 6 months imprisonment and to enter into a probation order for a term for 18 months on certain specific conditions. A ten-year firearm, ammunition and explosive substance prohibition order was made against the appellant pursuant to the provisions of s. 81(1)(a) of the Code. The accused appealed the sentence and reduced the term of imprisonment imposed at trial from 6 months to "time served" and maintained the 18 month probation order subject only to amending the time within which the appellant was to report to the chief probation officer as therein provided. HELD: The appeal was allowed and it was set aside. 1)The sentencing principles of protection of society, punishment, general and specific deterrence, reformation and rehabilitation and the need to maintain the public's confidence in the administration of justice were applied. 2)The sentence imposed was too severe. The appellant had now served 15 days of the sentence. He commenced serving the noted sentence of 18 months. 3)The prohibition order had been reduced to 18 months subject to an adjustment in time.

On August 4, 1994, the then presiding judge of
the Provincial Court of Saskatchewan sentenced the accused to
serve a term of six months\' imprisonment and to enter into a
probation order for a term of 18 months on certain specific
conditions. As well, a ten-year firearm, ammunition and
explosive substance prohibition order was made against the
appellant pursuant to the provisions of s. 100(1) of the
Criminal Code, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-46. This is an appeal against (1) said six-month term
of imprisonment and (2) said s. 100(1) prohibition order. In these circumstances, having regard for the
applicable sentencing principles of protection of society,
punishment, general and specific deterrence, reformation and
rehabilitation, and the need to maintain the public\'s
confidence in the administration of justice, and, after
applying thereto the various applicable factors as discussed
by and with both counsel during the hearing of this appeal, I
allowed the appeal against sentence and reduced the term
imposed at trial from six months\' imprisonment to "time
served" and maintained the 18 month probation order (against
which no appeal was taken) subject only to amending the time
within which the appellant was to report to the chief
probation officer as therein provided. As earlier observed the appellant was charged and
on his plea of guilty thereto was convicted of an offence
contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code which provides as
follows:

266. Every one who commits an assault is
guilty of

(a) an indictable offence and is liable to
imprisonment for a term not exceeding five
years; or

(b) an offence punishable on summary
conviction. more. In the particular circumstances, as the requisite
two pre-conditions did not exist, the Provincial Court judge
erred in making the noted s. 100(1) prohibition order.

column2: FIAT Matrimonial property dispute. A previous order had prohibited the removal of any assets from the matrimonial home and the disposal of all other assets. By this fiat an order was granted pursuant to Queen's Bench Rule 344 itemizing the household contents and personal items removed by the respondent from the matrimonial home in order to allow for a Writ of Delivery and prohibiting the respondent from disposing of any of the assets that the respondent had removed from the matrimonial home and also requiring him to pay all outstanding utility payments and other expenses associated with his occupation of the matrimonial home. The judge declined to cite the respondent for contempt.
column3: FIAT. Following a trial before me in November 1993, I issued a judgment dealing with a number of issues including the division of matrimonial property. When the evidence concluded but before heard argument, issued the following fiat: Order that there be nothing removed from the matrimononial home or any other assets disposed of until further ordered. HELD: The motion was granted. The court was left with no alternative but to assist the petitioner in regaining the assets taken out of the house by granting an order pursuant to Rule 344 of the Queen's Bench Rules prohibiting the respondent from disposing of any of the assets that the petitioner removed from her matrimony home. An order requiring the respondent to pay all outstanding utilities and other expenses associated with his occupation of the matonial home up to and including December 26, 1993, as well as any losses experienced as a result of no insurance coverage between September 28, 1993 and December 29, 1993.

column2: The accused was convicted of assault. He contends that the trial judge so concerned himself with the question of credibility of the complainant and the accused that he overlooked his duty to consider evidence of a witness, 'together with the rest of the evidence, with a view to determining whether it raised a reasonable doubt of the appellant's guilt, irrespective of whether he believed the evidence of the complainant.' HELD: Appeal dismissed and conviction accordingly affirmed.  1)Great deference to findings of credibility made at trial should be shown. 2)The trial judge did not say that he found the accused guilty only upon the credibility of the complainant and the accused. He said that he found the Crown's evidence to be credible, and the accused's evidence not to be credible. The Crown's evidence was comprised of both the complainant and the witness. 3)The trial judge's findings are supported by the evidence and his conclusions are not clearly wrong so as to make the conviction unreasonable.
column3: The appellant was convicted of assault contrary to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. He argued the necessary implication is that the trial judge took into account only the evidence of the complainant and the accused to the exclusion of the accused. HELD: The appellant was found guilty. 1)The trial judge concerned himself with the credibility of the evidence and not the credibility. He said he found the Crown's evidence to be credible, and the Crown’s evidence not to becredible. 2)The court overlooked his duty to consider such evidence together with the rest of theevidence with a view to determining whether it raised a reasonable doubt of the appellant’ s guilt. 3)The accused was found not guilty only upon the credibility and evidence of both the complainant & the accused but because he found both the Crown and the complainant to be unreliable. He also said he thought the Crown had evidence that was credible and not credible.
column4:
After
a trial before a judge of the Provincial Court, he was convicted of
the charge. His
contention, as I understand it to be, is that the trial judge so
concerned himself with the question of the credibility of the
evidence of the complainant and the accused that he overlooked his
duty to consider such evidence, "together with the rest of the
evidence, with a view to determining whether it raised a reasonable
doubt of the appellant\'s guilt, irrespective of whether he believed
the evidence of the (complainant)": Here the trial judge did not, I suggest, say that he found
the accused guilty only upon the credibility of the evidence of
the complainant and the accused. He said he found the Crown\'s
evidence to be credible, and the accused\'s evidence not to be
credible. Upon a consideration of all the evidence in
the transcript thereof, and "having due regard to the advantages
afforded to the trial judge", it cannot be said his findings are
not supported by the evidence, nor can it be said his conclusions
are clearly wrong so as to make the conviction unreasonable. In the result, the appeal against the conviction is
dismissed, and accordingly affirmed.

the evidence of the (complainant)": Here the trial judge did not, I suggest, say that he found
the accused guilty only upon the credibility of the evidence of
the complainant and the accused. He said he found the Crown\'s
evidence to be credible, and the accused\'s evidence not to be
credible. Upon a consideration of all the evidence in
the transcript thereof, and "having due regard to the advantages
afforded to the trial judge", it cannot be said his findings are
not supported by the evidence, nor can it be said his conclusions
are clearly wrong so as to make the conviction unreasonable. In the result, the appeal against the conviction is
dismissed, and accordingly affirmed.
column22: The accused was convicted of assault. He contends that the trial judge so concerned himself with the question of credibility of the complainant and the accused that he overlooked his duty to consider evidence of a witness, 'together with the rest of the evidence, with a view to determining whether it raised a reasonable doubt of the appellant's guilt, irrespective of whether he believed the evidence of the complainant.' HELD: Appeal dismissed and conviction accordingly affirmed.  1)Great deference to findings of credibility made at trial should be shown. 2)The trial judge did not say that he found the accused guilty only upon the credibility of the complainant and the accused. He said that he found the Crown's evidence to be credible, and the accused's evidence not to be credible. The Crown's evidence was comprised of both the complainant and the witness. 3)The trial judge's findings are supported by the evidence and his conclusions are not clearly wrong so as to make the conviction unreasonable.

column2: The parties have two children, a son born March 1990 and a daughter December 1991. A trial on the issues of the son's residence in 2006, the parties' income for the purposes of child support and any s. 7 expenses was held. HELD: 1) From September 2006 to February 2007 the parties shared custody of the son. This is a period of no more than 5 months. Thereafter he resumed living with his grandmother and was supported by his mother. The father does not meet the threshold provided for in s. 9 of the Guidelines.  2) The father's income from employment shows earning of $108,629. The mother's income consisted only of investment income of $1,672.37 and allowance of $2,000. 3) The parties have been divorced since 1998. The son has played baseball since 2004. The daughter has speed skated since 2001. The mother has paid the extraordinary expenses of both children, without reimbursement from the father. It was only in 2006 that the father paid any of the son's expenses. Accordingly, 2006 is not the appropriate year to begin reimbursing the father for expenses he may have paid for him. To do so would be exceedingly unfair to the mother who has borne the expenses of both children on her own for many years.  4) The children's expenses related to fees, registration and equipment for baseball and speed skating are extraordinary expenses within the meaning of s. 7 of the Guidelines. The expenses may be estimated at $2,000 for baseball and $1,000 for speed skating, annually. The orthodontic work, which is estimated at $2,522 should be amortized over two years. The alternative acne treatment, proposed by the mother for the daughter is not an appropriate health related expense in the absence of a medical referral or prescription. The father's proportionate share is 80% and the mother's is 20%. Paid monthly the father's payment is $284. 5) Although the mother did not bring an application to vary child support upward, the filing of the application to vary by the father is sufficient to re-determine the issue of child support based on current incomes. The current support order is based on the father's income of $87,794. His income is considerably higher now. His child support payments are adjusted accordingly.
column3: The respondent father applied to vary an order made May 14, 2002. The order provided for child support payable to the petitioner mother on behalf of the two youngest children, Michael, born March 15, 1990, and Jessica, born December 30, 1991. The parties had been divorced for over a year. The father had the use of his mother's vehicle because she was in Viet Nam visiting her husband. This ended in January or February 2007, which is a period of no more than 5 months. The mother did not bring an application to vary child support upward. HELD: The court found that from September 4, 2006 until approximately February 22, 2007, the parties shared custody of the children. The respondent father's proportionate share of child support was 80% and the mother's was 20%. The father's share of the expenses were to be amortized over two years. The court ordered that the parties determine the appropriate amount to be paid by the father each month to cover s. 7 expenses.

column2: FIAT: The respondent applies for an interim order granting her sole custody of the parties' two children and child support retroactive to the date of separation being October 2005. The petitioner seeks joint custody with specified access. The petitioner acknowledges an obligation to pay child support but there is an issue with respect to his income and whether the interim order should be retroactive. The children are ages 3 and 2.HELD: 1) Section 3 of The Children's Law Act 1997 provides for a presumption of joint custody where parents of a child have cohabitated after the birth of the child. That is the situation here. There is nothing in the evidence to rebut that presumption on an interim basis. In making interim orders, the Court tries to disrupt the lives of the children as little as possible. The status quo in this case is represented by the verbal agreement between the parties entered into after their separation. That is the petitioner would have the children every third week during his week off from Saturday to Tuesday. This seems reasonable on an interim basis. This agreement did not address the fact that the petitioner shall be laid off for two months in the spring. It is reasonable that during this period his contact with the children should be increased. The petitioner has not seen the children for 10 months. He will have to be re-introduced to them. A phase in period is required. 2) The petitioner has worked for the same drilling company for about 6 years. His gross income in 2006 was $112,064. This is verified by his year to date income statement from his employer. The petitioner attests that $9,600 of his income is a 'living allowance' paid to cover expenses for his truck, fuel, vehicle maintenance and meals and should be deducted from his Line 150 income to arrive at his current income for child support purposes. This is a matter for the trial judge who will have the benefit of the 2006 tax return and notice of assessment and better evidence of the expenses and their purpose and make any retroactive adjustment deemed necessary. The petitioner's income for child support purposes is $112,064. 3) The claim for retroactive child support is a claim for child support payments which pre-date service of the notice of this application. The petitioner was served with the application in September 2006. The petitioner lived up to the parties' verbal agreement to pay child support of $1,200 per month starting October 2005. He unilaterally stopped paying child support in January 2006. He attests that his reason for doing so was because he was not having access to the children. The obligation to pay child support is not contingent on a payor's ability to see their children.  The respondent's income is substantially less then that of the petitioner's. The child support was necessary to meet the children's basis ongoing needs. The petitioner knew he had an obligation to provide child support and there is no evidence that a retroactive order would cause him undue hardship. There is evidence that a request for change in child support preceded the commencement of this application. A retroactive adjustment of child support to January 2006 is warranted.
column3: FIAT: The respondent applied for an interim order granting sole custody of the parties' two children and child support, including s.7(a) child care expenses retroactive to the date of separation, being October 2005. The petitioner, Evan Gavelin, requested joint custody with specified access. HELD: 1) Retroactive child support was granted. The court found that retroactive child care was warranted. 2) The petitioner knew he had an obligation to provide child support and there was no evidence a retroactive order would cause him undue hardship. 3) The parties' verbal agreement at the time of separation that Mr. Gavelins would have parenting time with the children every third weekend during his week off from Tuesday to Tuesday was not accepted. 4) The respondent had not received any income from the company prior to the separation. 5) The court ordered that retroactivity of child support be made retroactive. 6) The Court found that the parties had verbal agreement following their separation that the respondent would pay one-half of the child care costs retroactive the date the parties separated. The parties had discussed the issue of child care expenditures prior to March 2006. The respondent was to pay $185 per month directly to the child support provider. The order should be based on the petitioner's 2004 income.
column4: 1) The respondent, Nevada Pateman, applies for an interim order granting her sole custody of the parties’ two children and child support, including s. 7(a) child care expenses retroactive to the date of separation, being October, 2005. There shall be an order that Mr. Gavelin pay support for his children, Kayden Marie Gavelin, born February 28, 2003 and Nolan Evan Gavelin, born December 28, 2004 of $1,531 per month commencing February 1, 2007 and continuing on the first day of each and every month thereafter for so long as the children remain children within the meaning of The Family Maintenance Act or until further order of this Court. Mr. Gavelin knew he had an obligation to provide child support and there is no evidence a retroactive order would cause him undue hardship. I am satisfied in the circumstances that retroactive child support is warranted. A retroactive adjustment of child support to January 1, 2006 is warranted.

The petitioner, Evan Gavelin, requested joint custody with specified access. While he acknowledges an obligation to pay child support and there is an issue as to his income and whether the interim order should be made retroactive, there is no evidence a retroactive order would cause him undue hardship. A retroactive adjustment of child support to January 1, 2006 is warranted.  2) The parties' verbal agreement at the time of separation was that the petitioner would have the children during his week off from Saturday to Tuesday during which time he would be responsible for arranging the pickup and return of the children. Retroactive support should be based on the petitioner's 2004 income.

column12: FIAT: The respondent applies for an interim order granting her sole custody of the parties' two children and child support retroactive to the date of separation being October 2005. The petitioner seeks joint custody with specified access. The petitioner acknowledges an obligation to pay child support but there is an issue with respect to his income and whether the interim order should be retroactive. The children are ages 3 and 2.HELD: 1) Section 3 of The Children's Law Act 1997 provides for a presumption of joint custody where parents of a child have cohabitated after the birth of the child. That is the situation here. There is nothing in the evidence to rebut that presumption on an interim basis. In making interim orders, the Court tries to disrupt the lives of the children as little as possible. The status quo in this case is represented by the verbal agreement between the parties entered into after their separation. That is the petitioner would have the children every third week during his week off from Saturday to Tuesday. This seems reasonable on an interim basis. This agreement did not address the fact that the petitioner shall be laid off for two months in the spring. It is reasonable that during this period his contact with the children should be increased. The petitioner has not seen the children for 10 months. He will have to be re-introduced to them. A phase in period is required. 2) The petitioner has worked for the same drilling company for about 6 years. His gross income in 2006 was $112,064. This is verified by his year to date income statement from his employer. The petitioner attests that $9,600 of his income is a 'living allowance' paid to cover expenses for his truck, fuel, vehicle maintenance and meals and should be deducted from his Line 150 income to arrive at his current income for child support purposes. This is a matter for the trial judge who will have the benefit of the 2006 tax return and notice of assessment and better evidence of the expenses and their purpose and make any retroactive adjustment deemed necessary. The petitioner's income for child support purposes is $112,064. 3) The claim for retroactive child support is a claim for child support payments which pre-date service of the notice of this application. The petitioner was served with the application in September 2006. The petitioner lived up to the parties' verbal agreement to pay child support of $1,200 per month starting October 2005. He unilaterally stopped paying child support in January 2006. He attests that his reason for doing so was because he was not having access to the children. The obligation to pay child support is not contingent on a payor's ability to see their children.  The respondent's income is substantially less then that of the petitioner's. The child support was necessary to meet the children's basis ongoing needs. The petitioner knew he had an obligation to provide child support and there is no evidence that a retroactive order would cause him undue hardship. There is evidence that a request for change in child support preceded the commencement of this application. A retroactive adjustment of child support to January 2006 is warranted.

column2: Accused pleaded guilty at opening of trial to one count of distributing child pornography in the form of written works. The accused was active on a pedophile website and posted 11 stories describing sexual activity between men and infants and pre-teen girls. HELD: Accused received 15 months imprisonment followed by 3 years of probation with addition orders including providing DNA samples and being added to the Sex Offender Registry. The Court accepted that the internet has led to the accelerated proliferation of child pornography, making it an increasing social problem. The social harm of such material is borne almost exclusively by infants and children, the most defenceless members of society. For this reason, denunciation and deterrence are the dominant sentencing principles. The defence submitted that the writings do not actually harm children in their making and, therefore, should not be subject to the same denunciation as pornographic images. The Court rejected this argument because it cannot be assumed that the writings do not stimulate the demand for images and since not all pedophiles are voyeurs only some will act on their desires and anything that stimulates this desire places children at risk in the real world. Aggravating factors in this case were 1) the fact that the accused extolled pedophilia and wrote hard core child pornography and encouraged others to the same. 2) The accused was a high profile contributor to the web site and he remains unrepentant Ã» he does not believe there is anything wrong with writing these stories and only stopped because the law requires it. A conditional sentence would not represent sufficient denunciation or deterrence. Mitigating factors in this case included a lack of criminal record, the guilty plea and the fact that the accused is looking after his elderly mother.
column3: The defendant pled guilty at the opening of trial to distributing child pornography contrary to s. 163.1(3) of the Criminal Code. The defendant had been active on a pedophile website for a while and had written 11 stories. The court found that the defendant had no criminal record and was now serving a social purpose of looking after his ailing mother and ailing father. HELD: The defendant was sentenced to 15 months imprisonment to be followed by a term of probation of 3 years, as well as the additional orders made for his release. The Court found that a conditional sentence would not deter others who might be inclined to engage in the activity of distributing child porn. The sentence was appropriate for a young offender with a relatively high profile. The mitigating factors referred to by the defence were that the accused had no previous criminal record, had no prior criminal record or plea agreement, had been convicted of distributing the material, had a low profile and was not a person who would endanger the community if one were imposed. The sentencing guidelines were met. The accused was sentenced for possession of child pornography and was to spend 15 months in custody. The sentences were set out in the Criminal Law Review. The judge found that there was no evidence that the offences were committed by the defendant. The fact that the probation officer verified his short participation in the program and that he did not plead guilty, along with other material referred to in the Review, did not deter the offender. The probation officer found that he was not an appropriate candidate for programming. The Crown found that it was appropriate to make an order pursuant to s.(1) of s. 490.012(1) requiring the accused to comply with the Sex Offender Information Registration Act, 2004, for a period of 20 years, which is the mandatory time specified in s.(2) for a person convicted of distribution of childpornography. The order was made to allow the accused's submission of a 'haunting story' to be heard by others. The offence was committed against the accused and the accused was convicted of possession of the material. The offences were both serious and were of significant nature. The Criminal Code requires a high profile and a significant risk profile.

contributor to the website during the time he was active, and he remains
unrepentant, meaning he does not yet believe there is anything wrong with writing

and did plead guilty, albeit at the opening of trial, along with the other material I

imprisonment, to be followed by a term of probation of three years, as well as the
additional orders I am about to make. Canada: (1) Pursuant to s. 490.012 of the Criminal Code, it is ordered you be

The sentencing guidelines for the defendant were that a sentence of 12 months imprisonment would be appropriate. The defendant had no criminal record, had no previous convictions, was not an active member of the community and did not wish to be imprisoned. The sentence imposed on the defendant would not exceed 2 years. There was no evidence that he would endanger the community if a conditional sentence were imposed.

Aggravating factors in this case were 1) the fact that the accused extolled pedophilia and wrote hard core child pornography and encouraged others to the same. 2) The accused was a high profile contributor to the web site and he remains unrepentant Ã» he does not believe there is anything wrong with writing these stories and only stopped because the law requires it. A conditional sentence would not represent sufficient denunciation or deterrence. Mitigating factors in this case included a lack of criminal record, the guilty plea and the fact that the accused is looking after his elderly mother.
column18: The accused pled guilty at the opening of trial to distributing child pornography contrary to s. 163.1(3) of the Criminal Code. HELD: The accused was sentenced to 15 months imprisonment to be followed by a term of probation of 3 years. A conditional sentence would not be strong enough to deter others who might be inclined to engage in the activity of distributing child porn. The accused had no criminal record and was serving a social purpose. The fact that he disclosed his stories were largely fantasies was not mitigating factor that detracts from the effects such written pornography has, as set out above. The court found that the accused was more of a voyeur than actively sexual with girls and that denunciation and deterrence were the dominant principles of sentencing in this area.

column22: Accused pleaded guilty at opening of trial to one count of distributing child pornography in the form of written works. The accused was active on a pedophile website and posted 11 stories describing sexual activity between men and infants and pre-teen girls. HELD: Accused received 15 months imprisonment followed by 3 years of probation with addition orders including providing DNA samples and being added to the Sex Offender Registry. The Court accepted that the internet has led to the accelerated proliferation of child pornography, making it an increasing social problem. The social harm of such material is borne almost exclusively by infants and children, the most defenceless members of society. For this reason, denunciation and deterrence are the dominant sentencing principles. The defence submitted that the writings do not actually harm children in their making and, therefore, should not be subject to the same denunciation as pornographic images. The Court rejected this argument because it cannot be assumed that the writings do not stimulate the demand for images and since not all pedophiles are voyeurs only some will act on their desires and anything that stimulates this desire places children at risk in the real world. A conditional sentence would not represent sufficient denunciation or deterrence. Mitigating factors in this case included a lack of criminal record, the guilty plea and the fact that the accused is looking after his elderly mother.

column2: The respondent pled guilty to a charge of manslaughter arising out of fatal injuries she inflicted on her 7 month old daughter. The sentencing judge awarded the respondent 26 months credit for 13 months in pre-trial custody and then imposed a sentence of 2 years less 1 day to be followed by 2 years probation. The Crown seeks leave to appeal the sentence imposed as demonstrably unfit. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1) Taking into account the mitigating factors and in particular the respondent's post-sentence rehabilitative potential and the absence of evidence of prior acts of violence, a sentence slightly below the range as the one imposed in R. v. Bighead, 2003 SKCA 44 leads the Court to conclude a sentence of 6 years is appropriate, with 26 months credit for remand as imposed below.  2) The sentencing judge was directed to a very narrow range of authorities. In these circumstances this Court cannot find that the judge failed to give proper weight to the gravity of the offence and the degree of the respondent's responsibility. It would be helpful if a more detailed analysis along the lines suggested in R. v. Laberge (1995), 165 A.R. 375 had been given in order to enhance meaningful appellate review. However, this Court is not satisfied the judge failed to properly consider this factor. The Court is satisfied that the limited framework presented by counsel led the judge to err by failing to observe the need for parity in sentence and as a result, the sentence imposed was not similar to sentences imposed on other offenders for similar offences committed in similar circumstances.
column3: The Crown appealed a sentence of 26 months in pre-trial custody and 2 years probation imposed on the respondent for manslaughter. The Crown argued the sentencing judge erred in his assessment of the gravity of the offence and the respondent's moral culpability in it and failed to address the principles of denunciation and deterrence. HELD: The appeal was allowed on the basis of this latter ground. The sentencing judge failed to give proper weight to the gravity and the gravity the offence, the respondent’s remorse, her abusive background, her mental health problems, her social and economic situation and the fact that she had never properly bonded with the child. The court found that the respondent had a high level of mental health issues and had a history of substance abuse, which led her to commit these offences. The respondent”s past criminal record and her current situation all led her not to seek help when it was apparent the child was injured. The Court found that a sentence for manslaughter with a factor of four years less a day was appropriate given the respondent was a high risk to re-offend and her past criminal history did not warrant a sentence higher than that imposed.
column4: Disposition: Allowed On February 11, 2009, the sentencing judge awarded the respondent 26 months credit for 13 months in pre-trial custody and then imposed a sentence of two years less one day to be followed by two years probation. The Crown seeks leave to appeal the sentence imposed as demonstrably unfit. I am satisfied the appeal should be allowed on the basis of this latter ground. I am, however, satisfied this same limited framework presented by counsel led the judge to err by failing to observe the need for parity in sentencing and as a result, the sentence imposed was not similar to sentences imposed on other offenders for similar offences committed in similar circumstances. Taking into account the mitigating factors already identified, in particular the respondent\'s post-sentence rehabilitative potential and the absence of evidence of prior acts of violence, a sentence slightly below the range as the one imposed in Bighead leads me to conclude a sentence of six years is appropriate, with 26 months credit for remand as imposed below. Leave to appeal is granted and the appeal is allowed.

column8: The Crown appealed a sentence of 26 months in pre-trial custody and 2 years probation imposed for the manslaughter of a seven-month-old child. The sentencing judge awarded the respondent 26 months credit for 13 months in custody and then imposed a sentence for 2 years less 1 day to be followed by 2 years of probation. The Crown sought leave to appeal the sentence imposed as demonstrably unfit. HELD: The appeal was allowed on the basis of the following grounds: 1) the sentencing judge erred in his assessment of the gravity of the offence and the respondent's moral culpability in it and failed to address s. 718.01 of the Code; 2) the judge failed to give adequate weight to both the seriousness of the offences and the degree of the respondent’s responsibility; and 3) the court found that the respondent had a history of mental health problems, including depression, alcohol and drug use, which resulted in a severe and persistent vegetative state with a severely reduced lifespan; and 4) the respondent was found to have had a dysfunctional upbringing and mental disorder. The court found the respondent did not have a mental disorder or a mental illness which would have resulted in the death of the child; her previous criminal record was not of character which interfered with her ability to appreciate her surroundings, control her actions or understand the consequences of them. The respondent had been diagnosed with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) and had a long history of domestic abuse, domestic abuse and sexual assault. The Court found that post-traumatic stress disorder was not a factor in the sentence as it was not aggravating to the respondent. The sentence imposed was based on a very narrow range of authorities, which included a case identifying the appropriate range, a case with dissimilar charge and a case from another jurisdiction with sentence at the low end of the range because of the personal circumstances of the accused. The judge was alive to the seriousness and the extent of her responsibility.

column13: The Crown appealed a sentence of 26 months in pre-trial custody and 2 years probation imposed for the manslaughter of a seven-month-old child. The sentencing judge awarded the respondent 26 months credit for 13 months in custody and then imposed a 2 year less 1 day sentence followed by two years probation. The Crown sought leave to appeal the sentence imposed as demonstrably unfit. HELD: The appeal should be allowed on the basis of this latter ground.  1)The essential facts are not in dispute. The respondent's acknowledgment of responsibility, her expressions of remorse, her abusive background which may have caused symptoms of PTSD, and her socioeconomic situation all contribute to the offence. 2)The sentencing judge failed to give proper weight to the gravity of the offence and the respondent's moral culpability in it and failed to properly consider this factor. 3)The respondent's dysfunctional upbringing or dysfunctional life was put forth by the Crown as an aggravating factor. The judge asked Crown counsel whether it could in fact be a mitigating factor. Counsel responded whether it was mitigating factor or not. 4)The court found the respondent had a high risk to re-offend and had compelling personal circumstances. 5)The sentence imposed did not adequately address the principles of denunciation and general deterrence. The court found that the respondent was in a position of trust and authority and did not seek immediate help when it was apparent the child was injured. 6)The Court found that a reasonable starting point for a custodial sentence for unlawful act manslaughter is seven years. The sentence imposed was based on the factors set out in R. v. Hathway. The Court also found that sentencing guidelines for adults who kill children do not require a detailed analysis of the factors considered in this case.

The Court noted that she had never properly bonded with the child. She continued to use drugs and alcohol after the birth of her child. 6) The judge did not refer to decisions of this Court on the starting point of a manslaughter sentence and specifically the issue of criminal negligence causing death.

column2: The judge declared the defendants could pay legal fees from third party loans without offending two prior execution orders that prevented them from disposing of any property. The declaration was explicitly made on the assumption that the loans would not be secured against the defendants' existing assets. Later, the defendants' counsel wrote to the court essentially indicating he could not confirm the loans would not be secured against any assets. The court issued this supplemental decision. In the absence of any evidence the loans will not be secured against assets already subject to the execution order, or will not otherwise reduce those assets, the order and declaration sought can no longer be granted.
column3: The defendants sought an order confirming their ability to pay certain amounts for billed and unbilled time without the defendants' consent. The defendants sought the order violating the terms of two execution orders previously issued February 18, 2010, as Hfx No. 190408 against the defendants judgment debtors to the plaintiff, who were successful litigants in this action. HELD: The Court was unable to grant the proposed order. The Court could only rely upon the affidavit evidence of Ms. Cochrane relating to the third party loans. The affidavit evidence did not reveal where the loans came from or if they will reduce the exigencies of the defendants, available for execution.
column4: [1] By a motion dated December 16, 2010, the defendants sought an order confirming their ability to pay certain amounts for billed and unbilled time of their respective legal counsel, as well as retainers with respect to ongoing litigation, without such payments violating the terms of two execution orders previously issued February 18, 2010, as Hfx No. 190408 against the defendant judgment debtors to the plaintiff herein, who were successful litigants in this action. I am therefore unable to grant the proposed order which accompanied the notice in this matter.

column19: [1] By a motion dated December 16, 2010, the defendants sought an order confirming their ability to pay certain amounts for billed and unbilled time of their respective legal counsel, as well as retainers with respect to ongoing litigation, without such payments violating the terms of two execution orders previously issued February 18, 2010, as Hfx No. 190408 against the defendant judgment debtors to the plaintiff herein, who were successful litigants in this action. I am therefore unable to grant the proposed order which accompanied the notice in this matter.
column22: The judge declared the defendants could pay legal fees from third party loans without offending two prior execution orders that prevented them from disposing of any property. The declaration was explicitly made on the assumption that the loans would not be secured against the defendants' existing assets. Later, the defendants' counsel wrote to the court essentially indicating he could not confirm the loans would not be secured against any assets. The court issued this supplemental decision. In the absence of any evidence the loans will not be secured against assets already subject to the execution order, or will not otherwise reduce those assets, the order and declaration sought can no longer be granted.

column2: Family – Child Support – Arrears – Appeal The appellant appealed from the decision of a Queen’s Bench judge ordering him to pay retroactive child support to the respondent in the amount of $21,645. The order indicated that the period in question would include support from January 2009 to August 2012 (see: 2014 SKQB 334). An original support order was issued by consent in 2006. It required that the appellant pay the respondent $1,220 per month in child support and that the parties would exchange their financial information yearly in order to adjust the amount of child support payable. In 2008, the appellant applied to vary the order because he had lost his position and his income was reduced to $1,500 per month. In his affidavit, he swore that his annual income would be $18,000. The application was allowed and the amount of support reduced to $769 per month based upon the judge setting the appellant’s income at $55,000 and directing him to provide his financial information to the respondent each year. One month later in 2009, the appellant regained his former employment position and began earning as much as he had in 2008 but he continued to pay $769 per month without informing the respondent of the change in his circumstances. In February 2011, the respondent served a notice to disclose. The parties met and made an oral agreement that the appellant would pay $950 per month based upon the appellant’s claim that he was still financially strapped and the respondent acquiesced because she was unwilling to engage in further court battles with him. The appellant’s lawyer provided the respondent’s lawyer with financial information that showed that the former was earning a substantially higher income. The respondent also indicated to the appellant that she would forgo about $7,200 in arrears. The terms of the agreement were submitted to the court, without the financial information or the respondent’s forbearance to sue, and a variation order was issued based upon them. In July 2012, the respondent applied to vary the 2008 order and the 2011 variation order claiming arrears from January 2009. Eventually the issue of retroactive child support went to trial. The trial judge found that the appellant had not given the respondent financial information as was required and his failure to inform her of the material change in his circumstances in 2009 constituted blameworthy conduct. The appellant’s income for the years 2009 through 2012 was assessed by the court and the amount of arrears established. The appellant argued that: 1) the trial judge did not have the jurisdiction to vary the 2011 variation order. He maintained that the 2011 order was final and could not be varied on an interim basis; 2) it was necessary to find a material change in circumstances before it could be varied; 3) the respondent had been advised of the change in circumstances; and 4) the trial judge had erred in failing to find unreasonable delay on the part of the respondent.  HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The court held with respect to each issue that: 1) a court can vary an interim or a final order on an interim basis for child support under the authority of ss. 15 and 17 of the Divorce Act. Although it might be necessary in some cases to determine whether an order is final or interim, it was not necessary to do so here because the nature of the terms of the orders in question and the circumstances surrounding the granting of the 2011 variation order. The trial judge had not erred in concluding that he had authority to vary it and to order the appellant to pay arrears before the agreement and compelling him to pay the Guideline amount for the period following it; 2) the terms of the 2011 order left it to a future court to finalize the amount of child support based upon the appellant’s income. Therefore the court retained the power to vary or rescind the order without searching for a change in circumstances; 3) the trial judge’s findings of fact on this point were supported by the evidence; and 4) the trial judge found that the respondent had not received disclosure and thus there had been no unreasonable delay.
column3: The parties agreed to vary the 2011 Variation Order in the amount of $21,645 and costs in the amounts of $1,500. The parties had agreed to fix the 2011 order by varying it in 2012. The respondent applied to the Court of Queen's Bench in May 2011 to vary it by varying the 2011 Order. The court found that the subsequent orders were all variations of the 2006 Consent Child Support Order and each order was made subject to further variation from the court. The Court of Appeal held that the Court could not overturn a decision of a different court dealing with the same lis. Appeal dismissed. The issue on appeal was whether the Court had the jurisdiction to vary a final order on an interim basis for child support. The evidence on appeal suggested that the court drew a clear distinction between interim orders, which can be varied on an ongoing basis as a matter of jurisdiction, and final orders. The courts draw a clear difference between interim and final order. In the case of the respondent, the Court found that he had not been advised of changes to his circumstances. The appellant argued that the respondent erred by misapprehending the facts and failing to find unreasonable delay. The applicant argued that in the area of family support orders, the courts draw the clear distinction from interim orders which can only be varied as a subject matter and final Orders. The appeal court held that in this case the Court was entitled to make a determination on the basis of affidavit evidence. The decision of the Court in May 2012 was also appealed. Appeal denied. The issues on appeal are whether the court has the jurisdiction or not to vary this order. The trial judge drew a distinction between the interim and a final orders and the Court's decision in the case in question was not binding. The order in question is not binding on the respondent.
column4: Appeal dismissed [1] This is an appeal from the decision of Turcotte J. on October 16, 2014, ordering Daniel Prescesky to pay retroactive child support to his former wife, Mandy Lantz, in the amount of $21,645 and costs in the amount of $1,500 (Prescesky v Prescesky, 2014 SKQB 334 (CanLII), 456 Sask R 306 [Prescesky]). Analysis [28] Mr. Prescesky submits that Turcotte J. erred: (i) by varying the 2011 Variation Order, which he submits was a final order issued by consent of the parties in accordance with their prior agreement; (ii) by varying the 2011 Variation Order without first finding a material change in circumstances; (iii) by misapprehending the facts when he found Mr. Prescesky did not advise Ms. Lantz of changes to his circumstances; and (iv) by misapprehending the facts by failing to find unreasonable delay. (a) Did Turcotte J. have the jurisdiction to vary the 2011 Variation Order? (b) Was it necessary to find a material change in circumstances before the 2011 Variation Order could be varied? A. Did Turcotte J. have the jurisdiction to vary the 2011 Variation Order? [35] Second, he argues that in the area of family support orders, the courts draw a clear distinction between interim orders, which can be varied on an interim basis as a matter of jurisdiction, and final orders. Whether the Court can vary an interim or a final order on an interim basis for child support is governed not by common law principles, but by the Divorce Act, RSC 1985, c 3 (2d Supp). [53] I will now turn to consider the nature of the orders in question and the authority that can be invoked to sustain their variation. [72] In short, I conclude that Turcotte J. did not err by concluding he had the authority to vary the 2011 Variation Order and to order Mr. Prescesky to pay arrears arsing before it and compelling him to pay the Guidelines amount for the period following it. B. Was it necessary to find a material change in circumstances before the 2011 Variation Order could be varied? By the terms of the 2011 Variation Order, the parties left to a future court the finalization of the amount of child support based on Mr. Prescesky’s income.  Faced with this state of affairs and these words, the Court of Queen’s Bench retained the power to vary or rescind the order without searching for a change in circumstances. [77] Turcotte J. also found that “there was no unreasonable delay on Mandy’s part in seeking a retroactive review of Daniel’s child support obligation” (para. 48). [78] The appeal is dismissed.
