column2: FIAT. The petitioner sought interim custody of his son. The respondent contested that the petition for divorce was a nullity and Saskatchewan courts did not have jurisdiction to hear the divorce proceedings and lacked jurisdiction or ought to decline to exercise jurisdiction under the Children's Law Act. Both parties made serious allegations against the other and there was substantial conflict in the affidavit evidence. HELD: An order for interim custody was granted on the condition the petitioner continued to reside with his parents in Regina and that the child not be removed from Regina without further court order. 1)The respondent did not acquiesce to the child's residing in Saskatchewan such that it may be said he was habitually resident here for the purposes of the Children's Law Act.  2)The seven factors listed in s15(1)(b) are conjunctive and the petitioner must satisfy them all. With respect to (iii) a petition for divorce was commenced in July 1996. 3)The child had a real and substantial connection with Saskatchewan and it was appropriate to exercise jurisdiction pursuant to s15(1)(b). Jurisdiction existed pursuant to s15(3) as the child had a closer connection to Saskatchewan then to Alberta. Both sets of grandparents and other family members on both sides reside in Saskatchewan. The child had no connection of consequence to the Province of Alberta.
column3: FIAT. The petitioner sought interim custody of his son. The mother had only been resident in Saskatchewan since April 1996. Section of the Divorce Act requires either spouse to have been ordinarily resident in the province for at least 1 year immediately preceding the commencement of the proceeding. HELD: Interim custody was granted to the mother. 1)The child had a real and substantial connection to Saskatchewan. The court lacked jurisdiction to exercise jurisdiction under the Children's Law Act. 2)The court had jurisdiction pursuant to ss15 and 1. The child had no connection to Alberta. The Court had jurisdiction to exist pursuant to s15(1)(b).  3)The Court had the jurisdiction to determine the issue of interim custody. shall not be removed from the city of Regina without further
order of this court.

column2: The defendant applied to have evidence found during a search of his premises excluded on the basis that the search warrant was invalid. Application dismissed; there was sufficient evidence to constitute reasonable and probable grounds for the issuance of the warrant. Overall the nature of the evidence was compelling with four separate and independent sources all confirming either that the defendant was selling drugs or that drugs were being sold at his residence; although individually none of the sources was of known or proven reliability, collectively they reinforced and confirmed each other; and the police conducted surveillance which corroborated the information provided by the sources.
column3: The defendant applied for the exclusion of evidence found following a search conducted at his residence pursuant to a warrant issued by fax from the Justice of the Peace Centre in Dartmouth, N.S. The information to obtain the warrant did not meet the test in R. v. Debot, 1989 CanLII 13 (SCC), [1989] 2 S.C.R. 1140, and therefore the warrant should not have been issued. The defendant argued that the information obtained by the information did not satisfy the test and therefore that the warrant was therefore warrantless, breached his Charter s. right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure, and that evidence obtained by it should be excluded under s. 24(2) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. HELD: The evidence found at the nature of the evidence was compelling. The evidence confirmed that the defendant was selling drugs or that drugs were being sold or used at his apartment, or both, and there was evidence on which the Justice could conclude that this was continuing activity and that it was on-going at the date of the warrant application. The court found that there was sufficient reliable evidence to constitute the reasonable and probable grounds for the application for exclusion of the information. The Court found that the evidence met the test of reasonable and reasonable grounds and that the search was therefore justified. The application was granted for the inclusion of evidence as a whole and the evidence on the basis of the credibility of the four sources was considered sufficient to warrant the exclusion. The applicant did not seek a warrant on the grounds of this information alone, but conducted surveillance, which corroborated the information provided by their sources. The officer did not suggest that the traffic could have been going to the other basement apartment. The police did not search the premises, conducted surveillance and found that no one was injured. The search was concluded that the drug was being sold and that there were no signs of activity or that the person was making any purchase. The affidavit evidence was not found to support the application.
column4: [1] The defendant has made an application for the exclusion of evidence found following a search conducted at his residence pursuant to a warrant issued by fax from the Justice of the Peace Centre in Dartmouth, N.S. [9] Looking first at the nature of the evidence, over all I find that it was compelling. So four apparently separate and independent sources over the month and a half prior to the warrant application all confirmed, with varying amounts of detail, either that the defendant was selling drugs or that drugs were being sold or used at his apartment, or both. [11] Finally the police did not seek a warrant on the basis of this information alone, but conducted surveillance, which corroborated the information provided by their sources. Conclusion [12] I find that there was sufficient reliable evidence to constitute the reasonable and probable grounds for issuance of this warrant.

HELD: The application was granted. 1)There was sufficient reliable evidence to constitute the reasonable and probable grounds for issuance of the warrant. 2)The information obtained by the police did not meet the test in R. v. There was evidence on which the justice of the peace could conclude that this was continuing activity and that it was on-going at the date of the application. 4)The court found that there was sufficient evidence to justify a warrantless search. 5)The officer did not seek a warrant on the basis of this information alone, but conducted surveillance, which corroborated the information provided by their sources. 6)The nature of the evidence, over all, was compelling.
column9: [1] The defendant has made an application for the exclusion of evidence found following a search conducted at his residence pursuant to a warrant issued by fax from the Justice of the Peace Centre in Dartmouth, N.S. [9] Looking first at the nature of the evidence, over all I find that it was compelling. So four apparently separate and independent sources over the month and a half prior to the warrant application all confirmed, with varying amounts of detail, either that the defendant was selling drugs or that drugs were being sold or used at his apartment, or both. [11] Finally the police did not seek a warrant on the basis of this information alone, but conducted surveillance, which corroborated the information provided by their sources. Conclusion [12] I find that there was sufficient reliable evidence to constitute the reasonable and probable grounds for issuance of this warrant.

column2: An appeal of an award of $1,245. The tenant's father contacted him about the hearing while he was out of the country. The father appeared at the hearing and objected to service of the hearing notice. HELD: The appeal was allowed. The award was set aside and a new hearing was ordered. The Deputy Rentalsman committed an error in law by denying 10 days notice. The Landlord and Tenant Act s.60(5.1) empowers the Rentalsman to validate a defective service provided the notice came to the attention of the person to be served. The day the notice was received and the day of the hearing must be excluded in calculating the notice period (Interpretation Act s.24(4)). In this case the tenant received only 8 days notice. No costs.

column2: This was an application for an order extending the time to apply for leave to appeal and for leave to appeal. Sections 13 and 14 of the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act govern the appeal. The applicant took no steps to appeal within the 21 day period due to an inadvertence of its lawyer. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The plain and ordinary meaning of the words of s. 14(2) of the Act is that only the court appealed from has power to extend the time within which leave must be sought. Section 14(2) of the Act prevails over s. 9(6) of The Court of Appeal Act, 2000.
column3: This was an application for an order extending the time to apply for leave to appeal and for leave-to- appeal. Sections 13 and 14 of the Companies Creditors Arrangement Act govern the proposed appeal. The applicant took no steps to appeal within the twenty-one day period due to an inadvertence of its lawyer. Although the applicant cannot bring itself within s.14(2), it argues that this court nevertheless has the power to extend the time either under s13 of the Creditor Arrangment Act which empowers the appeal court to grant leave to make an appeal or under s9(6) of the Court of Appeal Act, 2000, S.S. 2000, C-42.1, which emulates the Court's power under s.9(7) of The Court of Appeals Act, 2001, S9(8) of S.9 and C-44.1. Both applications were dismissed.

column2: All parties agree that this case turns on the interpretation of article XIV, subsection 14.01 of the joint venture agreement. They also agree that the subsection is a right of first refusal clause. It is clear that the subject matter of the clause is a 'Participating Interest in the Program Land or a Project Area'. HELD: Appeal dismissed orally. The appellant relies on the words in parenthesis 'the Parties being absolutely prohibited from selling, assigning, transferring, conveying or otherwise disposing of any interest other than all of part of its Participating Interest' to establish its case that the voting agreement contravenes the terms of the joint venture agreement. However, subsection 14.01, with the words in parenthesis deleted, creates a complete right of first refusal. In our view, the words in parenthesis, rather than being intended to create substantial new contractual obligations, were intended, as is buttressed by the parenthetical structure, merely to recall to the parties their dedication of assets to the joint venture, and their inability to dispose of them qua separate assets. Thus, the phrase in parenthesis is mere surplusage in that it does not add or subtract substantively to subsection 14.01 or the joint venture agreement as a whole. Accordingly, the voting agreement is not caught by subsection 14.01.

The parties also sought to use the voting agreement to establish their case that the voting agreements contravened the terms of the joint venture. The voting agreement secured follow-up steps under Kensington's commitment which would eventually be implemented in a different direction. The respondents Cameco and UEM preferred the Kensington plan and were prepared to commit themselves to it. They took the position that they had exercised their right to vote by entering into the voting agreement, rather than having sold their vote by so doing. The vote was counted as part of the transaction. The chambers judge dismissed the appeal with costs to be taxed.

The words in parenthesis, rather than being intended to create substantial new contractual obligations, were intended, as is buttressed by the parenthetical structure, merely to recall to the parties their dedication of assets to the joint venture, and their inability to dispose of them qua non negotiable.
column19: Disposition: Dismissed (orally) Thus, the phrase in parenthesis is mere surplusage in that it does not add or subtract substantively to subsection 14.01 or the joint venture agreement as a whole. [7] The appeal is dismissed with costs to be taxed.
column22: All parties agree that this case turns on the interpretation of article XIV, subsection 14.01 of the joint venture agreement. They also agree that the subsection is a right of first refusal clause. It is clear that the subject matter of the clause is a 'Participating Interest in the Program Land or a Project Area'. HELD: Appeal dismissed orally. The appellant relies on the words in parenthesis 'the Parties being absolutely prohibited from selling, assigning, transferring, conveying or otherwise disposing of any interest other than all of part of its Participating Interest' to establish its case that the voting agreement contravenes the terms of the joint venture agreement. However, subsection 14.01, with the words in parenthesis deleted, creates a complete right of first refusal. In our view, the words in parenthesis, rather than being intended to create substantial new contractual obligations, were intended, as is buttressed by the parenthetical structure, merely to recall to the parties their dedication of assets to the joint venture, and their inability to dispose of them qua separate assets. Thus, the phrase in parenthesis is mere surplusage in that it does not add or subtract substantively to subsection 14.01 or the joint venture agreement as a whole. Accordingly, the voting agreement is not caught by subsection 14.01.

column2: The action, originally filed in 2000, concerned allegations of breach of - fiduciary duty, trust, industry regulations/standards, contract; and claims of negligence and malpractice. These claims related to the actions of an investor formerly employed by the defendant. The matter had languished at a slow pace for many years. The evidence showed the plaintiffs had taken three years to reply to a demand for particulars. There was also delay when the defendant requested a change in the plaintiff's counsel (because of a conflict of interest). The defendant applied to dismiss the plaintiffs' action, claiming want of prosecution under the Rule 28.13 of the old Civil Procedure Rules (1972), and asserting it has suffered significant prejudice as a result of the delay such that it will be impossible to properly defend the claim. Application dismissed. While there has been inordinate delay (eight-and-a-half-years) attributable to the plaintiffs, the defendant is also responsible for some of the delay (another two-and-a-half-years). While the plaintiff's delay could be considered inexcusable if viewed in isolation, the defendant's contribution to the delay is not irrelevant. There were actions on the part of the defendant that could be interpreted as acquiescing to the delay. After considering the case law concerning the circumstances in which a presumption of prejudice will arise as a result of the passage of time, the court found no presumption of prejudice here. On the facts, there is not a sufficient causal connection between the delay/blameworthy conduct and the prejudice. There is a significant documentary record of the transactions. The defendant has been in contact with its former employee and could have taken the opportunity to discover him sooner. The defendant's failure to act to secure the evidence available to them at time mitigates the effects of the passage of time. While there is a possibility of some prejudice should the matter proceed, the defendant has not established it will suffer serious prejudice. Even if there was serious prejudice, the balance of convenience weighs in favour of the plaintiffs given that dismissing the action would leave them with no other recourse.
column3: The plaintiffs sought to dismiss a proceeding for want of prosecution pursuant to Rule 28.13 of the Civil Procedure Rules. The application was made in accordance with Rule 28(13) because it was a matter of fact and not a political action. The plaintiffs had received some particulars in connection with a claim for damages against the defendant. The defendant had retained a solicitor of record and had advised the plaintiffs that they intended to move the matter forward. The plaintiff had not received the particulars until May 2006. The defendants had retained another solicitor of the record in Nova Scotia. The solicitor of general had retired in December 1997. The delay was caused by the death of the plaintiff's solicitor and the difficulty in locating competent counsel to advance the claim. The lawyer who represented the plaintiffs at the time of the action was not retained. Even allowing for two-and-a-half years of delay, this means the delay of attributable to the plaintiffs was of some eight years, which is inordinate.
column4: [1] This is an application to dismiss a proceeding for want of prosecution pursuant to Rule 28.13 of the Civil Procedure Rules (1972). Issue [14] RBC maintains that the Statement of Claim should be dismissed for want of prosecution, asserting that it has suffered significant prejudice due to delay, which will make it impossible to properly defend the claim should it proceed to trial. Even allowing for two-and-a-half years of delay attributable to RBC, this means the delay of attributable to the Plaintiffs was of some eight-and-a-half years, which I am satisfied is inordinate. They submit that RBC, as defendant, was responsible for a considerable period of delay, and that RBC acquiesced to a slow tempo of litigation. First, RBC was in contact with Mr. O\'Neill as early as October, 2000, and could have compelled him to attend discovery, but did not do so. In the circumstances, even if there is a possibility of some prejudice, I do not believe that the defendant has established that the delay caused it serious prejudice (my emphasis). While there is certainly a significant amount of delay attributable to the Plaintiffs, RBC was also responsible for some delay. [74] On balance, in view of the drastic nature of the dismissal remedy and the divided responsibility for the cumulative delay, I believe that the balance weighs in favour of preserving the proceeding. [76] Accordingly, the application is dismissed.

column8: The plaintiffs sought to dismiss a proceeding for want of prosecution pursuant to Rule 28.13 of the Civil Procedure Rules (1972). The application was made to dismiss an application for wantof prosecution under the heading of inexcusable delay. The Court found that the defendant was responsible for a considerable period of delay and that it acquiesced to a slow tempo of litigation. The delay was caused by the death of the plaintiff's solicitor and the difficulty in locating competent counsel to advance the claim after his death. The defendant had retained a solicitor of record who was no longer employed by the plaintiffs. The solicitor had declined to continue with the claim while another lawyer pursued an action resulting from a boating accident in which he was injured. The plaintiffs filed an Originating Notice and Statement of Claim in 2000. The action was dismissed in 2008. The application to dismiss the action was granted in 2009. The court found that even allowing for two-and-a-half years of delay, this means the delay of attributable to the plaintiffs was of some eight years, which is inordinate.

column13: The plaintiffs sought to dismiss a proceeding for want of prosecution pursuant to Rule 28.13 of the Civil Procedure Rules (1972). The application was made in accordance with the 1972 Rules because it was filed before December 31, 2008. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant was responsible for a considerable period of delay and that RBC acquiesced to a slow tempo of litigation. HELD: The application to dismiss the proceeding was dismissed. The Court found that the delay was caused by the defendant's failure to file its list of documents and its acquiescence to the slow pace of litigation, and that, in part, caused the delay. The delay was entirely due to the negligence of the defendant solicitor and the plaintiff himself was blameless. Even allowing for two-and-a-half years of delay, this means the delay of attributable to the plaintiffs was of some eight years.

column2: motion dismissed. There are factors that suggest there is a presumption in favor of proceeding by way of an application (Rule 6.02(3)). The respondent failed to show that, on balance, an action is the preferable route. While not all of the witnesses will be ascertained quickly, the important ones can be, which is all that Rule 6.03(5)(a) requires. The hearing should be predictable in scope and length and ready to be heard within months. The issues are straightforward. The only thing that would cause delay is the intended counterclaim.
column3: Civil Procedure Applications versus Actions Motions to Convert Nova Scotia Civil Procedure Rule 6. The applicants hold some $2.5 million in debentures issued by the Respondent, Medusa Medical Technologies Inc. The debenture have matured and Medusa has failed to pay the principal and interest amounts owing. The Respondent has commenced a separate action against the Respondant, Boone and Bough, alleging breach of contract and resulting economic losses. The applicant seeks to convert the debentured into an action. The application is to convert a portion of the debenture issued by Medusa into an enforcement action. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The Court found that the Respondents' application was not appropriate. 2)The Respondent's application was more complicated then might initially appear. The Court found the Respondants' application to convert was more complex than the original application. 3)The respondents failed to meet their burden of proving the proposition on a balance of probabilities.
column4: Result: Dismissed the Motion of Medusa to convert as it had failed to satisfy the Court, on a balance of probabilities, that an application was not appropriate. The motion of Medusa is therefore dismissed.

column8: Civil Procedure Applications versus Actions Motions to Convert Nova Scotia Civil Procedure Rule 6. The applicants hold some $2.5 million dollars worth of debentures issued by the Respondent, Medusa Medical Technologies Inc. The debentureures have matured and Medusa has failed to pay the principal and interest amounts owing. The Respondent and Bough are taking steps to secure payment of their debenture by means of an application to this Court. The application to convert is an attempt at enforcement in violation or in breach of clauses 2.2.2 and 3.1 of the Debenture Agreements. Medusa is seeking repayment of the debentured debt. The applicant seeks to convert as it failed to satisfy the Court, on a balance of probabilities, that an application was not appropriate. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1) The Court found that the application should be allowed to continue because converting it to an action will protract proceedings indefinitely, denying the parties their right to timely determination on the question of repayment. 2) There are other circumstances to be considered by the Court in motion such as the following: the relative costs and delay associated with the two different modes of proceeding; the application to determine liability for and enforceability of their Debentures; the issue of damages or economic losses allegedly suffered by Medusa as a result of the enforcement application; the appointment of a receiver pursuant to the Third Schedule of the 'Companies Act' by the applicant; and the fact that Medusa had failed to meet its burden of proving such a proposition on a balanced of probabilities. 3) The court found that a motion to convert could not be taken against the applicant as it would be a waste of time and money. The Court dismissed the application.
column9: Result: Dismissed the Motion of Medusa to convert as it had failed to satisfy the Court, on a balance of probabilities, that an application was not appropriate. The motion of Medusa is therefore dismissed.

column2: The court concluded that the respondent was not a credible, trustworthy, or reliable witness for many reasons. The petitioner, on the other hand, was found to be a truthful and reliable witness. The court was also impressed with the petitioner’s witnesses because they were close family members, long-time friends, and her live-in partner. By contrast, the respondent’s witnesses were friends seen from time to time, neighbours, and his mother. The court found the respondent’s mother to be evasive and guarded at times. To determine custody the court reviewed the factors set out in s. 8 of The Children’s Law Act, 1997. The petitioner was found to be the primary parent of the child since his birth. The court was left with a degree of uncertainty as to the day-to-day activities of the child when he was with the respondent. The quality of the child’s relationship with the petitioner was found to substantially exceed that of the respondent’s relationship with the child. The court accepted that the child said disturbing things upon his return to the petitioner from the respondent. The child’s need for a stable, reassuring, and positive home were found to be met in the petitioner’s home. The court indicated that decreasing the respondent’s time with the child may ameliorate the adverse effect on the child’s emotional needs. The child was also found to be afforded more social fulfillment in the petitioner’s care. The petitioner also had more constructive plans for the child’s future. The respondent’s negativity towards the petitioner was found to negatively impact his ability to parent. The court concluded that it was in the child’s best interests to primarily reside with the petitioner. The petitioner was granted sole custody of the child so as to minimize further conflict between the parties. The respondent was given unsupervised access every other weekend. The court added $5,000 to the petitioner’s line 150 income for the personal component of her vehicle expense deduction. After determining the respondent’s income the court found that the s. 3 Guideline child support due by the respondent to the petitioner was $676 per month and that he should be responsible for 37 percent of the s. 7 expenses. The petitioner did not request child support but instead asked the court to consider it in the distribution of property. The respondent discharged the onus of establishing a common-law relationship of two or more years. The respondent’s pension value available for division was found to be $11,663.97.  The court did not find an extraordinary circumstance to warrant an unequal division of the family home. The value of the home was $360,000. The court used the date of application to determine the amount owing on the home. The petitioner also had rental properties and was given an exemption of $90,641.43 for those properties. column3: HELD: The Court ordered interim shared custody of the parties. The parties had been together for four years. The petitioner had previously filed an Answer and Counter-Petition in 2012 contesting the respondent’s claims for sole custody, specified and supervised parenting time, and costs. The respondent had previously been granted interim shared parenting time. The Court found that the parties had not spoken since the parties separated. The court ordered the parties to proceed to an expedited pre-trial conference. The judge ordered the parents to have Z. on a shared week-on-week basis. The mother had moved out of the home and was now living with the petitioner. The father had been receiving Worker’S Compensation benefits and top-up from SaskTel. The wife had moved in with the husband. The husband had been living with his mother for several months. The two parties had reconciled in December 2012. The child had been in the mother’ s house for a few days. The relationship had been going on for some time. HELD: 1)The Court found the parties were not in a relationship. The children had been separated for four months. 2)The parties had a provisional agreement that the child would be in the interim care of the mother. The parents would have access to the mother when the trial could be held. 3)The court found that there was no evidence that the father had physically harmed the child. The evidence did not support the petitioner’d claim. The fact that the mother had physically restrained the child from the father was not sufficient evidence to justify the claim. 4)The evidence did support the parties’ contention that the respondent had physically assaulted the child and that the petitioner had been unable to contact the father. The agreement was not binding on the parties as the child was not a party animal. The only evidence that could be found was that the husband had physically abused the child for several days prior to the birth of the child, and that he had physically threatened the petitioner and her mother.
column4: I will now go through the factors set out in s. 8 of the Act. I find that despite what Mr. S. states, she was the primary parent of Z. since birth and continues to be so. Indeed I learned more (although not much) from his mother’s evidence as to the day-to-day activities. I am left with a degree of uncertainty. I accept that the child expresses these words. The child is in need of a stable, reassuring and positive home. I find that it is best provided in the mother’s home. I am concerned that Z.’s emotional needs have been adversely affected by the conduct of Mr. S. A lessening of Mr. S.’s time with Z. may ameliorate this. [145] Accordingly I am persuaded that Z. is afforded far more social fulfillment when in his mother’s care. I find that this adversely reflects upon Mr. S.’s ability to parent. [165] Therefore after carefully considering all of the above, I am of the view the following orders are in the child’s best interests, and I so order: (a) The petitioner, M.D.J., shall have sole custody of the child Z., born in June 2010, with his primary residence to be with the said petitioner. (b) The respondent, C.W.S., shall have alternate weekend access with the said child from Friday at 6:00 p.m. to Sunday at 6:00 p.m. to be extended to Monday at 6:00 p.m. in the event Monday is a school holiday. Therefore I accept the respondent’s argument and will add back into her income $5,000, which I consider to be fair. [170] I am satisfied that Z.’s s. 7 expenses for health, dental, activities and pre-school are about $5,061.35 per year (see P-28, tab 19 in P-8). I do not find the evidence supports an “extraordinary circumstance” as per s. 22(1)(a) of The Family Property Act (see Phillips v Phillips, 2010 SKCA 117 (CanLII), 362 Sask R 124). She was concerned that the father was holding the child from her and that she needed to end the relationship. She telephoned the respondent the next morning principally to try and get the child back. column2: HELD: The application for leave to appeal was dismissed. The court found that a term permitting an appeal from an arbitrator’s decision on an error of law did not fall into the category of the obvious and was not the same as an implied term, such as that of good workmanship in contracts for repair. The contractual language used by the parties was clear that they intended to resolve disputes by final and binding arbitration. Even if it had found that the parties had not contracted out of s. 45(2) of the Act, the application for leave would have been dismissed because the proposed grounds of appeal did not raise a pure issue of law.
column3: HAL applied for leave to appeal the decision of an arbitration panel. The arbitration panel was constituted to resolve a commercial contractual dispute between HAL and SecurTek. The parties entered into three separate contracts designed to accomplish the business goals of the parties. They were (i) the International Distribution and Software Licence Agreement (IDSL); (ii) the Software Customization Agreement (ESMA) and (iii) the Escrow and Software Modification Agreement (EMMA). HELD: The application was dismissed. A term permitting an appeal from the arbitrators' decision on an error of law simply does not fall into the category of the obvious, or something that goes without saying, in the factual matrix of this case. Such an implied term is not akin, for instance, to the implied term of good faith in contractual negotiation, or the implied terms of good workmanship in contracts for repair or renovation work, or to the term of reasonable notice of termination in contracts of employment. The terms of the agreements, which contain clauses relating to the minimum sales target that Securtek was required to meet in order to maintain its exclusive right to distribute its products, were clearly intended to be binding. The fact that the parties referred to one specific instance in which an appeal would be permissible was significant. The absence of reference to any other circumstances in which appeal would not be permitted was intentional. The decision of the arbitration panel constituted to determine the commercial contractual disputes between HAL, Secur Tek and SecuraTek was not inadvertent, but intentional. It reflects the role of courts of appeal in ensuring the consistency of the law rather than providing new forum for parties to continue their private litigation. The court must conclude that these matters are referred to as questions of mixed law and fact, rather than a question of law.

The contractual language used by the parties was clear that they intended to resolve disputes by final and binding arbitration. column8: HAL applied for leave to appeal the decision of an arbitration panel. The arbitration panel was constituted to resolve a commercial contractual dispute between HAL and SecurTek. The parties entered into three separate contracts designed to accomplish the business goals of the parties. They were (i) the International Distribution and Software Licence Agreement (IDSL); (ii) the Software Customization Agreement (ESMA) and (iii) the Escrow and Software Modification Agreement. HELD: The application was dismissed. A term permitting an appeal from the arbitrators’ decision on an error of law simply does not fall into the category of the obvious, or something that goes without saying, in the factual matrix of this case. Such an implied term is not akin, for instance, to the implied term of good faith in contractual negotiation, or the term of fair workmanship in contracts for repair or renovation work, or to implied term for reasonable notice of termination in contracts of employment. It raises a question of mixed law and fact rather than question of law. While there are some cases in which term must be implied in order to ensure that the intention of parties is not defeated, the court does not have licence to reconstruct a contract on equitable principles, or from the point of view of what the parties should reasonably have contemplated.

column18: HAL applied for leave to appeal the decision of an arbitration panel. The arbitration panel was constituted to resolve a commercial contractual dispute between HAL and SecurTek. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)A term permitting an appeal from the arbitrators' decision on an error of law simply does not fall into the category of the obvious, or something that goes without saying, in the factual matrix of this case. Such an implied term is not akin, for instance, to the implied term of good faith in contractual negotiation, or the term of reasonable notice of termination in contracts of employment. If the right to appeal is not abrogated by the language of the agreements, the court does not have licence to reconstruct a contract on equitable principles, or from the point of view of what the parties should reasonably have contemplated. 2)The term should generally not be implied where it is inconsistent with the express terms of the contract. While there are some cases in which term must be implied in order to ensure that the intention of the parties is not defeated, it does not provide for right of appeal on the basis of errors in law. 3)The terms of a contract set out very clear and well-defined procedures for dispute resolution. It does not permit appeals on questions of law, which is something that the parties intentionally “contracted out” of it. 4)The provisions of the agreement between the parties (the IDSL, the SCA and ESMA) exclude the right of an appeal on a questions of fact, pursuant to s. 45(2) of the Act. It is trite law that parties who have commercial contractual relationship can, by agreement, abrogate appellate review of the arbitrator’s decision. While it is clear that there were some cases which require the parties to appeal an arbitrators’ decision, with leave, on a limited application, this supports treating contractual interpretation as a question of mixed fact and law. 5)It is clear from the wording of the arbitration agreements that the agreements in place between HAL, Securtek, and the ESMA contain an implied condition that permits them to appeal a decision made on a case-by-case basis, notwithstanding the absence of such provision in the agreements. The court can imply terms that are in the nature of things that go without saying. However, such terms cannot always be found, and if there is evidence of contrary intention on the part of either party, it cannot be dismissed.

column2: HELD: The application was granted. The judgment was set aside and the defendant given leave to file its statement of defence. column2: The 21 year old appealed his conviction of armed robbery, the sentence of three years imprisonment and a ten year s.100 order. HELD: The conviction appeal was dismissed, the sentence appeal was allowed and one year incarceration with a ten year s100 order were imposed. The Crown was correct in characterizing the incident as technically a robbery which was at the low end of the scale of seriousness. What originally would have been a shop-lifting became more serious because of the altercation between the clerk and the appellant.
column3: The 21 year old appellant appeals his conviction on a charge of armed robbery pursuant to ss. 343(d) and 344 of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to three years imprisonment and a ten year s. 100 order. HELD: The appeal was dismissed. The sentence appeal was allowed and a sentence of 1 year incarceration was imposed along with a ten years s.100 order. 1)The Crown conceded the incident was 'technically a robbery' and was at the low end of the scale of seriousness. 2)The Court of Appeal allowed the sentence appeal and reduced the sentence to 1 year imprisonment with a 10 year s100 order; 3)The sentence appeal is allowed and the sentence of one year incarceration is allowed.
column4: Appeal as to conviction dismissed: December 10, 1996 (orally) LANE J.A. The 21 year old appellant appeals his conviction on a charge of armed robbery pursuant to ss. 343(d) and 344 of the Criminal Code. He was sentenced to three years imprisonment and a ten year s. 100 order. We are all of the view the Crown is correct in characterizing the incident as “technically a robbery”. The appeal against conviction is therefore dismissed. We also agree with the Crown the robbery was at the low end on a scale of seriousness and what originally would have been a simple shop-lifting became more serious because of the altercation between the clerk and the appellant. The conviction appeal is therefore dismissed, the sentence appeal is allowed and a sentence of one year incarceration is imposed along with a ten year section 100 order.

The 21 year old appellant appeals his conviction on a charge of armed robbery pursuant to ss. 343(d) and 344 of the Criminal Code. column2: The plaintiff paid its municipal property taxes as assessed for three years. On appeal it was held to be entitled to a refund for each of the three years in the total amount of $420,000. The plaintiff, pursuant to s. 41(I) of the Judicature Act, sought payment of interest on this amount from the date of the payments. Awarding 5 months interest, that the date from which interest is calculated in this type of action is upon completion of the appeal process. An appropriate interest claim under s. 41(I) therefore only exists for the five month period between the Court of Appeal's assessment determination and the refund of the property tax five months later.
column3: The plaintiff municipal tax payer paid its property taxes as assessed for the years 1994, 1995, 1996 and 1997 but on appeal was held entitled to a refund for each of the three years in the total amount of $420,177.13. The plaintiff sought interest on the refund from the date it made the overpayments in response to HRM's tax invoices requiring payment of those amounts on the due dates in 1994, 1996, 1995 and 1996. The court upheld the Utility and Review Board's assessment determination which translated into $420.13 overpayment of taxes. HRM paid interest on this amount for the five month period between the Nova Scotia Court of Appeal assessment determination in March 1997 and the payment of the property tax refund in September 1997. HRMs earned interest on that money from the time of receipt or had the use of these monies. HELD: 1)There was no right to a full refund of overpaid taxes until March 1997 when the Nova Nova Scotia court of appeal rendered its decision upholding the reduction in the assessment. An appropriate interest claim does exist under s. 41(i) of the Judicature Act, supra on the principal amount for five month periods between the the Nova SCC assessment determination and the November 1997 decision and the September 1997 payment of property tax refunds as well as on the unpaid interest until date of judgment. An interest rate of 8.75% being a rate equatable to the interest rate charged by HRM on overdue taxes (prime plus 4.75) is an appropriate rate on the balance of principal amount of the five year period between Nova Scotia Supreme Court of Appeals assessment determination of March 1997 to the date of the refund on September 1997 and on the outstanding unpaid interest from September 1997 to date of Judgment. 2)There is no right or entitlement to a return of overpaymentof taxes until the March 1997 date the Nova Scotian Court of appeal decision upholding a reduction in assessment. There was no entitlement to the refund of the overpaid tax until March 1998 when the Halifax Regional Municipality rendered its ruling upholding the assessment decision upholding it. 3)The Court of Queen's Bench awarded interest on an overpayment in the amount of approximately $420 to HRMs. HRH was under direct mandatory statutory obligation pursuant to s. 90 of the Assessment Act, s.41(i), supra to refund any amount overpaid as soon as the appeal process concluded.

HRM paid the refund of overpaid real property taxes to Canada Trust, pursuant to S. 90 of the Assessment Act, supra on the principal amount for the five month period between the Nova Scotia court of Appeal assessment determination in March 1997 and the payment of the property tax refund in September 1997 as well as on the unpaid interest until the date of judgment. The date the interest claim did not change or revert back to an earlier date when the tax payments were remitted because the appeal process has concluded.  4)The plaintiff was awarded a refund of the overpaid taxes for the three year period from March 1997 to September 1997. 5)Costs were to be determined on the basis of pre-judgment interest on the amount overpaid.

column2: An appeal under s.33.1 of the Municipal Board Act from a decision of the Assessment Appeals Committee of the Saskatchewan Municipal Board, one in a series of appeals heard at the same time dealing with the application of a newly introduced market adjustment factor (MAF) to assessments for municipal tax purposes. In issue was whether the assessor erred in law by misconstruing or misapplying the provisions of the Assessment Manual in determining the MAF for the appellant's shopping centre properties by using a single sale to calculate the MAF; and by creating as a commercial building neighbourhood the grouping of fully enclosed shopping centres which encompassed the entire city. HELD: 1)The assessment was set aside and the matter was remitted to the assessor to be dealt with according to the manual. Both issues were dealt with in Cadillac Fairview v. Saskatoon (TWL CA00074) and the same reasoning applied. 2)The appellant conceded that the question of whether the various expansions of the shopping centre resulted in abnormal functional economic obsolescence was a question of mixed law and fact and was thus beyond the scope of this appeal. 3)The second branch of the appeal was dismissed. Whether the committee erred in law by saying the definition of functional obsolescence did not apply to an add-on type of construction was beside the point since that was not the ground for the decision. The decision was not the result of any wrong interpretation of the manual but was the result of the appellant's failure to establish to the committee's satisfaction the facts on which it based its case. The decision was therefore beyond the Court of Appeal's jurisdiction to review.  4)There was no order as to costs as success was divided.
column3: This appeal was taken under s.33.1 of The Municipal Board Act, s.23.2. It was from a decision of the Assessment Appeals Committee of the Saskatchewan Municipal Board. The issues raised by the appellant in this case respecting the MAF to be used in calculating the assessed value were exactly the same as those raised in another judgment, issued concurrently with this one. The appeal was allowed on the same basis in respect of these grounds of appeal. HELD: The decision was arrived at not as a result of any wrong interpretation of the manual, but as a consequence of the appellant's failure to establish to the satisfaction of the committee the facts on which it based its case.  1)The decision was not a result to any wrong interpretations of the Manual but rather a result that the appellant failed to establish the facts of the Committee the facts upon which it relied.  2)The appeal was arrived too late in the process of reviewing the assessment of Midtown Plaza in Saskatoon. It is one of a series of appeals heard at the same time dealing with the application of a newly introduced market adjustment factor to assessments for municipal tax purposes.  3)The issues raised in this appeal were exactly those raised and dealt with in another decision issued concurrently. The Saskatchewan Assessment Manual summarizes and defines functional obsolescence in this way: formula, rules and principles for determining the amount of money spent on a project. The formula is specific that all normal functional obsolescentence is accounted for in the Maf. Abnormal functional obs obsolescences is accounted only for if there is an inability of an improvement to perform the function for which it is used. 4)The appellant only raised two issues: 1)Did the assessment adjust the MIFF by misconstruing or misapplying the provisions of the assessment manual or by creating a commercial building neighbourhood the grouping of fully enclosed shopping centres which encompassed the entire City of Saskatoon?  2.)Did the Assessor err in law by misapprehending or misunderstanding the provisions in the Assessment Manual in determining the market adjustment factors for the appellant properties by using a single sale to calculate the market adjust factor?  3.)Did he err in his interpretation of abnormal functional obsence as defined in the Manual? 4)Did he erred in law in concluding that the definition of functional obsolesence did not apply to an add-on type construction, or by finding that there must be an inability to an improvement of the function to perform for which the appellant is used? 5)The

[16] This branch of the appeal must, accordingly, be dismissed.

column17: An appeal under s.33.1 of the Municipal Board Act from a decision of the Assessment Appeals Committee of the Saskatchewan Municipal Board, one in a series of appeals heard at the same time dealing with the application of a newly introduced market adjustment factor (MAF) to assessments for municipal tax purposes. In issue was whether the assessor erred in law by misconstruing or misapplying the provisions of the Assessment Manual in determining the MAF for the appellant's shopping centre properties by using a single sale to calculate the MAF; and by creating as a commercial building neighbourhood the grouping of fully enclosed shopping centres which encompassed the entire city. HELD: 1)The assessment was set aside and the matter was remitted to the assessor to be dealt with according to the manual. Both issues were dealt with in Cadillac Fairview v. Saskatoon (TWL CA00074) and the same reasoning applied. 2)The appellant conceded that the question of whether the various expansions of the shopping centre resulted in abnormal functional economic obsolescence was a question of mixed law and fact and was thus beyond the scope of this appeal. 3)The second branch of the appeal was dismissed. Whether the committee erred in law by saying the definition of functional obsolescence did not apply to an add-on type of construction was beside the point since that was not the ground for the decision. The decision was not the result of any wrong interpretation of the manual but was the result of the appellant's failure to establish to the committee's satisfaction the facts on which it based its case. The decision was therefore beyond the Court of Appeal's jurisdiction to review.  4)There was no order as to costs as success was divided.

column2: The accused was charged with assault causing bodily harm. The complainant willingly took part in a fight club after which the accused followed him and engaged in a second physical altercation with him. During the fight, the parties fell into a dresser, onto the floor and out a window. At some stage of the fight, the complainant sustained a nasal fracture, which was the basis of the charge. Accused not guilty of assault causing bodily harm. The confrontation between the accused and the complainant was one continuing episodic event and the complainant's actions were provoked by the accused. However, no causal relationship was shown between the blows of the accused and the broken nose sustained by the complainant. There were too many variables and probabilities as to how the complainant's nose might have become broken.
column3: HELD: The accused was found guilty of assault causing bodily harm to the complainant. The court found that the accused had not provoked the assault. The complainant sustained a nasal fracture. The accused did not admit to the assault but argued self defence. The Court found that he had not intended to cause grievous bodily harm but rather that he was provoked by the assault by the complainant and that he did not intend to cause it.
column4: However, at some stage of their contact, the complainant sustained a nasal fracture for which he sought and received medical attention. I find the accused, Craig Nickerson, not guilty, as charged, and will enter an acquittal on the record.

It must prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the blows delivered by the accused when they were on the floor were the actual cause or were contributing factors outside the de minimis range.

column2: FIAT: The sole issue before the court is the amount to be fixed for the ongoing s. 7 expenses. The s. 7 expenses claimed by the petitioner include dental work of $112.90 for Kristen, orthodontic work for Brina and costs associated with Brina's post-secondary education. It is uncontroverted that Brina has disabilities that necessitate certain tools such as a computer for her to be successful in her post-secondary training. HELD: 1) The respondent accepts responsibility for his proportionate share of the girls' dental and orthodontic expenses and there shall be an order accordingly. 2) The September 2004 consent order provided that computer repairs and equipment were included in Brina's s. 7 expenses. Accordingly the costs relating to the computer are legitimate s. 7 costs. 2) The crisis prevention class was a reasonable expense incurred on Brina's part and will assist her with her future plans. 3) The Zeller's supplies would normally be covered under the Table support and that expense is disallowed. 4) Brina's s. 7 post-secondary expenses are $7,123.72 and include tuition, crisis prevention class and books, required university books, bus pass, black cartridge for the printer, Shaw internet, Microsoft licence, computer repairs and updated virus protection.
column3: FIAT: The petitioner applies to have arrears fixed with regard to s. expenses related to her daughter's post-secondary education and in addition requests that the amount of ongoing s. 7 expenses be specified. HELD: 1) The Court finds that the parties' three children have been married for over four years and that the respondent has not paid any s.7 expenses since Justice Dickson's order of September 23, 2004. The Court also finds that crisis prevention class was a reasonable expense incurred on the petitioner's part and will assist her in her future plans. The Zellers supplies, however, would normally be covered under Table support. Accordingly, that expense shall be disallowed. 2) The s.8 post-graduate education expenses for the 2005/2006 year are calculated as follows:University of Saskatchewan fall and spring terms ($932.97 x 2) 3,002.60 x 2);University of Regina fall and winter terms ($1,501.94 x 2), 3,000.94 3) The respondent's s.-7 post-primary education expenses are calculated using the table support. The respondent has been ordered to pay 66% of the s. costs for the s7 expenses. The costs relating to the computer are legitimate s. 7 costs. The crisis prevention classes were a reasonable expenditure incurred on Brina's part on her part and would assist her future plan. The $1,221 orthodontic work was included in the computer's s7 costs and was legitimate s7 expense. The cost relating to computer repairs was disallowed as the costs relating the computer were legitimate s-7 costs of the respondent. The addition of the Zeller supplies was a substantial expense incurred by the petitioner on the respondent's part. The other expense was disallow. 3) There shall be an order for the respondent to immediately pay his 66% share of the table and Table support to the respondent within 10 days of receipt of any bills pertaining to such expenses.

column27: FIAT: The petitioner applies to have arrears fixed with regard to s. expenses related to her daughter's post-secondary education and in addition requests that the amount to be fixed for ongoing s. 7 expenses. HELD: 1) The Court ordered that the respondent immediately pay the petitioner's 66% share of the child support costs.  2) The court found that the September 28, 2004 consent order provided that computer repairs and equipment were included in the applicant's s.7 expenses. Accordingly, the costs relating to the computer were legitimate s. 7 costs. The crisis prevention class was a reasonable expense incurred on Brina's part and will assist her in her future plans. column2: The appellants were found guilty of breaching a rural municipal bylaw which provides 'That no poultry or livestock be permitted in districts zoned Hamlet [sic].' There were four grounds of appeal: 1) an application to admit new evidence on appeal; 2) a constitutional challenge seeking a declaration that the bylaw was ultra vires for uncertainty; 3) the significance of the word 'hamlet' in the bylaw; and 4) the meaning of the word 'livestock' in the bylaw. HELD: The appeal is dismissed. 1) New evidence will not be admitted on an appeal if, by due diligence, it could have been adduced at trial. Further, new evidence will be admitted only if it bears upon a decisive or potentially decisive issue in the trial. Neither of these requirements is met. 2) The constitutional challenge is not properly before the Court as notice is required when the constitutionality of a bylaw is impugned. In any event, the uncertainty on which the appellants rely in attacking the bylaw does not exist. 3) The appellants misunderstand the use of the word 'hamlet' in the bylaw. 4) Whatever definition of 'livestock' is used, the definition always includes cattle.

column23: At a June 2, 2006 trial in Provincial Court, the appellants were found guilty of breaching a bylaw of the Rural Municipality of Vanscoy No.345. The trial justice convicted them of breaching Bylaw 2.1995, which provides that no poultry or livestock be permitted in districts zoned Hamlet. The appellants did not lead evidence at trial. They did not dispute that they were keeping cattle on their property. Their defence related to points of law. HELD: The application to admit new evidence was dismissed. The evidence will be admitted on appeal only if it bears upon a decisive or potentially decisive issue in the trial. The uncertainty on the evidence does not exist. The references to proposed amendments in the letter would not establish that there had been any amendments. Even if the question were properly before me, it would dismiss the application. 1) The evidence that has come into the possession of appellants after the trial and that they seek to admit admit, includes: (a) minutes of council meetings that occurred before the trial; (b) Bylaws 1-1993, 8-1994 and 1-1998 of the rural municipality; (c) letter from Saskatchewan Government Relations and Aboriginal Affairs suggesting an amendment to the rural Municipality's basic planning statement; (d) the significance of the word 'hamlet' in the bylaw; and (e) the meaning of 'livestock' under any definition. 2) In the absence of a specific definition of livestock, it is uncertain, and it can be defined so broadly as to be either meaningless or unenforceable. 3) For the reasons listed in the balance of this decision, the application was dismissed for reasons of due diligence. 4) There is no basis on which to reverse the trial decision. It is not unreasonable to expect non-lawyers to frame their requests for documents in a manner that permits one to understand what documents are being sought.

column2: The defendant council, charged with the general oversight and administration of matters under the Natural Products Marketing Act, delegated certain authority to commodity boards such as the plaintiff. The plaintiff requested that the defendant hold a show cause hearing to determine whether certain producers had contravened their licence but when a procedural breakdown occurred as to how that hearing would be conducted, with the plaintiff seeking and being denied an adjournment, the hearing was held without the plaintiff's participation. The plaintiff brought an application for mandamus to compel the defendant to hold a new hearing and filed two affidavits providing some detail and background information as to its reasoning for its failure to attend the hearing and the parties' differing positions regarding their respective roles in the application of the management plan. The defendant brought an application to strike certain of the affidavits filed by the plaintiff on the basis that they were an attempt to put evidence to the court on matters not forming part of the record. Application to strike affidavits dismissed; the Rules do not preclude the admission of affidavits on an application and, in the present circumstances, reason and fairness militated against ruling the affidavits inadmissible. There was no authority for denying the parties the use of affidavits should this application proceed as a jurisdictional dispute and, should it proceed by way of an error of law on the face of the record, the affidavits were also admissible to complete the record.
column3: The applicant board applied to have the affidavits of the applicant board's president and president struck out as an attempt to put evidence to the Court on matters not in or forming part of the Council's record. The applicant sought to have these affidavits struck as an effort to put forth evidence not in the Record of the council and in its adjudicative setting. The Attorney General had previously dismissed the Board's application. The Board had refused to appear at the hearing because their request for adjournment had been denied. The appellant had challenged the Board’s decision that the Merks brothers to produce turkeys had been contravened and that their license should be suspended. The board had refused in part to allow the Merk brothers to file a motion for a show cause hearing. The Merks license was not suspended.

column8: The applicant board applied to have the affidavits of the applicant board's president and president struck out as an attempt to put evidence to the Court on matters not in or forming part of the Record of the Council Panel in its adjudicative setting. The applicant sought to have these affidavits struck as an effort to put forth evidence not in the record but in the adjudicatory setting. HELD: The application was dismissed. The court found that there was a jurisdictional dispute between the parties and that the affidavit evidence was not admissible. If the applicant had refused to appear at the hearing because their request for adjournment had been denied, the hearing would have been held as scheduled without the participation of the Board and the reasons for holding the'show cause' hearing were irrelevant. The affidavits were admissible but otherwise not admitted. The Court found that the affidavit evidence was never struck on the basis of an error in law.

Dismissing the application, that there must be a real dispute with respect to the authority of the Board to suspend and deal with licenses, and the authority to cancel or revoke or suspend licenses, as well as evidentiary issues of the nature raised in Waverley et al v. Nova Scotia (1993), 123 N.S.R. (2d) 46 (SC), the applicant board argued that affidavit evidence is only admissible if it raises jurisdictional issues or if they complain of an error in law. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)If the Court reviewed the present application as a jurisdictional dispute (which seems to be the position of all parties), that quotation does not form authority for denying the parties the use of affidavits. 2)The affidavits were always admissible to show that the record was incomplete, as for instance, that the conviction omitted the evidence of one of the witnesses. If the hearing was held as scheduled, without the participation of the board, the decision would be quashed and new hearing ordered.  3)The court found that affidavits are admissible on an application for certiorari. column2: The respondent mother applied to lift the stay of execution imposed by Court of Appeal Rule 15(1) when the appellant father appealed the trial judge's decision to award custody of the parties' son to the mother with the child to have access to the father for one extended weekend per month during the school year (see: 2013 SKQB 212). The trial judge had found that both parties had exhibited a lack of interest in their child and there was little to distinguish either of them as the better custodial parent. As the mother had facilitated the father's access to the child and he had not demonstrated the same willingness and that the most important relationship in the child's life was with his sister, who resides with the mother, the trial judge found that it was in the child's best interest to foster that relationship and grant custody to the mother. HELD: The Court granted the application. There would be no harm to the child if the stay was lifted. The father was directed to perfect his appeal and the stay of proceedings arising from Court of Appeal Rule 15(4) was also lifted.
column3: The applicant mother sought a lifting of the stay of execution on the judgment of the trial judge (indexed as 2013 SKQB 212 (CanLII)). The trial judge awarded the mother custody of the parties' son to have access to the father for one extended weekend per month during the regular school year and for one half of major school breaks, with each party to share and assist in the transportation of their son for the purposes of access. The trial court found that the child was to have regular and consistent contact with both his parents. HELD: The application was granted.  1)The court found it was in the child's best interests to lift the stay on the decision of the Trial Judge (indexing as 2013SKQB 212) which was automatically imposed upon the father's appeal from that decision. 2)The Court found that it would be in the children's best interest to lift this stay on a decision made between the parties’ parents. The child was the only constant in his life and the only person who could have been a better custodial parent. The father’s seeming inability to facilitate access to his mother and his sister was of considerable concern. 3)The child was essentially abandoned by both parents. From the time the parents abdicated their parental responsibilities in favour of his grandmother, who abdicates their parental responsibility in favour the Clifton family. The relationship with his sister had not yet formed the bond with them that he had with his brother. 4)The evidence before the trial court was not supplemented by the materials submitted in respect of the within application. The evidence before her was not much supplemented by materials submitted by the mother. 5)The trial judge found that although the child could be bonded or attached to either of his parents in any meaningful way, the child would not be able to be permanently attached to them. The court lifted the stay and lifted the remainder of proceedings arising pursuant to Rule 15(4).

column2: A notice to vacate rented premises contained an erroneous address. The Rentalsman granted a writ of possession and after the issuance of the writ, amended the writ to correct the address without notice to the tenant. The tenant appealed. HELD: Appeal allowed. There had not been compliance with s. 23(1)(b) of the Act. The notice to vacate was therefore ineffective and the consequent writ of possession was quashed. Given the tenant's obstructionist tactics he was denied his costs of the appeal.
column3: The tenant was served with notice to deliver up the premises described as 201 1st Street West in Blaine Lake, Saskatchewan. When this did not produce the desired result, the tenant was ordered to vacate the premises. The tenant did not attend and in his absence a writ of possession was authorized in respect to the premises, which were municipally described as '201 1st St West'. The landlord did not reply to the appellant's request for a writ. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the order of the Rentalsman and the consequent writ of possess were quashed. There was no costs of the appeal.

column2: The applicant landowner sought to register a declaration with the respondent respecting a condominium property, which was subject to a right of way in favour of all the original landowners. An adjacent landowner refused to consent to the declaration. The applicant sought a declaration that the consent of the adjacent landowner was not required. Granting the application, that the word 'encumbrance' as defined in s.3(1)(o) of the Act involves a security feature and as there is no security feature to a right of way, unlike a mortgage or lien, it is not an encumbrance. The consent of the adjacent landowner, who had a right of way over a servient tenement, was not required.
column3: The applicant owner of certain lands informed the Registrar of Condominiums of his intention to seek registration pursuant to the Condominium Property Act. The land was subject to a right of way in favor of all landholders out of the original undivided piece of land. The structure sought to be registered as a condominium had been completed and did not physically encroach upon the right of a condolee. An adjacent owner with rights over the right-of-way refused to consent. The Registrar of condominiums advised the applicant that s.11(b) of the Act prohibits him from registering a declaration with respect to the property, such declaration being condition precedent to the operation of the act, unless the owners of the right‑of-ways consent to the declaration. The applicant has not formally applied to the Registrar for registration.
column4: The land is subject to a right‑of‑way in favor of all landholders out of the original undivided piece of land. The structure sought to be registered as a condominium has been completed and does not physically encroach upon the right‑of‑way. The applicant is seeking an order in the nature of mandamus directing the Registrar to accept the applicant's property for registration under the Act without a declaration of consent from the users of the right‑of‑way or, in the alternative, a declaration that such consent is not required by that section of the Act. The Legislature hints what it means by "encumbrance" in giving us the examples of a mortgage and a lien. But there is no security aspect to a right‑of‑way and, therefore, a right‑of‑way is not an encumbrance as defined in s. 3(1)(o) of the Act. In the result, the Court is prepared to issue a declaration in favor of the applicant and pointing out to the Registrar of Condominiums that consent is not required of users of rights‑of‑way over servient tenements.

In the result, the Court is prepared to issue a declaration in favor of the applicant and pointing out to the Registrar of Condominiums that consent is not required of users of rights‑of‑way over servient tenements.
column27: The owner of certain lands informed the Registrar of Condominiums of his intention to seek registration pursuant to the Condominium Property Act. The land was subject to a right-of-way in favor of all landholders out of the original undivided piece of land. The structure sought to be registered as a condominium had been completed and did not physically encroach upon the right of way. An adjacent owner refused to consent to the registration. The applicant sought an order directing the Registrar to accept the applicant's property for registration without a declaration of consent from the users of the right-o-way or, in the alternative, a declaration that such consent is not required by that section of the Act. HELD: The application was granted. The Court was prepared to issue a declaration in favour of the applicant and pointing out to the Registrar that consent was not required of users of rights-of‑way over servient tenements.

column3: The applicant solicitor applied to strike the proceeding on the basis that he had failed to make a proper affidavit and was in the position of a witness. The applicant solicitor had indicated that he would withdraw as solicitor for the plaintiff and that he was considering a number of remedies, including compensation for the plaintiffs and fees, but continued on the defence application to strike. The application was supported by the 17 page affidavit of the applicant solicitor and placed himself in the role of a cross-examined witness.
column4: The defence takes the position that the application is supported by the 17 page, 123 paragraph affidavit of Charles D. Lienaux, and that he has placed himself in the position of a witness who may be cross‑examined. Undoubtedly the court will, when the original application on its merits is heard, hear any evidence which it determines to be relevant, but I fail to see how that determination permits the plaintiff's solicitor to escape the ethical duty not to give evidence in a matter in which the lawyer is involved as counsel except in merely formal or uncontroverted matters. The boundaries of Civil Procedure Rule 14.25 are quite broad, and I am satisfied that with his removal from the original application, it would not be proper for him to continue on an application directly related or arising from it.

column2: The accused, a young offender, was convicted of escaping lawful custody, theft of property valued in excess $1,000.00, dangerous driving and being in possession of stolen property. A Provincial Court Judge sentenced him to 5 months closed custody concurrent with a sentence of 9 months open custody which he was serving at the time of his escape. The Crown appealed. HELD: Appeal allowed. 1)The accused had a lengthy record as a young offender and turned 18 two days after the commission of the last of the offences for which he was being sentenced. 2)The Court substituted a sentence of 12 months closed custody, concurrent with the 9 months open custody which he was already serving.
column3: The Crown appealed the disposition of a young offender, who pled guilty to four Criminal Code offences following his guilty plea to four criminal Code offences. HELD: 1)The Crown appeal was allowed. 1)A five month closed custody disposition was not fit. 2)A nine month open custody sentence was substituted. 3)The offender had been involved in a series of offences. He had been in breach of probation. All offences committed after the first two charges were in breach. 4)A 5 month secure custody disposition, concurrent to an existing disposition, was not considered.
column4: Appeal Allowed: The Crown appealed the disposition imposed on B.D.L., a young offender, following his guilty plea to four Criminal Code offences. For these offences, B.D.L. received, in total, a five months closed custody disposition on October 17, 1994 concurrent to a nine month open custody disposition previously imposed on September 17, 1994. We are all of the view, having regard for the age of the offender, his previous record and the nature of the offences committed, notably the escape custody and dangerous driving, that a five month secure custody disposition, concurrent to an existing disposition, was not fit. Accordingly, the disposition of five months is set aside and one year secure custody, again concurrent to the nine month open custody sentence, substituted.

column2: The plaintiff, a specialty seed marketing company, claimed damages from the defendant for an alleged breach of contract. Johnson Seeds entered contracts with growers prior to the seeding and harvesting to secure product for resale. After extended negotiations the defendant eventually signed and mailed the standard form contract but never received an executed copy. The price of the canary seed escalated substantially during 1993. The defendant thought that as he did not have a copy of the contract signed by the plaintiff it was not a valid contract and sold the seed to a third party for more than double the contract price. HELD: Johnson Seeds was awarded judgment for $50,850.05 and pre-judgment interest together with costs of the action. 1)There was a valid contract between the parties. Damages were assessed as of January 1994 when Johnson Seeds knew that the defendant was in breach of the contract. 2)The issue was whether communication by delivery of the fully executed contract was necessary to complete the contract. The parties communicated by fax, mail and telephone. There was no doubt that the defendant verbally confirmed that a contract did exist. Discussions prior to May 1993 were pre-contractual negotiations. 3)Johnson Seed knew that it was prepared to pay 10 cents only if delivery occurred after January 1/94. The formal contract did not expressly set forth these conditions. Both parties knew these terms were absent when they executed the contract but both considered that they had a legally binding contract in 1993.  4)Farr took a calculated risk and sold the seed which alleviated his immediate cash-flow problem. Johnson Seeds waited until the last possible day under the written contract terms to call the contract in an effort to position itself to claim increased damages for breach of contract.
column3: The plaintiff entered into a contract with the defendant for the resale of canary seed. The contract was written in May 1993 and the parties had discussed the possibility of a contract being executed. The defendant had not received an executed copy of the contract. The plaintiff argued that the contract was not binding and that the terms of the agreement were not in the contract and that it was incumbent upon the defendant to insist that it be expressly stated in the document. The court awarded the plaintiff $50,000.00 in damages. The agreement was not valid. The parties had communicated in person, by telephone and by fax. The defendants both considered that they had a binding and legally enforceable contract in May and in November 1993. The use of the word 'call' was unfamiliar to the defendant. The lawyer had retained a fully executed copy on his file. The letter from the defendant was never received. The judge was satisfied that the defendant had verbally confirmed the contract to the plaintiff.

The plaintiff, S.S. Johnson Seeds Ltd. ("Johnson
Seeds"), claims damages from the defendant, Barry Farr
("Farr"), for an alleged breach of contract. Farr and Johnson Seeds both considered that they had
a binding and legally enforceable contract in May and in
November, 1993. While it may have
been in the reasonable contemplation of Farr that he would
receive back a fully executed copy of the contract, there is
no doubt that in the telephone conversations he had with
Calcutt in November and December, 1993, he verbally confirmed
that in his view a contract did exist. satisfied. Further, Farr had verbally confirmed on at least
two occasions that he did have a contract with Johnson Seeds
and at all times Calcutt confirmed that such a contract did
exist. For all these reason, I find that there was a valid
contract between Johnson Seeds and Farr. I find that Johnson Seeds knew in January 1994 that
Farr was in breach of the contract and this is when damages
should be assessed. Accordingly, Johnson Seeds shall have
judgment against Farr for $50,850.05 and pre-judgment interest
calculated in accordance with The Pre-Judgment Interest Act,
S.S. 1984-85-86, c. P-22.2 together with costs of the action.
