column13: The plaintiff sought damages from the defendant for an alleged breach of contract. The defendant had entered into a binding and legally enforceable contract with the plaintiff in 1993. The plaintiff had not received an executed copy of the contract until November 1993. In November 1993, the plaintiff telephoned the defendant and confirmed that he had a contract with Johnson Seeds. At the time the contract was executed, Johnson Seeds retained a fully executed copy. In early 1994, the defendant called Johnson Seeds to inquire whether they produced any overage on the contract. When Johnson Seeds did not contact Johnson Seeds in December 1993, it should therefore have been in the reasonable contemplation of the plaintiff that he would receive back a fully-executed copy. The post office was legitimate agent of Johnson Seeds for the purpose of communicating the acceptance of the offer and the postal acceptance rule was satisfied. Further, Farr had verbally confirmed on at least two occasions that he did have a contract and at all times the defendant confirmed that such a contract did exist. HELD: 1)The contract was valid. 2)It was not written into the contract and the defendant was not sufficiently careful to ensure that this term was there in print at the time he executed it. 3)Although it may have been possible to argue that a contract was not valid, there was no doubt that in the telephone conversations between Johnson Seeds and Farr in November and December 1993 that he verbally confirmed that in his view a contract existed. 4)The defendant had not proven that the contract did not exist. 5)Although the defendant did not provide a copy to the plaintiff, it was clear that the defendant had signed the contract in person and that the parties communicated in person, by telephone, by fax and by mail.  6)The plaintiff was awarded $50,000.00 in damages.

column22: The plaintiff, a specialty seed marketing company, claimed damages from the defendant for an alleged breach of contract. Johnson Seeds entered contracts with growers prior to the seeding and harvesting to secure product for resale. After extended negotiations the defendant eventually signed and mailed the standard form contract but never received an executed copy. The price of the canary seed escalated substantially during 1993. The defendant thought that as he did not have a copy of the contract signed by the plaintiff it was not a valid contract and sold the seed to a third party for more than double the contract price. HELD: Johnson Seeds was awarded judgment for $50,850.05 and pre-judgment interest together with costs of the action. 1)There was a valid contract between the parties. Damages were assessed as of January 1994 when Johnson Seeds knew that the defendant was in breach of the contract. 2)The issue was whether communication by delivery of the fully executed contract was necessary to complete the contract. The parties communicated by fax, mail and telephone. There was no doubt that the defendant verbally confirmed that a contract did exist. Discussions prior to May 1993 were pre-contractual negotiations. 3)Johnson Seed knew that it was prepared to pay 10 cents only if delivery occurred after January 1/94. The formal contract did not expressly set forth these conditions. Both parties knew these terms were absent when they executed the contract but both considered that they had a legally binding contract in 1993.  4)Farr took a calculated risk and sold the seed which alleviated his immediate cash-flow problem. Johnson Seeds waited until the last possible day under the written contract terms to call the contract in an effort to position itself to claim increased damages for breach of contract.
column23: The plaintiff claims damages from the defendant for an alleged breach of contract. The contract between the plaintiff and the defendant was written in 1993 and signed in 1993. In 1993 the contract was signed by both parties and both parties considered that they had signed a binding and legally enforceable contract in May and in November 1993. The defendant retained a fully executed copy of the contract on its file in Arborg, Manitoba. In addition to the fax, the defendant had used the mail to communicate the offer to Johnson Seeds and it should therefore have been in the reasonable contemplation of the plaintiff that he would receive a fully-executed copy. The post office was a legitimate agent of Johnson Seeds for the purpose of communicating the acceptance of the offer and the postal acceptance rule was satisfied. Further, the plaintiff had verbally confirmed on at least two occasions that he did have a contract with Johnson Seeds, and at all times the defendant confirmed that such a contract did exist. HELD: The contract was valid. 1)The contract was not a binding one. 2)It was not written into the contract. 3)The defendant was not sufficiently careful to ensure that this term was there in print.

column2: The issue was whether it was appropriate for the court to require the accused to commence the trial by calling evidence on a Charter voir dire, where the accused gave notice of a Charter application. This would differ from the usual procedure, wherein the Crown commences the trial by calling its witnesses in the trial proper, and thereafter the accused applies for leave to apply the Crown evidence to the Charter application, where it is appropriate, in addition to calling other defence evidence on the application.HELD: In R. v. Kutynec, the court made the following determinations: 1) whatever procedures are used should not unnecessarily interfere with the inherent jurisdiction of the trial judge to control the conduct of the trial; 2) instead of creating procedures for Charter applications in provincial court, it is better to leave judges the discretion to determine matters such as sufficiency of notice and the extent of the offer of proof; 3) counsel should give timely notice to the Crown of the Charter issue, and at trial, the accused should be able to state with reasonable particularity the grounds upon which the application is made; 4) objections to admissibility of evidence must be made before or when the evidence is proffered; 5) the onus is on the accused to demonstrate on a balance of probabilities that he or she is entitled to a Charter remedy; 6) the trial judge should insist defence counsel state his or her position on possible Charter issues, either before or at the outset of the trial; 7) failing timely notice, a trial judge is entitled to refuse an application to assert a Charter remedy; 8) fairness may require the accused be given some latitude to explore potential Charter issues which he or she had no opportunity to develop prior to trial; and 9) the trial judge must control the proceedings to ensure this legitimate exploration does not become a fishing expedition. In R. v. Loveman, the court said the trial judge must ensure fairness and preserve the integrity of the trial process. This may require a judge to refuse to hear a motion where insufficient notice has been given, even when the motion involves an application to exclude evidence under s. 24 of the Charter. In R. v. Habhab, the court was asked to consider a procedure which involved entering into voir dire at the start of the trial and the Crown proceeding to lead their evidence at the outset regarding the Charter application and substantive issue. The court dismissed this proposal and stated that the case law implies it is the accused's obligation to lead the evidence on the voir dire. The court was not able to justify the proposed procedure. If the authorities imply there is an obligation on the accused to call evidence first on the Charter voir dire, this can occur by the application of some or all the evidence which is already on the record on the substantive issues. The admissibility of evidence can be reserved by the court pending judgment on the Charter and any s. 24 remedy. An advantage of having the Crown evidence on record at the outset is it removes uncertainty as to the nature of the testimony as it relates to the Charter application. This is preferable to the accused calling the Crown witness at the outset on the voir dire, discovering aspects of the evidence are contrary or unfavourable, and then having to convince the court to grant leave to cross-examine. It avoids a scenario where the Crown witness evidence is led by the defence on the voir dire, and then the accused must impeach the creditability of this witness in cross-examination as it relates to the proof of the substantive issues. The court concluded the fairness of the proceedings and public confidence in the administration of justice, were best served by the Crown first leading its evidence on the charge alleged and the accused having leave to request the evidence be applied to the Charter issue, if appropriate.
column3: The issue was whether it was appropriate for the court to require the accused to commence the trial by calling evidence on a Charter voir dire, where the accused has given notice of a Charter application. This would differ from the procedure which is usually utilized, wherein the Crown commences the trial in the trial proper and thereafter the accused applies to the court for leave to apply the Crown evidence to the Charter application, where it is appropriate to do so, and in addition to calling other defence evidence on the application. The issue was also raised in these proceedings whether it is proper for the Court to require a accused to begin the trial on a voir de dire, or where the defendant has given Notice of a charter application. HELD: The Court found that the procedure proposed by the Court was appropriate and reasonable. It would differ in that the Crown commenced the trial the same way as the accused commences a trial by call its witnesses in the Trial proper and then the accused applied to the Court for leave in the Court's jurisdiction to apply Crown evidence or to the application, and also in addition, calling other evidence on it. The Court reviewed the authorities which have been filed by the Crown. The court found that it was preferable to leave judges the discretion to determine matters such as sufficiency of notice and the extent of the offer of proof. It also found that there were instances where the defence could ask the court of leave to exclude evidence. The accused was not entitled to sit back and hope that something will emerge from the Crown's case to create a Charter argument or assist in one counsel is already prepared to make.

HELD: The Court found that the procedure proposed by the Court was appropriate and reasonable. It would differ in that the Crown commenced the trial the same way, calling its witnesses in a trial proper, and then the accused applied to the Court for leave in the case of the accused applying to the trial judge for leave. The Court reviewed the authorities which were filed by the Crown. The court found that in Provincial Court trials, it is better to leave judges the discretion to determine matters such as sufficiency of notice and the extent of the offer of proof. It also found that there will be instances where the defence, through no fault of its own, cannot provide a detailed summary of the evidence that it anticipates it will call in the application, and must assert entitlement at the earliest possible point of the trial. There will be circumstances where no less severe order will prevent unfairness and maintain the integrity of the process.  4)The court found no justification for the proposed procedure.

column2: The accused was charged with operating a vehicle when his blood alcohol level exceeded the prescribed limit and impaired driving. After being involved in an accident, the accused was taken to hospital where a blood demand was given and eventually acceded to. The accused challenged the validity of the blood demand and argued that his right to counsel was violated. Accused guilty of operating a vehicle when his blood alcohol level exceeded the prescribed limit; there was no violation of the accused's right to counsel. The officer had valid grounds to make the demand, having been advised that the accused was in an accident, that someone had said the accused was either high or intoxicated, having smelled a mild odour of alcohol on the accused and the accused having advised him that he only had three beer. Even if the accused's claim to amnesia for all the events around that time was believed, there was no medical evidence to suggest that he could not understand what the officer said to him at the hospital. Although his degree of alertness may have fluctuated, he displayed an understanding of the situation by showing appropriate concern for how much he had been drinking and asking questions which showed an understanding of his situation and what speaking to counsel would entail.
column3: The accused was charged under s. 253(b) of the Criminal Code with operating a motor vehicle when his blood alcohol level exceeded the prescribed limit. The accused was found guilty of impaired driving. HELD: The accused is found guilty. 1)The accused displayed an understanding of his situation through words and actions spanning a significant period of time. 2)The Court found that the accused possessed sufficient understanding of the circumstances surrounding his offence to warrant a blood demand. 3)The officer focused on the accused's understanding of what took place in the hospital regarding his right to counsel. The Court found an error in law in his interpretation of s. 10(b). 4)The court found that while his degree of alertness may have been fluctuating and his emotions unstable, the accused nevertheless displayed an awareness of his situations through words, actions and statements spanning a considerable period of period.
column4: [1] The defendant, Troy Burton, is charged under s. 253(b) of the Criminal Code with operating a motor vehicle when his blood alcohol level exceeded the prescribed limit. By focussing entirely upon Mr. Kennedy’s understanding of the communication of his right, the trial judge made an error of law in his interpretation of the import of s. 10(b) of the Charter. [36] While his degree of alertness may have been fluctuating, and his emotions unstable, Mr. Burton nevertheless displayed an understanding of his situation through words and actions spanning a significant period of time. [40] Accordingly, Mr. Burton is found guilty of the offence under s. 253(b).
column7: The accused was charged with operating a vehicle when his blood alcohol level exceeded the prescribed limit and impaired driving. After being involved in an accident, the accused was taken to hospital where a blood demand was given and eventually acceded to. The accused challenged the validity of the blood demand and argued that his right to counsel was violated. Accused guilty of operating a vehicle when his blood alcohol level exceeded the prescribed limit; there was no violation of the accused's right to counsel. The officer had valid grounds to make the demand, having been advised that the accused was in an accident, that someone had said the accused was either high or intoxicated, having smelled a mild odour of alcohol on the accused and the accused having advised him that he only had three beer. Even if the accused's claim to amnesia for all the events around that time was believed, there was no medical evidence to suggest that he could not understand what the officer said to him at the hospital. Although his degree of alertness may have fluctuated, he displayed an understanding of the situation by showing appropriate concern for how much he had been drinking and asking questions which showed an understanding of his situation and what speaking to counsel would entail.
column8: The accused was charged under s. 253(b) of the Criminal Code with operating a motor vehicle when his blood alcohol level exceeded the prescribed limit. He was charged with impaired driving under s253(a). HELD: The accused was granted s. 10(v) Charter rights at a time when he was capable of appreciating and understanding the rights. The accused displayed an understanding of his situation through words and actions spanning a significant period of time.

column13: The accused was charged under s. 253(b) of the Criminal Code with operating a motor vehicle when his blood alcohol level exceeded the prescribed limit. The accused had been in a single car accident in which his vehicle hit a shoulder and left the road. Witnesses testified that they first heard the defendant's vehicle accelerate towards them, then lost sight of it, and then heard the vehicle go over the embankment. While his degree of alertness may have been fluctuating and his emotions unstable, the defendant nevertheless displayed an understanding of his situation through words and actions spanning a significant period of time.

column27: The accused was charged under s. 253(b) of the Criminal Code with operating a motor vehicle when his blood alcohol level exceeded the prescribed limit. The accused was found guilty of impaired driving. HELD: The accused is found guilty. 1)The accused displayed an understanding of his situation through words and actions spanning a significant period of time. 2)The Court found that the accused possessed sufficient understanding of the circumstances surrounding his offence to warrant a blood demand. 3)The officer focused on the accused's understanding of what took place in the hospital regarding his right to counsel. The Court found an error in law in his interpretation of s. 10(b). 4)The court found that while his degree of alertness may have been fluctuating and his emotions unstable, the accused nevertheless displayed an awareness of his situations through words, actions and statements spanning a considerable period of period.

column2: An application for a DNA warrant on the basis s.487.05 (the general warrant provision) of the Criminal Code with respect to DNA warrants does not refer to a form. The applicant suggested a tape recording would avoid the potential problems in bringing the application before a Provincial Court Judge. HELD: These concerns were raised in the January 21 decision concerning potential prejudicial or negative effects, which outweigh any requirement to swear the Information before a judge. An oath taken before a commissioner or notary is as valid as it is before a provincial court judge and avoids all the possible problems that relate to personal attendance. The intention is to make protocol work as flexible as possible, not impeding the police in their legitimate role, while making sure the court maintains its independence. Form 5.01 is specifically set out in the Code. Section 487.1 does not have a form, but even if it did and used the same words 'taken before me', that would elevate form over substance in a significant way.
column3: The accused applied for a DNA warrant. The accused swore the Information to Obtain before a Provincial Court Judge. The Provincial Court judge had previously sworn the Information before a Commissioner of Oaths. The applicant had raised concerns about potential prejudicial or negative effects of a personal attendance before the judge. Dismissing the application, that the officer had to appear before the Provincial Court to swear the Information. The officer had not followed the proper procedure in dealing with this application. The court was of the view that the better practice is to put as much as possible in the Information as possible. The application if the sworn Information is delivered or faxed in secure way to the judge and then the judge can immediately deal with it and not have to have the officer come and appear at all and swear it.
column4: I understand -- and I did when I made the order -- that s.487.05 of the Code with respect to DNA warrants does have reference to a form and Form 5.01 which is related to that, and that’s specifically set out in the Code. I’m of the view, especially because s. 487.1, which is the general warrant provision, doesn’t have a form, but even if it did have a form and it used the same words, “taken before me”, that to require that the Information be sworn before the Provincial Court Judge elevates form over substance in a significant way, particularly in the context of the concerns that I raised in that decision about the potential prejudicial or negative effects of a personal attendance before the judge. It’s my view that those potential negative effects or results outweigh any supposed requirement to swear the Information before the judge. And looking at it in terms of substance, it seems to the Court that to ask the question, “Is there any more truth in the officer’s affidavit of Information because he swore it before a provincial -- before a Commissioner of Oaths or a Notary Public,” the answer is self-evident. [28] THE COURT: But regardless of that side issue, it seems to me the oath is perfectly as valid taken before a commissioner or a notary as it is before me. It gets sworn Information before the judge, on which he or she can act, and it avoids all of the possible problems that relate to the personal attendance, and I take your point about, about the tape recording getting around a good part of that.

column2: Two years after the divorce, the wife applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties' Corollary Relief Judgment, which incorporated the terms of Minutes of Settlement. Pursuant to the Corollary Relief judgment, the husband was currently paying the wife $4,350 per month as spousal support. The wife now wished to increase the monthly support to a figure which would more closely resemble that assessed pursuant to the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines, along with a substantial lump sum to compensate her for the underpayment of spousal support for the past two years. She also sought removal of a clause which provided for the discontinuation of support if the husband's professional income dropped below $80,000. The parties had been married for approximately thirty years and had one child, who was now independent. Application dismissed; the parties' current circumstances did not constitute a significant departure from the range of reasonable outcomes anticipated by the parties when the Agreement was signed. Both parties' income had increased since the divorce and the wife was not deeply in debt, as she alleged; there was no pressure exerted and no oppression during the course of negotiations; the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines are not law and allow for exceptions to the general formulas provided, one such exception being the assumption of debt by one of the parties (the husband in this case); the spousal support figure recognized the husband's reasonable expectation of retirement and the fact that he was experiencing health problems; it was completely foreseeable at the time that the Agreement was signed that, given the wife's age, she might experience difficulty in finding employment in her narrow field; the subsequent increased value of one of the husband's properties was not a reason to vary the spousal support provisions of the Agreement.
column3: The parties were married for over 29 years prior to their separation and had a daughter. The parties separated in May 2001 when the respondent moved from the matrimonial home and they were divorced in February 2003. At the time of their separation, the parties were granted a Corollary Relief Judgment. The applicant applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the Corollaries Relief Judgment, which incorporated the terms of an agreement signed by the parties. The respondent argued that the Agreement was sound when it was signed, that there have been no material changes in the circumstances of either of the parties since it was made and that the respondent did not take advantage of any vulnerability of the applicant. HELD: The agreement was valid and the applicant was bound by it. 1)The parties had been married for 29 years and had been engaged for 29 of those years. Although the parties had separated for over two years prior, the agreement was signed in good health and the parties' agreement with respect to spousals was not unconscionable. 2)The Agreement was signed with respect respect to the terms and conditions of the Agreement. The Agreement was not intended to be a complete and complete agreement. The agreement included the terms for spousa and the terms on which the parties agreed. 3)The agreement was not in substantial compliance with the objectives of the Divorce Act. The court found that there had been no change in the situation of either party since it signed. The husband had made modest mortgage payments and the wife was left essentially debt free while the respondent was assuming debts in excess of $300,000. The rental income more than covered the mortgage payment. 4)The respondent did nothing to take advantage or deference to the applicant's vulnerability. The amount of spousas payable by the respondent and the amount of the respondent were to be paid by the applicant in the amount set out in the Corolla Relief Judgment was $1,000,000 and the respondent had made no effort to reduce the amount owing to the wife. 5)The court found no evidence of coersion or coersion. The agreements were not intended for this Court to substitute what it might have ordered had the parties proceeded to trial. Although both parties were engaged in a long and successful marriage, the husband was in his late fifties when he received his doctorate and had spent time in the matriculation home. The wife was in the process of completing her university education. The mother was working part-time and the father was working full-time.
column4: [1] The Applicant, Marie-Louise Stening-Riding, has applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties’ Corollary Relief Judgment dated February 20th, 2003. At the same time as their divorce was granted a Corollary Relief Judgment was also granted which incorporated the terms of an agreement signed by the parties dated January 30, 2003. She proposed that the monthly support be increased to a figure that more closely resembles that which would be assessed pursuant to the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines and that she receive a substantial lump sum to compensate her for the “underpayment” of spousal support since the 1st of February 2003. [27] I find that there was no pressure exerted by the Respondent upon the Applicant and no oppression during the course of the negotiations or the signing of the Agreement and I find further that the Respondent did not take advantage of any vulnerability of the Applicant as contemplated by the Supreme Court in Miglin (supra). [35] Although the parties were married for over 29 years prior to their separation, in determining the appropriate spousal support terms, one has to take into account a number of factors including the Respondent’s age, his health (which has not been good) and the reasonable expectation of retirement. The Applicant should have been aware that whereas she was in her late fifties when she received her doctorate the prospects of her obtaining a full-time teaching position at a university in the narrow field of her expertise were far from great. It was completely foreseeable that she would have difficulty and perhaps no chance at all of obtaining such a position. [47] The incomes of both parties have increased since the Agreement was signed but that too was a foreseeable event. I do not consider the increased appraised value of the Respondent’s real estate to be a reason to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties’ Agreement. [54] In conclusion, the current circumstances of the parties are not a “significant departure from the range of reasonable outcomes anticipated by the parties” when they signed their Agreement. The application is dismissed.

It was completely foreseeable that the applicant would have difficulty and perhaps no chance at all of obtaining such a position. 3)The agreement was not unconscionable. Although the parties had been married for almost 29 years, they had been divorced for over a year prior to the parties' separation. The parties were engaged in a long and complicated marriage with a substantial amount of property being divided between them. 4)The respondent did not take advantage of any vulnerability of the applicant as contemplated by the Supreme Court decision Miglin v. Miglin (2003). 5)Although the parties lived in a relatively modest home, the applicant found that the divorce proceedings were very stressful and at the same time she was under great pressure to finish her thesis. She borrowed $150,000 on line of credit, using her home as security, to purchase mutual funds as an investment. She was also taking antidepressants. 6)The court found that there were no changes in circumstances since the signing of the Agreement. The respondent was left essentially debt free while the applicant was assuming debts in excess of $300,000. The amount of her rental income was effectively taxed free. The court ordered that the respondent receive a lump sum to compensate her for the 'underpayment' of spousals since the 1st of February 2003.
column9: [1] The Applicant, Marie-Louise Stening-Riding, has applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties’ Corollary Relief Judgment dated February 20th, 2003. At the same time as their divorce was granted a Corollary Relief Judgment was also granted which incorporated the terms of an agreement signed by the parties dated January 30, 2003. She proposed that the monthly support be increased to a figure that more closely resembles that which would be assessed pursuant to the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines and that she receive a substantial lump sum to compensate her for the “underpayment” of spousal support since the 1st of February 2003. [27] I find that there was no pressure exerted by the Respondent upon the Applicant and no oppression during the course of the negotiations or the signing of the Agreement and I find further that the Respondent did not take advantage of any vulnerability of the Applicant as contemplated by the Supreme Court in Miglin (supra). [35] Although the parties were married for over 29 years prior to their separation, in determining the appropriate spousal support terms, one has to take into account a number of factors including the Respondent’s age, his health (which has not been good) and the reasonable expectation of retirement. The Applicant should have been aware that whereas she was in her late fifties when she received her doctorate the prospects of her obtaining a full-time teaching position at a university in the narrow field of her expertise were far from great. It was completely foreseeable that she would have difficulty and perhaps no chance at all of obtaining such a position. [47] The incomes of both parties have increased since the Agreement was signed but that too was a foreseeable event. I do not consider the increased appraised value of the Respondent’s real estate to be a reason to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties’ Agreement. [54] In conclusion, the current circumstances of the parties are not a “significant departure from the range of reasonable outcomes anticipated by the parties” when they signed their Agreement. The application is dismissed.
column12: Two years after the divorce, the wife applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the parties' Corollary Relief Judgment, which incorporated the terms of Minutes of Settlement. Pursuant to the Corollary Relief judgment, the husband was currently paying the wife $4,350 per month as spousal support. The wife now wished to increase the monthly support to a figure which would more closely resemble that assessed pursuant to the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines, along with a substantial lump sum to compensate her for the underpayment of spousal support for the past two years. She also sought removal of a clause which provided for the discontinuation of support if the husband's professional income dropped below $80,000. The parties had been married for approximately thirty years and had one child, who was now independent. Application dismissed; the parties' current circumstances did not constitute a significant departure from the range of reasonable outcomes anticipated by the parties when the Agreement was signed. Both parties' income had increased since the divorce and the wife was not deeply in debt, as she alleged; there was no pressure exerted and no oppression during the course of negotiations; the Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines are not law and allow for exceptions to the general formulas provided, one such exception being the assumption of debt by one of the parties (the husband in this case); the spousal support figure recognized the husband's reasonable expectation of retirement and the fact that he was experiencing health problems; it was completely foreseeable at the time that the Agreement was signed that, given the wife's age, she might experience difficulty in finding employment in her narrow field; the subsequent increased value of one of the husband's properties was not a reason to vary the spousal support provisions of the Agreement.

column18: The parties were married for over 29 years prior to their separation. At the time of their separation, the parties were granted a Corollary Relief Judgment, which incorporated the terms of an agreement signed by the parties. The parties separated in May 2001 when the Respondent moved from the matrimonial home and they were divorced in February 2003. The Respondent applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the Agreement. The applicant argued that the Agreement was sound when it was signed, that there had been no material change in the circumstances of either party, and that the respondent did not take advantage of any vulnerability of the applicant as contemplated by the Supreme Court in Miglin (supra). HELD: 1)The Agreement was not in substantial compliance with the objectives of the Divorce Act. 2)It was not necessary for the court to determine the agreement was unconscionable. Rather, the court is to look at the circumstances in which the parties negotiated and executed to determine whether there was any reason to discount it. The onus is on the applicant to satisfy the Court that the agreement is not unconscionsable. 3)The parties had been married for more than 29 years. Although the parties lived in the same home for over four years, they were engaged for over two years. The husband worked long hours and weekends to earn extra money because of the significant legal costs that he incurred in relation to the divorce. He also had a substantial debt to pay down. 4)Although the parties' divorce settlement had left them deeply in debt, the agreement reached in January 2003 did not conform with the objective of the Act. The respondent was left essentially debt free while the applicant was assuming debts in excess of $300,000. 5)Spousal Support Advisory Guidelines allow for exceptions to general formulas provided in the guidelines. The exceptions listed are not intended to be an exhaustive list and each case must be decided on its own facts. The court should be willing to give some deference to the terms that the parties chose.  6)The agreement was not only justified but required. There was no pressure exerted upon the applicant and no oppression during the course of the negotiations or the signing of the agreement and it was completely foreseeable that she would have difficulty and perhaps no chance at all of obtaining such a position.

column23: The applicant applied to vary the spousal support provisions of the Corollary Relief Judgment dated February 20th, 2003. Although the parties were married for over 29 years prior to their separation, the parties had been married for some time prior to the separation. The parties had received an agreement signed in January 2003 which incorporated the terms of the parties' settlement of the property division issue. The applicant argued that the Agreement did not conform with the objectives of the Act and that there had been no material change in the circumstances of either party since it was signed. HELD: The application was dismissed. The court found that there was no pressure exerted upon the applicant and no oppression during the course of the negotiations or the signing of the Agreement and that the respondent did not take advantage of any vulnerability of the applicant as contemplated by the Supreme Court in Miglin (supra). 1)Although the parties lived in the same household for over 30 years, there had not been a significant change in circumstances since the parties’ separation. 2)The parties had a reasonable expectation of retirement. 3)The Agreement was sound when signed and met the requirements, objectives and spirit of all applicable legislation and legal principles. 4)It was not necessary for the court to determine the agreement was unconscionable. Rather, the court is to look at all of the evidence and determine whether one party took advantage of the vulnerability of another party in the negotiations. 5)The agreement was based on a common understanding of the economic and social consequences of separation and was not intended to be an exhaustive list and each case must be decided on its own facts.

column2: A single vehicle accident occurred when the driver swerved to avoid hitting a dog that ran onto the highway. An action was brought against both the driver and the farmer who owned the land on both sides of the highway on the basis that the farmer owned the dog in question and was negligent in failing to keep it off the highway. The farmer contended that although he owned a dog, it was tied to a tree at the time and his was not the dog that had run onto the highway. When his application for summary judgment was dismissed, the farmer appealed. Appeal dismissed. At this stage of the proceedings, it was not necessary for the plaintiffs to prove that the defendant's dog contributed to the accident or the truth of the statements and evidence attached to the affidavit. It was only necessary to show that the facts were contested, there was some evidence to support their version of events and, if their evidence was accepted by the trier of fact, their action had some merit. Although the judge appeared to blur the two parts of the test on a summary judgment application, the Court found that the farmer failed to meet the first part of the test; namely, that there was no genuine issue of fact for trial as there was conflicting evidence as to the identity of the dog involved.
column3: The defendant was charged with negligent driving and failing to stop his vehicle. The plaintiffs brought an action against the defendant and his sister, who were killed. The defendant claimed that he swerved to avoid hitting a dog that ran onto the highway in front of him. The defendants brought an application for summary judgment on the basis that the defendant had failed to establish that he owned the dog. The chambers judge admitted and relied on the affidavit of the defendant. The plaintiff appealed. Allowing the appeal and dismissing the appeal, that the chambers judge erred in applying the test for summary judgement. The application for dismissal was dismissed. The court found that the applicant met the burden placed upon him in step one of the two step test and that the plaintiffs met the onus on them in the second part of the test.
column4: Held: Leave to appeal is granted and the appeal is dismissed with costs, per reasons for judgment of Roscoe, J.A.; [1] This is an application for leave to appeal and, if granted, an appeal from an order of Justice Glen G. McDougall dismissing a summary judgment application brought by the defendant, Theodore Hogeterp. [2] On April 18, 1996 a car driven by 16 year old Andrew Larkin veered off the road and struck a power pole on Route 359, Centerville, Nova Scotia. The driver said that he swerved to avoid hitting a dog that ran onto the highway in front of the car. They also named Theodore Hogeterp as a defendant. Mr. Hogeterp was a farmer who owned land on both sides of the road at the site of the accident. The application for summary judgment is therefore dismissed. The order of the chambers judge should be confirmed, although for different reasons. [41] I would grant leave to appeal but dismiss the appeal.

It was unnecessary to consider the second step.

The application was brought pursuant to Rule 62.11(a) of the Judicature Act and Rule 13.01(a). The application for summary judgment was dismissed.

column2: The plaintiff bus driver was in a serious bus/motor vehicle accident that killed two people. He was charged with dangerous driving. His employer offered the services of its lawyer, who eventually transferred the file to the defendant who represented him at trial. At trial, the Crown introduced a video of a purported accident re-enactment. The defendant chose not to object to its admission, saying he felt it was a perfect example of the Crown's 'doomed to failure' theory. As for the problems (it was recorded in the daytime, while the accident happened at daybreak; it assumed the vehicle that was struck was stopped, although there was no proof it was; and it didn't show all of the vehicles at the original scene), he felt these could be addressed by cross-examination. The plaintiff was convicted. He retained a different lawyer to represent him on appeal, and won. Eventually, the charges were dropped. The lawyer's competence was not raised as an issue on appeal. In their decision, the Court of Appeal criticized him for not objecting to the admission of the video and other evidence. They found this evidence was inadmissible, highly prejudicial and should never have been put to the jury. The plaintiff sued in negligence and breach of contract. The parties introduced conflicting opinions from criminal law experts to support their respective positions. Action dismissed. The standard of care is that of a reasonably competent lawyer. Lawyers make strategic decisions and exercise judgment, but are not responsible to ensure a certain result. Sometimes the decisions are wrong: it is only negligence if it was outside the realm of acceptable possibilities in the circumstances of the case. The appeal panel had the benefit of hindsight - it is improper to judge the plaintiff's actions in light of their conclusions. While the experts were not helpful in establishing what a reasonably competent lawyer (as opposed to a specialist in the field) would do, their differing opinions illustrate how the admissibility of evidence can be the subject of much debate.
column3: The plaintiff was charged with dangerous driving causing death. Following the laying of criminal charges, the plaintiff's employer suspended him from work without pay. The plaintiff offered to use his legal counsel to defend him in relation to the criminal charges. The defendant refused and the plaintiff brought an expert's report. The expert's evidence was so favourable that it was not necessary to object to the admission of the still photographs. The court found that the expert's opinion was so accurate as to be of no relevance to the plaintiff’s case that it should have been admitted into evidence. The Court found that while the video re-enactment was a very good example of how the accident could have gone, it was also not a very convincing example of the Crown’ s flawed theory. The video evidence was not admissible and the court found the expert’d opinion was not supported by the evidence.

HELD: The court found that the court erred when he failed to strike the offending evidence, and in allowing into evidence the opinion of the RCMP Traffic Analyst when there was an insufficient factual basis established for his opinion. column2: A class action was certificated at Queen's Bench on the basis of breaches of The Consumer Protection Act and a breach of duty of care. The defendants were granted leave from the Court of Appeal to appeal the portion of the certification order dealing with alleged breaches of The Consumer Protection Act only. The certification on the basis of duty of care was upheld. As a result, a situation existed where the class action process could continue on only part of the claim until the appeal of consumer protection act issues was heard. HELD: Rule 15 of The Court of Appeal Rules is engaged and the entire certification judgment is stayed pending the disposition of the appeal. If the plaintiffs wish to apply to lift the stay they must do so to a judge of the Court of Appeal.
column3: FIAT: By order and judgment dated March 29, 2010, the Court certified the within action as a class action. The defendants were granted leave to appeal only that portion of the certification order that pertained to the cause of action relating to alleged breaches of the Consumer Protection Act, S.S. 1996, c.30.1 (the CPA) and all other aspects of the leave to appeals application were dismissed. The Court of Appeal did not have the authority to lift the stay. HELD: The class action was certified as a Class Action. The court granted the defendants leave to proceed with the remaining portion of their leave to apply. Steps can now be taken to move this action forward concurrently with the appeal. Steps should be taken in the context of the breach of duty of care cause of actions.

column2: The accused was charged with impaired care and control of a motor vehicle and care and control of a motor vehicle while his blood alcohol level exceeded .08. The accused was found in the driver's side of a vehicle with his legs near the pedals. His body was slumped over into the passenger side. The vehicle had collided with a power pole and sustained significant damage. The engine was running when the police arrived. There was no one else in the vehicle. The accused was transported to hospital where the doctor suspected he had a brain bleed and recommended the police obtain a blood warrant. The officer who swore the Information to Obtain the warrant indicated that the interior of the vehicle smelled strongly of beverage alcohol and the accused smelled of beverage alcohol. The Justice of the Peace did not sign the Information to Obtain. The issues before the Court were whether there had been a breach of the accused's s. 8 right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure and whether the Crown had proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused was in care and control of the motor vehicle. HELD: The blood warrant was found to be invalid, meaning that the blood samples were obtained as part of a warrantless search in breach of s. 8. The Information to Obtain the blood warrant did not depose that the officer believed the accused was the driver of the vehicle which had crashed into the power pole or that the accused was in care and control of the motor vehicle. The officer should have included information about the accused's position in the vehicle and that the accused was unconscious. Without this information, the Information to Obtain did not contain reasonable grounds to believe that the accused had committed an offence under s. 253 of the Criminal Code. However, the blood sample evidence was admitted after a s. 24(2) analysis. The Court held that the officer was acting in good faith and that he honestly held the belief that the accused was drinking and driving when he swore the Information to Obtain. The impact on the accused was technical in nature and did not seriously undermine the accused's rights. The Court held that the truth seeking function of the trial process would be better served by admission of the Certificate of Analysis. The Court found that the accused was in care and control of the motor vehicle at the time of the collision. There was no evidence that anyone else was in the vehicle and the position of the accused when discovered suggested he had been driving the vehicle. The accused was found guilty of driving while his blood alcohol level exceeded .08. The Court held that his blood alcohol level was between 236 mgs% and 283 mgs%.
column3: HELD: The Court held that the information to obtain blood samples was not sufficient grounds to warrant a search. The Court found that the warrant to search for blood was invalid and that the Certificate of Analyst and the report from the analyst were not sufficient reasons to warrant the warrant. The officer who swore the information was not fatal to the warrant and the warrant was invalid. The court held that it was a breach of the accused's s. 8 rights under s. 7 of the Charter respecting the violation of the officer's s8 rights. The Certificate of Analysis was not necessary to warrant an application to search the blood of an accused. The information was obtained by the officer who testified during the voir dire and was not part of the warrant application. The certificate of analyst was not required to provide his reasonable grounds for belief. The evidence was not obtained by mistake. The warrant to be searched was invalid because the information contained in the information did not constitute reasonable grounds to the belief that the accused had committed an offence under s253. The Warrant to Search for Blood was invalid as the Certificate was not provided by the police officer. The affidavit was not prepared by the accused to be amplified on the evidence. The accused did not depose that he believed that the driver of any motor vehicle, let alone the driver, was the sole occupant of the vehicle, was unconscious with his feet located in the driver's leg/foot area of the car and his body slumped across the passenger's seat. The Crown did not provide sufficient detail in the Information to Obtain to permit the Justice of the Peace to determine that reasonable grounds existed for the warrant issue. The Information to Otain was a technical error and was therefore not fatal. The Order to Search For Blood was issued pursuant to s. 24(2) of the charter respecting the breach of s.8 rights of the person. The order to search was made pursuant to R. v. Garofoli (1993). The Court reviewed the whole of the material presented and determined that the certificate of analysis and the analyst dated April 2010, should be admitted into evidence at trial. The application to be taken under s24(2 of the Code was dismissed. The Act to Obtained was amended to include the Certificate and the Report dated April 2011. The provisions of the Act to Obey and the Charter were not amended. The Executive Summary of the Information was not amended nor was the Warrant to search For Blood invalid.
column4:
[1] A trial took place before me regarding Curtis Russell Francis who is charged that on or about the 10th day of January A.D. 2009, at or near Regina, Saskatchewan, he did:

1. While his ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or drug operate a motor vehicle contrary to sections 255(1) and 253(1)(a) of the Criminal Code. I found that it did not and as a result there was a breach of the accused’s rights under s. 8 of the Charter to be free from unreasonable search and seizure. I then conducted an analysis pursuant to s. 24(2) of the Charter respecting the violation of the accused’s s. 8 rights. I determined that the Certificate of Analyst and the report from the analyst dated April 20, 2010, should be admitted into evidence at trial. He did not depose that he believed that Mr. Francis was the driver of any motor vehicle, let alone the driver of the Tempo motor vehicle which was registered in his name and which crashed into a light standard around 1:19 a.m. on January 10, 2009. [35] I am of the view that the information which Constable Strueby deposed in the Information to Obtain, when reviewed as a whole, did not constitute reasonable grounds for the belief that the accused had committed an offence under s. 253. Accordingly, I hold that the Warrant to Search for Blood was invalid. [53] While I have found that the blood warrant was invalid and that the seizure of blood samples from Mr. Francis breached his s. 8 right to be secure against unreasonable search or seizure, I am of the view that Constable Strueby was nonetheless acting in good faith when he obtained blood samples from Mr. Francis. While I have found the Information to Obtain in support of the blood warrant deficient, I am confident that Constable Strueby honestly held the belief that Mr. Francis was drinking and driving and was acting in good faith throughout the early morning of January 10, 2009. [56] With respect to this avenue of inquiry, I am of the view that the breach of Mr. Francis’ s. 8 Charter right was done in good faith and did not seriously undermine the interests protected by the accused. [70] The issue at trial is whether the Crown has proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused, Curtis Francis was the driver of the Tempo motor vehicle or alternatively was in care and control of the motor vehicle. [71] I am of the view that the Crown has proved beyond a reasonable doubt that Curtis Francis was the driver of the Tempo vehicle which collided with the power pole on 6th Avenue at 1:19 a.m. on January 10, 2009. However, when their evidence is examined as a whole I am sure that Mr. Francis was driving his Tempo vehicle when it collided with the power pole. [78] As I have determined that the accused was the operator of a motor vehicle at 1:19 a.m. on January 10, 2009, with a blood alcohol concentration of between 236 mg% and 283 mg%, I find him to be guilty of count number two.

column27: HELD: The Court held that the information to obtain blood samples was not sufficient grounds to warrant a search. The Court found that the warrant to search for blood was invalid and that the Certificate of Analyst and the report from the analyst were not sufficient reasons to warrant the warrant. The officer who swore the information was not fatal to the warrant and the warrant was invalid. The court held that it was a breach of the accused's s. 8 rights under s. 7 of the Charter respecting the violation of the officer's s8 rights. The Certificate of Analysis was not necessary to warrant an application to search the blood of an accused. The information was obtained by the officer who testified during the voir dire and was not part of the warrant application. The certificate of analyst was not required to provide his reasonable grounds for belief. The evidence was not obtained by mistake. The warrant to be searched was invalid because the information contained in the information did not constitute reasonable grounds to the belief that the accused had committed an offence under s253. The Warrant to Search for Blood was invalid as the Certificate was not provided by the police officer. The affidavit was not prepared by the accused to be amplified on the evidence. The accused did not depose that he believed that the driver of any motor vehicle, let alone the driver, was the sole occupant of the vehicle, was unconscious with his feet located in the driver's leg/foot area of the car and his body slumped across the passenger's seat. The Crown did not provide sufficient detail in the Information to Obtain to permit the Justice of the Peace to determine that reasonable grounds existed for the warrant issue. The Information to Otain was a technical error and was therefore not fatal. The Order to Search For Blood was issued pursuant to s. 24(2) of the charter respecting the breach of s.8 rights of the person. The order to search was made pursuant to R. v. Garofoli (1993). The Court reviewed the whole of the material presented and determined that the certificate of analysis and the analyst dated April 2010, should be admitted into evidence at trial. The application to be taken under s24(2 of the Code was dismissed. The Act to Obtained was amended to include the Certificate and the Report dated April 2011. The provisions of the Act to Obey and the Charter were not amended. The Executive Summary of the Information was not amended nor was the Warrant to search For Blood invalid.

column2: HELD: The court found that both parties were significantly involved in the day-to-day parenting of the children such that a conclusion that one parent or the other was the primary caregiver could not be made. The court also found that the respondent responded positively and appropriately to the petitioner’s concerns regarding masturbation and pornography. The respondent indicated that he had not watched pornography since December 2014 and that software on his cell phone and computer provide assurances that he had not watched pornography to the petitioner. The petitioner did not dispute that evidence. The court could not reasonably give weight to the petitioner’s opinion evidence regarding the respondent’s alleged addictions. The court listed numerous problems with the petitioner’s evidence of addiction. The court was unable to conclude that there was a risk of harm to the children caused by the respondent. With respect to the petitioner’s allegation of the respondent’s anger management problem, most of the incidents were dated. The respondent had since taken anger management counselling, accepted that he suffers from ADD, and began taking medication for ADD. The court held that it was in the best interests of the children to continue to reside in the family home and that it would not be in their best interests for one parent to be classified as or be the primary parent. It was also in the children’s best interests that their parenting be shared on an equal basis. A nesting arrangement was found to be in the best interests of the children. The court ordered that the parties would have joint custody of the children and each party had exclusive possession of the family home when they were enjoying their assigned periods of parenting. The parents would alternate weeks living in the family home with the children.
column3: FIAT: The applicant seeks orders granting her exclusive possession of the family home, primary residence of the children and supervised access only for the respondent father. HELD: The application is dismissed. The court cannot conclude that there is a risk of harm. The evidence before the court is that the respondent has anger management problems that make him and his daughters fearful of him and addictions to pornography and masturbation that make it impossible for them to continue to reside in the same home. The respondent has in response filed a detailed affidavit in which he disputes the allegations of addictions, pornography and masturbation and asks the court to accept this as proven. The petitioner swears as fact that the father is addicted to pornography. It was his position that if a parenting plan and agreement were reached that this would protect the children from both his anger and the risks associated with his sexual abuse. The harm test is not accepted. The Court must consider all of the evidence before it can conclude that a risk exists.
column4: [1] The petitioner’s application seeks orders granting her exclusive possession of the family home, primary residence of the children and supervised access only for the respondent father. He seeks to have the exclusive possession order terminated and an order providing for shared parenting of the children. Rather it is opinion evidence that she is not entitled to give and to which I cannot reasonably give weight. After considering all of the evidence I am unable to conclude there is a risk of harm. I conclude that the petitioner’s stated concerns of fear of the respondent to such a degree that he should be excluded from the family home or that put the children at risk of harm are not supported by the evidence and are unreasonable. [46] Based upon their respective past parenting activities I am satisfied that it would not be in the children’s best interests for one parent to be classified as or be the primary parent. The principle of maximum contact is particularly applicable and workable in the circumstances of this case and I am satisfied that it is, at this time and in the present circumstances, in the best interests of the children that their parenting be shared on an equal basis. [49] In the circumstances I have concluded that on an interim basis the best interests of the children are best served by a parenting regime sometimes called a nesting arrangement. Conclusion [52] I order as follows: a. The without notice order of August 18 granting the petitioner exclusive possession of the family home is terminated effective as of the time that so ordered in open court on September 2, 2016; b. The parties shall have joint custody of the children [name of child stated] and [name of child stated];

column13: FIAT: The applicant seeks orders granting her exclusive possession of the family home, primary residence of the children and supervised access only for the respondent father. HELD: The application is dismissed. The court cannot conclude that there is a risk of harm to the children. 1) The respondent has anger management problems that make him and his daughters fearful of him and addictions to pornography and masturbation that make it not in the children's best interests to continue to reside in the same home. 2) The petitioner has provided factual evidence as background to her opinion. Much of it is expressly disputed by the respondent or to the extent allegations are acknowledged by the petitioner to have some factual basis, that evidence relates to significantly dated matters. The problems with the petitioner's evidence of addiction are multiple and include: 1) It is not credible or reasonable to conclude that the respondent has an addiction to pornography or masturbation that makes it impossible for him to put the children to bed. The respondent's anger management issues have made it untenable for them to continue their relationship with him. The evidence from the petitioner herself supports this conclusion. It is also not reasonable to infer that he is the only person who can reasonably be considered a parent of a child who is prone to anxiety, depression, anger management, anxiety, and other problems. The petitioner is not entitled to have her opinion evidence rebutted by the Court of Appeal. She is not a psychologist or psychiatrist and has demonstrated no qualifications to make a diagnosis of the respondent's so-called addictions. She has no evidence that she has ever seen him masturbate in the presence of her children. She does not have any evidence that he has ever masturbated under a blanket while sitting on the couch watching sports or movies with the girls. The Court has no reason to believe that this is an appropriate way to deal with the risk involved with unsupervised access.  2) There is no evidence to support the petitioner’s allegations of sexual abuse or that there was any improper behaviour on the part of either parent. The facts do not support the conclusion that the child is at a risk to harm. 3) The evidence that the petitioner has given factual evidence is not supported by the evidence. It was opinion evidence that was not given and to which I cannot reasonably give weight. 4) The court must err on the side of caution, whether or not proper evidentiary foundation has been established, is not accepted.
column14: [1] The petitioner’s application seeks orders granting her exclusive possession of the family home, primary residence of the children and supervised access only for the respondent father. He seeks to have the exclusive possession order terminated and an order providing for shared parenting of the children. Rather it is opinion evidence that she is not entitled to give and to which I cannot reasonably give weight. After considering all of the evidence I am unable to conclude there is a risk of harm. I conclude that the petitioner’s stated concerns of fear of the respondent to such a degree that he should be excluded from the family home or that put the children at risk of harm are not supported by the evidence and are unreasonable. [46] Based upon their respective past parenting activities I am satisfied that it would not be in the children’s best interests for one parent to be classified as or be the primary parent. The principle of maximum contact is particularly applicable and workable in the circumstances of this case and I am satisfied that it is, at this time and in the present circumstances, in the best interests of the children that their parenting be shared on an equal basis. [49] In the circumstances I have concluded that on an interim basis the best interests of the children are best served by a parenting regime sometimes called a nesting arrangement. Conclusion [52] I order as follows: a. The without notice order of August 18 granting the petitioner exclusive possession of the family home is terminated effective as of the time that so ordered in open court on September 2, 2016; b. The parties shall have joint custody of the children [name of child stated] and [name of child stated];
column17: HELD: The court found that both parties were significantly involved in the day-to-day parenting of the children such that a conclusion that one parent or the other was the primary caregiver could not be made. The court also found that the respondent responded positively and appropriately to the petitioner’s concerns regarding masturbation and pornography. The respondent indicated that he had not watched pornography since December 2014 and that software on his cell phone and computer provide assurances that he had not watched pornography to the petitioner. The petitioner did not dispute that evidence. The court could not reasonably give weight to the petitioner’s opinion evidence regarding the respondent’s alleged addictions. The court listed numerous problems with the petitioner’s evidence of addiction. The court was unable to conclude that there was a risk of harm to the children caused by the respondent. With respect to the petitioner’s allegation of the respondent’s anger management problem, most of the incidents were dated. The respondent had since taken anger management counselling, accepted that he suffers from ADD, and began taking medication for ADD. The court held that it was in the best interests of the children to continue to reside in the family home and that it would not be in their best interests for one parent to be classified as or be the primary parent. It was also in the children’s best interests that their parenting be shared on an equal basis. A nesting arrangement was found to be in the best interests of the children. The court ordered that the parties would have joint custody of the children and each party had exclusive possession of the family home when they were enjoying their assigned periods of parenting. The parents would alternate weeks living in the family home with the children.

column2: This was an appeal of a decision which denied variation of a maintenance award where a lump sum had been previously ordered. The judge determined that since the respondent had paid the lump sum, his obligations were terminated; therefore, the Family Court did not have jurisdiction to hear the application. Allowing the appeal and returning the matter to the Family Court, that orders for child support made under the Family Maintenance Act do not have the finality which they did under other previous legislation. The order is always subject to variation in appropriate circumstances. Accordingly, the Family Court has jurisdiction to vary awards of lump sum child support made pursuant to the Family Maintenance Act.
column3: This was an appeal from a decision of a Family Court Judge. The order required the respondent to pay lying-in expenses in the amount of $209 and periodic payments for the support of the child in the alternative lump sum payment of $7,500. The respondent elected to make the lump sum payments on or about the 2nd of October 1985. The appellant made an application for variation of the order pursuant to s. 37 of the Family Maintenance Act. The court held a pre-trial conference at which the respondent raised a jurisdictional question, arguing that the payment of the lump sums in 1985 fully and finally discharged his responsibility for child support. The matter was adjourned with the direction from Judge Levy. The applicant appealed. Appeal allowed.
column4: Judge Levy held a pre‑trial conference, at which time the respondent raised a jurisdictional question, arguing that the payment of the lump sum in 1985 fully and finally discharged his responsibility for child support. For all the foregoing reasons, the appeal succeeds and I direct that the matter be sent back to Judge Levy for a hearing on the merits.

At issue was whether an order for lump sum payment under the Children of Unmarried Parents Act, R.S.N.S., 1967, c.32, made shortly after the boy's birth was subject to variation. It was possible to arrive at the conclusion merely by considering the scheme of the Act and the order made by Judge MacDonald. However any lingering doubt is removed by s.34, which states with finality that 'this Part', the part dealing with the father's civil liability to pay maintenance, to which the Family Maintenance Act is the successor legislation, is the operative portion of the order.

column2: The Mother applied to vary the custody provisions of the decree nisis for divorce which provided for joint custody of the parties' 2 children, aged 11 and 9 years. Under the existing order the children's primary residence was with their Father. A custody investigation conducted in 1990 when the mother had first commenced this application had recommended that the existing arrangement be continued. The Father now intended, however, to move with the children to Ontario to take additional education. HELD: Application dismissed. 1)The Judge found that the move to Ontario was a sufficient change of circumstances to permit a variation application to proceed. She therefore proceeded to consider if the move was in the best interests of the children. 2)The Judge reviewed recent authorities from across Canada dealing with whether a custodial parent should be permitted to move with the children. 3)In the circumstances of this case the Judge was convinced that the move was reasonable and was not motivated by any desire on the part of the Father to thwart the Mother's access.
column3: The parties separated in December 1988. They entered into a separation agreement in which they agreed to joint custody, residence with the father and generous access to the mother. The mother sought to have the custody of the children transferred to the father, who was no longer employed. The father applied to vary the judgment by granting the mother sole custody of both the boys and joint custody with principal residence with him. The parties moved from Ontario to Saskatchewan in 1990. The petitioner mother applied for change in the divorce judgment by giving the mother joint custody of all the boys with the access to her. The court granted the mother interim interim custody and granted joint custody to the parties. The respondent applied to have custody transferred to his daughter, who wished to move out of Saskatchewan and to the province. The applicant mother opposed the move. The evidence showed that the father had been able to provide generous access and the mother had been granted generous access. The Court of Appeal reversed the previous order and reinstated the interim custody order.
column4:
This is an application by Twila Faye Brothwell
(mother) for an order varying the judgment of Dickson J. of the
5th of January 1990, in which he gave judgment for divorce and
joint custody to the parents of two boys Matthew, born April 22,
1984 and Luke, born June 3, 1986. The affidavit material filed on this application
shows that the father has informed the mother that he is moving
to Aurora, Ontario, at the beginning of July, 1995 and intends to
enroll in a course at the dental college in Toronto, which will
enable him to teach Public Health Dentistry. issue. I did not form the opinion that his move was to thwart
his ex-wife's access, since there does not seem to be any dispute
about this since 1990, and indeed friends and neighbours from
MacRorie filed affidavits stating how much the boys enjoyed their
visits with their mother and how they fitted in with the people
of that town and environs, and he has, in addition offered
generous access. Because of the reasons given above: father being
the long-time custodial parent, the reasons for the proposed
move, the generous access offered I dismiss the application of
the mother.

column8: An application for an order varying the judgment of Dickson J. of the 5th of January 1990 in which he gave judgment for divorce and joint custody to the parents of two boys. The parties had separated in 1988 and had entered into a separation agreement in which they agreed to joint custody, residence with the father and generous access to the mother. The petitioner mother applied for change in the divorce judgment by granting mother sole custody of the boys, or joint custody with principal residence with mother. HELD: The application was granted. 1)The Court of Appeal reversed the previous decision and reinstated the previous one. 2)The court found that the best interests of the children lie with the custodial parent. 3)The evidence showed that the father had been able to provide support and care to the children for the past five years. 4)The father was able to access the children from his home in Melfort. 5)The mother had been granted generous access. The father was to pay for the cost of flying the boys to Saskatchewan and return for all the access except the Easter and mid-term break.

HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)There was no evidence of a change in the circumstances of the children. 2)The father was entitled to reasonable access. 3)The mother's wish to move to Canada was bona fide and not motivated by a wish to thwart the father's access. 4)The parties had been married for 10 years and had two children. The father had lived in the home of the mother for the past 10 years. The children had spent their entire life in Melfort and had always been with her. She had moved from Regina to Aurora in 1990 and had recently moved with her husband to a new community. She was seeking better employment and housing. 5)The decision of the Court of Appeal to grant joint custody was made with the mother's consent.

HELD: The application was allowed. 1)The court found that the best interests of the children lie with the mother's being with the custodial parent. 2)The mother's wish to move to Canada was bona fide and not motivated by a wish to thwart the father's access. 3)The evidence showed that the father had, together of course, with his present wife, the day to day care of the four children from their early years onward except when they were exercising the access. 4)The father's move was to thwart his ex-wife's access since there does not seem to be any dispute about this since 1990, and indeed friends and neighbours from the area filed affidavits stating how much the boys enjoyed their visits with their mother and how they fitted in with the people of that town and environs.
column24:
This is an application by Twila Faye Brothwell
(mother) for an order varying the judgment of Dickson J. of the
5th of January 1990, in which he gave judgment for divorce and
joint custody to the parents of two boys Matthew, born April 22,
1984 and Luke, born June 3, 1986. The affidavit material filed on this application
shows that the father has informed the mother that he is moving
to Aurora, Ontario, at the beginning of July, 1995 and intends to
enroll in a course at the dental college in Toronto, which will
enable him to teach Public Health Dentistry. issue. I did not form the opinion that his move was to thwart
his ex-wife's access, since there does not seem to be any dispute
about this since 1990, and indeed friends and neighbours from
MacRorie filed affidavits stating how much the boys enjoyed their
visits with their mother and how they fitted in with the people
of that town and environs, and he has, in addition offered
generous access. Because of the reasons given above: father being
the long-time custodial parent, the reasons for the proposed
move, the generous access offered I dismiss the application of
the mother.

column2: FIAT. The mother sought to have the ongoing child support of $180 per month per child for the three children of the marriage increased. The last three income tax returns of the father indicated an average gross income of $28,000 after adjustments. His net worth had increased substantially since the original order in 1993 from a net worth of $105,744 after deducting debts of $352,655 to $484,684 after deducting debts of $342,000. He purchased stock totalling $202,061 in 1996 using income generated from the farm. He claimed he could not work full time in the oil field because he was involved in a bison operation. HELD: The respondent was to pay monthly child support of $957 for as long as the children remained children as defined by the Divorce Act. It was appropriate to impute income of $56,000 as the respondent's assets were not being reasonably utilized to generate income.
column3: FIAT. The applicant mother sought to have ongoing child support of $180 per month per child for three children of the marriage increased. The respondent father filed his last three income tax returns. The returns indicate that he had an average gross taxable income of $28,000. However, the file also indicates that his net worth has increased substantially since the original order in 1993. HELD: The respondent's assets were not being reasonably utilized to generate income. In the circumstances it was appropriate for me to impute income to the respondent. The father's gross annual income imputed at $56,000 and the amount of $957.00 for the support of the three children born in 1997 as long as the children remained children of their marriage under the Divorce Act. There will be no order as to costs.
