She completed a Consumer Proposal being advised that it would discharge these loans, only to find out that it did not. She sought advice from a debt counsellor provided by the provincial government, having had judgment entered against her. She followed this advice with proposal, which was fully performed in 2005 but then she learned it was ineffective against the student loans. That year she married. Now she has two children. HELD: This application was granted. 1)If I could compromise the debt, I would have no difficulty in requiring her to pay a significant portion of the debt (say half of it), which would be a continuation of financial difficulty which has prevented her from paying the loans. Any period longer would be too long. It would protract the burden of these loans in a manner inconsistent with the overall objectives of the BIA. 2)It would be normal for someone in Ms. Field-Currie's circumstances to be required to pay surplus income for fifteen months. This would require total payments of $12,000 and 21 months. Any reasonable repayment scheme that is not going to prejudice the reasonably frugal lifestyle they have could well take another 10 years. To expect them to pay in a shorter period say five years would be an extension of the financial difficulty that has prevented them from paying these loans. 3)It gives me two options, one to refuse relief, the other to discharge in its entirety. There is no middle ground.
column19: Subject: The Bankrupt, who had outstanding student loans of about $39,000 applied for relief under Subsection 178(1.1) of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act. Held: To discharge the loans would require several years on top of the already 13 years she has been burdened with them. [1] This is an application by Catherine Field-Currie for an order under Subsection 178(1.1) of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. B-3 (BIA) directing that Paragraph 178 (1)(g) does not apply to her outstanding student loans [9] I am satisfied that Ms. Field-Currie has acted with good faith. To expect them to pay in a shorter period say five years would be a continuation of financial difficulty which has prevented her from paying the loans. [13] If I could compromise the debt, I would have no difficulty in requiring her to pay a significant portion of the debt, say half of it.
column22: The bankrupt, who had outstanding student loans of approximately $39,000, applied for relief under s. 178(1.1) of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act. She had completed her studies to become a teacher 13 years ago and had erroneously been advised that a consumer proposal would discharge these loans. Although both she and her husband had good incomes, it would still take several more years to discharge the loans without prejudicing her family's reasonably frugal lifestyle. Relief granted; to require the bankrupt to discharge the loans in a reasonable manner would require an additional 10 or more years on top of the 13 years with which she had already been burdened, and to expect her to pay in a shorter period would cause her continuing financial difficulties. The bankrupt had acted in good faith and had been unable to service the loans in the early years when she did not have permanent employment. Compromising the debt and requiring her to only pay half of it was not an available option.

column2: The accused was charged with numerous weapons-related offences, including possession and trafficking. The police had intercepted numerous ambiguous calls between the accused and others and had interpreted the coded language used as involving discussions about firearms. The defence had been unsuccessful in arguing that the inferences drawn were mere hunches and the conversations could not support a reasonable inference that the subjects under discussion were firearms. A search at his parents' residence had resulted in the seizure of several firearms but none were found in the accused's actual possession. One of the issues was whether the accused had constructive or joint possession of the firearms seized from his parents. Accused found guilty on all the weapons' possession charges and some of the trafficking charges, but not guilty of careless storage of a firearm. It was clear that the accused had much more than a passive or quiescent knowledge of the guns seized from his parents' home and there were a number of indicators that he had a measure of control over them, such as his telling his father on occasion to get rid of them, his being notified immediately when one of the firearms went missing, the way he pressed his parents to explain how that could happen and his ability on other occasions to tell his father where in the home a particular firearm was located. However, despite his knowledge of the location of some of the firearms at certain times, the court was unable to find that the accused had stored the firearms in the manner they were found when the search warrant was executed. The evidence also established that he was stashing guns at locations other than his residence and he possessed those guns for the purpose of transferring them to others. The only reasonable inference to be drawn from the intercepts was that the speakers were talking about guns and the communications revealed the commercial nature of the accused's activities. Given that the accused had asserted a privacy interest with respect to an application to exclude the evidence arising from the police search of the cell phone seized from him, he could not now deny that the phone was his.
column3: HELD: The Court found that the accused was guilty of possession of a prohibited firearm and that the evidence supporting the accused's claim was circumstantial. The Court held that the Crown had not proven the accused guilty of the firearms possession charges. The accused was charged with trafficking firearms. The evidence supporting his claim was that the firearms were not the accused’s. The court found that evidence supporting this claim was not available at the time of the trial. The Crown had provided notice of its intention to seek this amendment at the start of the defence’ s trial.
column4: Also as a result of the Part VI authorized intercepts, on April 29, 2009, Kyle Cater was charged with trafficking firearms. They are: the unlawful storage of a sawed off Cooey 84 shotgun, a Lakefield Mark II rifle, and an AA Arms Model AP 9 handgun, and ammunition, in a careless manner (contrary to Criminal Code section 86(1) x 3), unlawful possession of the sawed off Cooey 84 shotgun, the Lakefield Mark II rifle and the AA Arms Model AP 9 handgun (contrary to Criminal Code section 88(1) x 3), unlawful possession of a loaded prohibited weapon – the AA Arms Model AP 9 handgun, and unlawful possession of a loaded prohibited firearm – the sawed off Cooey 84 shotgun (contrary to Criminal Code section 95(1) x 2), unlawful possession of the sawed off Cooey and the AP 9 handgun, knowing that possession is unauthorized (contrary to Criminal Code section 92(1) x 2), and unlawful possession of two over capacity magazines, a prohibited device (contrary to Criminal Code section 92(2)). [9] On February 24 at the close of the Crown’s case against Kyle, I granted an amendment to Count #8 of the January 15, 2009 Information to allege, pursuant to section 95(1) of the Criminal Code, unlawful possession by Kyle Cater of an unloaded prohibited firearm - the AA Arms Model AP 9 handgun together with readily accessible ammunition that was capable of being discharged in the firearm. [43] I am unable to accept that Kyle Cater can assert a privacy interest in order to obtain the protection of section 8 of the Charter and then, when that application goes badly and the evidence is admitted, turn around and claim to be a stranger to the item in which the privacy interest resided. [101] I have concluded that the only reasonable inference to be drawn from the intercepts is that the speakers are talking about guns. He obviously also tried to exercise a measure of control, telling his father to get rid of what was there, to no avail. [168] The “Tracey” calls on December 7 and the January 15 calls indicate that Kyle had much more than merely a passive or quiescent knowledge of the firearms and ammunition at 80 Cavendish. [171] There are a number of indicators of Kyle Cater having a measure of control over the firearms at 80 Cavendish. Accordingly I find him guilty of Counts 4, 5 and 6 of the Information sworn January 15, 2009, unlawful possession of the sawed off Cooey shotgun, the Mark II Lakefield rifle, and the AA Arms AP 9 handgun, contrary to section 88(1) of the Criminal Code. I also find him guilty of Count 7, unlawful possession of a loaded prohibited firearm, a sawed off Cooey shotgun, contrary to section 95(1) of the Criminal Code, and of the amended Count 8, unlawful possession of an unloaded prohibited firearm, the AA Arms AP 9 handgun together with readily accessible ammunition capable of being discharged in the firearm, contrary to section 95(1) of the Criminal Code. [179] I further find Kyle Cater guilty of Counts 9 and 10 of unlawfully possessing the Cooey and the AP 9 knowing their possession was unauthorized, contrary to section 92(1) of the Criminal Code. And I find him guilty of Count 11, unlawfully possessing a prohibited device, two over-capacity magazines, contrary to section 92(2) of the Criminal Code. I am acquitting him of those charges. However I am not able to find beyond a reasonable doubt that Kyle had stored the three firearms in the manner they were found on January 15. I infer this from Intercept 7, a conversation on December 2, 2008 with D.M. and from the evidence that establishes Kyle was stashing his guns at locations other than where he was living. I find that the purpose of Kyle’s possession was offering to transfer it, that is, his purpose conforms to the Criminal Code definition of “transfer.” It was a firearms trafficking purpose. [207] My conclusions on the firearms trafficking charges can be summarized as follows: I find the Crown has proven beyond a reasonable doubt that Kyle Cater is guilty of Counts 3 and 4, relating to the .410 gauge shotgun; Counts 5 and 6, relating to the Derringer; Counts 7 and 8, relating to the .308 calibre rifle; and guilty of possession of the .45 calibre handgun for the purpose of offering to transfer it. [208] I acquit Kyle Cater of Counts 9, 10, 11 and 12 on the firearms trafficking Information. I find Kyle to be guilty of the possession of the .45 calibre firearm on December 28, 2008, a finding I am making in relation to Count 1 of the Information, not as specifically charged under Count 9 of the Information as I find that on or about December 7, 2008, Kyle Cater did not have possession of the .45 calibre handgun he was discussing at that time with I.E.

Accused found guilty on all the weapons' possession charges and some of the trafficking charges, but not guilty of careless storage of a firearm. It was clear that the accused had much more than a passive or quiescent knowledge of the guns seized from his parents' home and there were a number of indicators that he had a measure of control over them, such as his telling his father on occasion to get rid of them, his being notified immediately when one of the firearms went missing, the way he pressed his parents to explain how that could happen and his ability on other occasions to tell his father where in the home a particular firearm was located. However, despite his knowledge of the location of some of the firearms at certain times, the court was unable to find that the accused had stored the firearms in the manner they were found when the search warrant was executed. The evidence also established that he was stashing guns at locations other than his residence and he possessed those guns for the purpose of transferring them to others. The only reasonable inference to be drawn from the intercepts was that the speakers were talking about guns and the communications revealed the commercial nature of the accused's activities. Given that the accused had asserted a privacy interest with respect to an application to exclude the evidence arising from the police search of the cell phone seized from him, he could not now deny that the phone was his.
column23: HELD: The accused was found guilty of possession of a firearm contrary to s. 8 of the Criminal Code, unlawful storage of a sawed off Cooey 84 shotgun, a Lakefield Mark II rifle and ammunition, in a careless manner, and having some control over the guns located at his father’s residence.  1)The accused was convicted of trafficking firearms.  2)The Crown was not satisfied that the accused could assert a privacy interest in order to obtain the protection of s.8 of the Charter and then, when that application went badly and the evidence is admitted, turn around and claim to be a stranger to the item in which the privacy interest resided. The accused could not have obtained a Charter application in relation to the guns seized from him. 3)The evidence on the firearms seized from the accused was that they were firearms within the meaning of the criminal code and that they and the two magazines had been correctly identified and classified in the charges against the accused. 4)There was nothing to the continuity/integrity of the exhibits. 5)The court was unable to decide whether the accused had constructive and/or joint possession of the firearms at the time of his arrest or whether the intercepts constituted a prohibited device within s. 84(1) of the Code.
column24: Also as a result of the Part VI authorized intercepts, on April 29, 2009, Kyle Cater was charged with trafficking firearms. They are: the unlawful storage of a sawed off Cooey 84 shotgun, a Lakefield Mark II rifle, and an AA Arms Model AP 9 handgun, and ammunition, in a careless manner (contrary to Criminal Code section 86(1) x 3), unlawful possession of the sawed off Cooey 84 shotgun, the Lakefield Mark II rifle and the AA Arms Model AP 9 handgun (contrary to Criminal Code section 88(1) x 3), unlawful possession of a loaded prohibited weapon – the AA Arms Model AP 9 handgun, and unlawful possession of a loaded prohibited firearm – the sawed off Cooey 84 shotgun (contrary to Criminal Code section 95(1) x 2), unlawful possession of the sawed off Cooey and the AP 9 handgun, knowing that possession is unauthorized (contrary to Criminal Code section 92(1) x 2), and unlawful possession of two over capacity magazines, a prohibited device (contrary to Criminal Code section 92(2)). [9] On February 24 at the close of the Crown’s case against Kyle, I granted an amendment to Count #8 of the January 15, 2009 Information to allege, pursuant to section 95(1) of the Criminal Code, unlawful possession by Kyle Cater of an unloaded prohibited firearm - the AA Arms Model AP 9 handgun together with readily accessible ammunition that was capable of being discharged in the firearm. [43] I am unable to accept that Kyle Cater can assert a privacy interest in order to obtain the protection of section 8 of the Charter and then, when that application goes badly and the evidence is admitted, turn around and claim to be a stranger to the item in which the privacy interest resided. [101] I have concluded that the only reasonable inference to be drawn from the intercepts is that the speakers are talking about guns. He obviously also tried to exercise a measure of control, telling his father to get rid of what was there, to no avail. [168] The “Tracey” calls on December 7 and the January 15 calls indicate that Kyle had much more than merely a passive or quiescent knowledge of the firearms and ammunition at 80 Cavendish. [171] There are a number of indicators of Kyle Cater having a measure of control over the firearms at 80 Cavendish. Accordingly I find him guilty of Counts 4, 5 and 6 of the Information sworn January 15, 2009, unlawful possession of the sawed off Cooey shotgun, the Mark II Lakefield rifle, and the AA Arms AP 9 handgun, contrary to section 88(1) of the Criminal Code. I also find him guilty of Count 7, unlawful possession of a loaded prohibited firearm, a sawed off Cooey shotgun, contrary to section 95(1) of the Criminal Code, and of the amended Count 8, unlawful possession of an unloaded prohibited firearm, the AA Arms AP 9 handgun together with readily accessible ammunition capable of being discharged in the firearm, contrary to section 95(1) of the Criminal Code. [179] I further find Kyle Cater guilty of Counts 9 and 10 of unlawfully possessing the Cooey and the AP 9 knowing their possession was unauthorized, contrary to section 92(1) of the Criminal Code. And I find him guilty of Count 11, unlawfully possessing a prohibited device, two over-capacity magazines, contrary to section 92(2) of the Criminal Code. I am acquitting him of those charges. However I am not able to find beyond a reasonable doubt that Kyle had stored the three firearms in the manner they were found on January 15. I infer this from Intercept 7, a conversation on December 2, 2008 with D.M. and from the evidence that establishes Kyle was stashing his guns at locations other than where he was living. I find that the purpose of Kyle’s possession was offering to transfer it, that is, his purpose conforms to the Criminal Code definition of “transfer.” It was a firearms trafficking purpose. [207] My conclusions on the firearms trafficking charges can be summarized as follows: I find the Crown has proven beyond a reasonable doubt that Kyle Cater is guilty of Counts 3 and 4, relating to the .410 gauge shotgun; Counts 5 and 6, relating to the Derringer; Counts 7 and 8, relating to the .308 calibre rifle; and guilty of possession of the .45 calibre handgun for the purpose of offering to transfer it. [208] I acquit Kyle Cater of Counts 9, 10, 11 and 12 on the firearms trafficking Information. I find Kyle to be guilty of the possession of the .45 calibre firearm on December 28, 2008, a finding I am making in relation to Count 1 of the Information, not as specifically charged under Count 9 of the Information as I find that on or about December 7, 2008, Kyle Cater did not have possession of the .45 calibre handgun he was discussing at that time with I.E.

He merely attempted to keep the plaintiff on track in the presentation of his case and discouraged him from asking the defendant the same question multiple times. The appeal judge also failed to address the appellant's cross-examination of the defendant.

column2: HELD: The application was granted. The court ordered the removal of the respondent as an executor in the grant of probate and ordered that the applicants remain as executors but that they should take no further steps to distribute the assets of the estate. It found that there were “special circumstances” within the meaning of s. 17 of The Administration of Estates Act. The respondent was entitled to challenge the validity of the will but not entitled to remain as an executor.
column3: The applicants sought to remove the respondent as executor of their estate. They argued that the respondent had brought an application that effectively challenged the validity of the Will he was presently an executor and that he was refusing to co-operate in taking the steps necessary to administer the estate and carry out the directions contained in the Will. HELD: The application was dismissed. 1)The respondent was removed as an executrator in the grant of probate ordered by Gabrielson J. on July 20, 2016 and Kent Jones and Rodney Argue shall take no steps to distribute assets of the estate to beneficiaries or otherwise finalize the administration of the Estate until after February 15, 2018. 2)The applicant had not proven his right to represent him on the applications. 3)The court found that the applicant had no status as a proper party to the proceedings and that since she was neither named beneficiary under the Will nor potential beneficiary in the event of an intestacy she had no right to remain as an agent of the will. The respondent was not entitled to represent himself on the application.

column8: FIAT: The applicants seek to remove the respondent as an executor of the estate of the deceased. The respondent has brought an application that effectively challenges the validity of the Will he is presently in power and is refusing to co-operate in taking the steps necessary to administer the estate and carry out the directions contained in the Will. HELD: 1)The Court has the jurisdiction to remove Evan as executor in the grant of probate ordered by Gabrielson J. on July 20, 2016 and Kent Jones and Rodney Argue to take no steps to distribute assets of the Estate to beneficiaries or otherwise finalize the administration of the will until February 15, 2018. 2)The applicant has no status and is not entitled to represent him on the applications. The affidavit evidence of Kent and Rodney satisfies me that Evan is refusing not to co‑operate. 3)The respondent is removed as an estate executor pursuant to Queen's Bench decision Whitworth Estate Whitworth, 2016 SKQB 369 (CanLII). The Court ordered that he is removed from the position of executor and that Kent Jones, Rodney Arggue shall continue as executors pursuant to that grant. 4)Having before this Court an application seeking revocation of the grant, and an order that the Will be proven in solemn form and related relief, it is incumbent on the executors to properly administer an estate.

column13: FIAT: The applicants seek to remove the respondent as an executor of the estate of Edna May Jones. Their grounds are that the respondent has brought an application that effectively challenges the validity of the Will he is presently an executrator of and he is refusing to co-operate in taking the steps necessary to administer the estate and carry out the directions contained in the Will. HELD: 1) The Court finds that the applicant has no status as a proper party to the proceedings. 2) There is no evidence before the Court that either of the respondent's sons or Rodney have acted contrary to their obligations as executors. 3) Having before this Court an application seeking revocation of the grant of probate, and an order that the Will be proven in solemn form and related relief, it is incumbent on the executors to properly administer an estate. 4) The respondent is removed as executor in the Grant of Probate ordered by Gabrielson J. on July 20, 2016 and Kent Jones and Rodney Argue shall take no steps to distribute assets to beneficiaries or otherwise finalize the administration of that estate until February 15, 2018.

column23: The applicants apply to have the respondent removed as an executor of an estate pursuant to a grant of probate and an order that the Will be proven in solemn form and relief. HELD: The application is granted and the respondent is removed as executor. 1)The Court has the jurisdiction to remove the respondent from administering the estate both pursuant to its inherent jurisdiction and pursuant to s. 17 of The Administration of Estates Act.  2)The court found that the applicant had no status as a proper party to the proceedings and was refusing to co-operate in taking the steps necessary to administer the estate and carry out the directions contained in the Will of Edna May Jones as admitted to probate.  3)The applicant is not entitled to represent the applicant on the applications.

column2: In a contract of employment, which involved an agreement changing the plaintiff from 'expatriate' to 'local' status, a termination clause providing that the agreement could be terminated upon 3 months' notice was held to be inadequate language to abrogate the implied term of reasonable notice. The plaintiff had correctly interpreted the clause as relating to the termination of the agreement, not of his employment. The agreement provided that it was governed by the laws of the province of Alberta. The plaintiff had been employed by the defendant for 12 years and was awarded compensation in an amount equivalent to 18 months notice less the three months pay he already received and any income from his new employment over the balance of the 15 months. He was also awarded the loss resulting from the difference in vacation and loss of an auto allowance for the 15 months. For emotional trauma, which lasted only briefly, he received $500.
column3: The plaintiff was an expatriate employee for several years. He was assigned to Canada as an expat. He received a salary of $60,000. In 1986 he was offered a position with the defendant company as a regional manager. He refused the offer and was terminated without cause. The defendant then gave the plaintiff the option of going back to work in Montreal or to Halifax. He chose Halifax. The plaintiff considered that his employment by the defendant was being terminated without causing and left his employment. He signed an expats' agreement which provided him with a monthly allowance of $55,000 and a four-week vacation with a half-week paid vacation. He applied for and was awarded a position as regional manager of the company. He later became a permanent resident of Nova Scotia. He had been employed for several months by one company which was taken over by the other company. The company offered him monies that had been set out in the memorandum referred to, he was refused. He became depressed and went into deep depression. He sought employment with the other firm. He eventually left the company and moved to Halifax, Nova Scotia, where he became a District Manager. He remained there for four years. In 1985, the defendant took over the office of the regional manager in Nova Scotia and placed the respondent in charge of the new office. He then became a district manager in Halifax. In 1989, he joined the corporate office of another company which he later joined. He now worked for the defendant. He is a retired general and has a family of four. He has three children. He worked for several companies in Nova Scotia and is a member of the corporate social responsibility committee. He also has a daughter. She is a nurse. She was his assistant. She has two children. She now works for the corporate administration company. She also has an interest in the company's new office in Halifax, which is located in Nova Nova Scotia but is located outside Nova Scotia where the respondent is a permanent permanent resident. She currently resides in Nova Brunswick. She works for a public service company. When the respondent went to Argentina to establish an office for the company, he became an expate. He returned to work for several weeks in Nova Southeastern and was given a two-week written notice of termination without cause in the amount of $20,000 to be paid in full. She had no other choice but to move to Halifax and seek employment with another firm. She considered Halifax employment. She became a temporary resident of the city and became a
column4: I find that based on the plaintiff's knowledge of the defendant's practises at the time that he signed the agreement in 1985, that his interpretation that clause #7 did not relate to termination of his employment, but rather to termination of the written agreement, was correct. I find that the terminology was unclear in that termination of employment was not specifically mentioned in the clause and had not been discussed with him previously in preparing the '85 or '84 or earlier contracts. After taking into consideration all of the arguments made by the plaintiff, I find that Mr. Legorburu is entitled to eighteen months notice. I also award the loss resulting from the difference in vacation for fifteen months, and loss of automobile allowance for fifteen months. I award $500.00.

column8: This was an action for wrongful dismissal. The plaintiff was an expatriate employee assigned to a company in Canada. He was given a salary of $60,000.00 per year. He later became a District Manager of the company. The company offered him monies that had been set out in the memorandum referred to, he was offered nothing in lieu of notice. The defendant refused to give him that money. He applied to the Federal Civil Service and was granted three months notice of termination without cause. The action was dismissed. The court found that reasonable notice is implied by law and held that the particular contract was to preserve confidentiality as condition of the employment and was not intended to deal with general terms of employment.

column13: This was an action for wrongful dismissal. The plaintiff was an expatriate employee assigned to a company in Canada. He was given a salary of $60,000.00 per year. He later became a District Manager of the company. The company offered him monies that had been set out in the memorandum referred to, he was offered nothing in lieu of notice. When he joined the defendant company, he signed an alleged employment contract which confirmed his continued employment as manager of the Halifax Office with responsibility for Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. He received a cheque amounting to 1.5 weeks salary for each year he was employed with the company, along with vacation pay and his regular pay until December 31, 1986. When the company decided to terminate the agreement, the plaintiff was given two days written notice of termination without cause. The defendant refused to give him a third month notice. At trial the plaintiff testified that he believed that he could leave the company on three months notice but that the company had no right to give it a further month's notice. He alleged that he had been told by the defendant that he would be transferred to a new office in Halifax and that he was reluctant to move because he believed there would be no alternative work in Nova Scotia. He also alleged that the defendant had threatened to terminate his employment if he did not obtain employment elsewhere. Dismissing the action, that reasonable notice is implied by law and the particular contract was not intended to deal with the plaintiff's termination of his employment.

column18: This was an action for wrongful dismissal. The plaintiff, an American citizen, commenced work for the defendant company in 1985 as an expatriate. He was assigned to the company as an office manager. In 1986, the company offered him a position as a senior geophysicist. He refused the job and became depressed. He applied for a position with the company which was taken over by the American company. The offer was for three years at a rate of $55,000 per year. The contract was not intended to deal with the plaintiff's needs. He believed there would be no alternative work in Nova Scotia. When the company decided to terminate the agreement, the plaintiff applied for the position of regional manager of the company. He received two days written notice of termination without cause. When he applied for another position, the offer was reduced to 30 days. The defendant refused to give him another job. He then applied for and was awarded a position in the company's regional office. He claimed to have no recollection of the meeting with the American manager. He also claimed that he was given a letter from the American executive suggesting that he could leave the company on three months notice and that he would be transferred to a new office in Halifax. He alleged that this letter did not refer to termination of his employment by the defendant but rather suggested that the company would give 30 days notice of its intention. The court held that to terminate without reasonable notice requires the use of very clear words. This means clear words are required to abrogate the implied term of reasonable notice of dismissal of employment.

column22: In a contract of employment, which involved an agreement changing the plaintiff from 'expatriate' to 'local' status, a termination clause providing that the agreement could be terminated upon 3 months' notice was held to be inadequate language to abrogate the implied term of reasonable notice. The plaintiff had correctly interpreted the clause as relating to the termination of the agreement, not of his employment. The agreement provided that it was governed by the laws of the province of Alberta. The plaintiff had been employed by the defendant for 12 years and was awarded compensation in an amount equivalent to 18 months notice less the three months pay he already received and any income from his new employment over the balance of the 15 months. He was also awarded the loss resulting from the difference in vacation and loss of an auto allowance for the 15 months. For emotional trauma, which lasted only briefly, he received $500.
column23: This was an action for wrongful dismissal. The plaintiff, an American citizen, commenced work for the defendant company in 1985 as an expatriate. He was assigned to the company as an office manager. In 1986, the company offered him a position as a senior geophysicist. He refused the job and became depressed. He applied to the Federal Civil Service and was given two days written notice of termination without cause. Dismissing the application without cause, that the agreement did not purport to deal with the plaintiff's termination of employment. The court found that reasonable notice is implied by law and held that the particular contract was to preserve confidentiality as condition of the employment and was not intended to deal specifically with the issue of termination. It was also held that if the defendant desired to terminate the agreement, it had to give 30 days notice of its intention.
column24: I find that based on the plaintiff's knowledge of the defendant's practises at the time that he signed the agreement in 1985, that his interpretation that clause #7 did not relate to termination of his employment, but rather to termination of the written agreement, was correct. I find that the terminology was unclear in that termination of employment was not specifically mentioned in the clause and had not been discussed with him previously in preparing the '85 or '84 or earlier contracts. After taking into consideration all of the arguments made by the plaintiff, I find that Mr. Legorburu is entitled to eighteen months notice. I also award the loss resulting from the difference in vacation for fifteen months, and loss of automobile allowance for fifteen months. I award $500.00.
column27: This was an action for wrongful dismissal. The plaintiff, an American citizen, commenced work for the defendant company in 1985 as an expatriate. He was assigned to the company as an office manager. In 1986, the company offered him a position as a senior geophysicist. He refused the job and became depressed. He applied for a position with the company which was taken over by the American company. The offer was for three years at a rate of $55,000 per year. The contract was not intended to deal with the plaintiff's needs. He believed there would be no alternative work in Nova Scotia. When the company decided to terminate the agreement, the plaintiff applied for the position of regional manager of the company. He received two days written notice of termination without cause. When he applied for another position, the offer was reduced to 30 days. The defendant refused to give him another job. He then applied for and was awarded a position in the company's regional office. He claimed to have no recollection of the meeting with the American manager. He also claimed that he was given a letter from the American executive suggesting that he could leave the company on three months notice and that he would be transferred to a new office in Halifax. He alleged that this letter did not refer to termination of his employment by the defendant but rather suggested that the company would give 30 days notice of its intention. The court held that to terminate without reasonable notice requires the use of very clear words. This means clear words are required to abrogate the implied term of reasonable notice of dismissal of employment.

column2: On appeal from 106 SaskR 277. 47 year old respondent, former President and Chief Executive Officer of STC, had been awarded $165,000 (18 months) for wrongful dismissal. He had successively served three Crown Corporations over a period of ten years. On appeal held the award of damages was not inordinately high. The court however reduced the damages by $16,500 as it disagreed with the trial judge's determination regarding mitigation of damages. Appeal allowed to the extent of reducing the damages from $165,000 to $148,500.
column3: This was an appeal from an assessment of damages in a wrongful dismissal action brought against Saskatchewan Transportation Company by Leo Larsen, its former President and Chief Executive Officer. For the most part we can find no tenable basis for concluding that the award of damages was inordinately high. The trial judge assessed the damages on the general principles, first, that the object of these awards is to compensate for the loss of income sustained in consequence of the wrongful dismissal; second, that their measure is prima facie the amount that would have been earned had the employment continued subject to deduction of such amounts as in the ensuing months are either earned or should have been. The salary was not included in the total amount awarded. The severance terms of the contract were arrived at with an eye to his earlier service. The judge found that the severance expenses were part of the plaintiff's year of employment and that they were not included on the total number of months of employment. The plaintiff appealed. Appeal allowed. The court found no tenability for concluding the award was inordinate high.
column4: This is an appeal from an assessment of damages in a wrongful dismissal action brought against Saskatchewan Transportation Company by Leo Larsen, its former President and Chief Executive Officer. In consequence Mr. Larsen obtained a judgment for damages against the corporation in the basic amount of $165,000, an amount it contends is exorbitant. For the most part we can find no tenable basis for concluding that the award of damages was inordinately high. And so we have decided to reduce his damages by some $16,000 to $17,000. It follows, then, that the appeal will be allowed to the extent of reducing this head of damages from $165,000 to $148,500.

column2: The appellant was convicted of indecent assault against two young girls. He appealed on five grounds related to a substantial conflict in the evidence. Dismissing the appeal, that there was no error on the part of the trial judge in weighing the evidence.
column3: The appellant was convicted of two counts of indecent assault. The trial judge found the appellant guilty of both counts. The Court of Appeal also dismissed the appeal of the convictions on the grounds of credibility. The appellant had been convicted of both charges.
column4: THE COURT: Appeal dismissed per oral reasons for judgment of Jones, J.A.; Chipman and Freeman, JJ.A. concurring. There was a substantial conflict in the evidence. The trial judge, after carefully considering the evidence, convicted the appellant on both counts. After carefully reviewing the evidence we cannot say that the verdict was unreasonable or not supported by the evidence and accordingly the appeal is dismissed.

column2: This was an appeal from a Supreme Court decision on an interpleader application by the respondent Shubenacadie Band to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owed by the Band to the respondent Francis, an Indian residing on the Eskasoni Reserve in Cape Breton, for the construction of residential homes on the Shubenacadie Reserve. Francis had made a number of assignments of book debts, some general and some specific, to the various claimants. The trial judge concluded that he was bound by s.89(1) of the Indian Act, which holds that the real and personal property of an Indian or a band situated on a reserve is not subject to charge, pledge, mortgage, attachment, levy, seizure, distress or execution in favour of or at the instance of any person other than an Indian or a band. He concluded that the money owed Francis by the Shubenacadie band was the property of an Indian on a reserve, and that assignment of book debts, both general and specific, were included within the meaning of s.89(1). He found that the respondent Eskasoni Band was the only Indian entity among the several claimants and ordered the money paid to them. The appellants appealed. Allowing the appeal on the issue of the Indian Act, that s.89(1) does not prevent an Indian from assigning book debts of his construction business to secure business loans. When Indians are in business they hold and deal with their business property in the commercial mainstream on terms no different than those applicable to all Canadians. Nevertheless, the Eskasoni Band is still entitled to the money owed to Francis by reason of having obtained the first general assignment of book debts from him and having registered it prior to Francis making further assignments. The registration of a general assignment of book debts is constructive notice of the assignment to subsequent assignees falling within the provisions of s.3 of the Assignment of Book Debts Act.
column3: The appellant Band Council applied to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owing by the appellant Band under a construction contract entered into by the respondent Band with the respondent in 1990. The appellant Band applied to have the money paid to the respondent by a letter to his solicitor instructing him to pay the respondent funds which were due to the appellant to the maximum amount of $70,000. The respondent Band appealed the decision of the trial judge, holding that assignments of book debts, both general and specific, were included within the wording of the Indian Act. The appeal court held that s. 89(1) of the Act was applicable and the appellant was entitled $70k of this fund by reason of a letter of direction from Francis to his lawyer instructing his solicitor to pay to the applicant funds which had been due to him from the respondent band to the limit amount of the maximum sum. The court also held that the appellant had not shown that he had a choice in action. Appeal allowed.
column4:
THE COURT: Appeal allowed per reasons for judgment of Hallett, J.A.; Bateman and Flinn, JJ.A. concurring. This is an appeal from a decision of Mr. Justice Edwards arising out of an interpleader application by the Shubenacadie Band Council to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owing by the Shubenacadie Band under a construction contract entered into by the Shubenacadie Band with the respondent Paul Kenneth Francis for the construction of residential homes on the Shubenacadie Reserve. Mr. Francis is an Indian, a member of the Eskasoni Band, and resides on the Eskasoni Reserve in Cape Breton. Section 89(1) states:

"89. (1) Subject to this Act, the real and personal property of an Indian or a band situated on a reserve is not subject to charge, pledge, mortgage, attachment, levy, seizure, distress or execution in favour or at the instance of any person other than an Indian or a band." The learned trial judge concluded that the sum of $101,636.33 owing by the Shubenacadie Band to Mr. Francis and held at the Council office in the form of a bank draft payable to the Band in trust was the property of an Indian on a reserve. He further held, applying a liberal interpretation of the Indian Act that assignments of book debts, both general and specific, were included within the wording of s. 89(1) of the Act. On the appeal L. Martin (1984) Inc. asserts that Justice Edwards misinterpreted s. 89(1) of the Act and that it is entitled to $70,000 of this fund by reason of a letter of direction from Francis to his solicitor instructing his solicitor to pay to Martin funds which were due to Mr. Francis from the Shubenacadie Band to the maximum amount of $70,000. I am, however, of the opinion that the Eskasoni Band is entitled to the fund by reason of having obtained the first general assignment of book debts from Francis and having registered it prior to Francis making further assignments notwithstanding that the holders of the subsequent assignments or directions to pay (which the parties agreed were assignments in the Agreed Statement of Facts) gave notice of the assignments they held to the debtor, the Shubenacadie Band, prior to the Eskasoni Band giving notice to the Shubenacadie Band of its prior registered general assignment of book debts. Conclusion Martin's appeal was successful on the issue raised under the Indian Act but it failed on the priorities issue.

column8: This was an appeal from a decision of the Supreme Court of Canada which held that s. 89(1) of the Indian Act was applicable and governed the issue he was required to consider. HELD: The appeal was allowed. 1)The respondent was an Indian, a member of the Eskasoni Band and resided on the Reserve in Cape Breton. The respondent made a number of assignments of book debts, some general and some specific to the various claimants. The assignment was made under a construction contract entered into by the respondent with the intention of giving the respondent a priority over the other claimants. 2)The appellant was entitled to $70,000 of this fund by reason of a letter of direction from Francis to his solicitor instructing his solicitor to pay to the respondent funds which were due to him from the Band to the maximum amount of $70.  3)The Court held that registration under the'Assignment of Book Debts Act' did not prevent an Indian from entering into normal financing agreements in conjunction with the operation of commercial business. The Act does not either expressly or impliedly confer any greater right upon an assignee of a chose in action that he had before. The innocent purchaser is protected provided he had no notice, whether the assignment was done on a different basis than all other Canadians. 4)The Act was never intended by the Legislature to be a 'legislative package' as it was not intended to prevent an individual from entering the business of an Indian or a band situated on a reserve. The act was intended to remedy the economically disadvantaged position of Indians by ensuring that they may acquire, hold and deal with property in the commercial mainstream on different terms than their fellow citizens.

column13: This was an appeal from a decision of the Chief Justice of the Shubenacadie Band Council to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owing by the respondent under a construction contract entered into by the Band with the respondent for the construction of residential homes on the Reserve. The respondent was an Indian, a member of the Eskasoni Band, and resided on the reserve in Cape Breton. He had made a number of assignments of book debts, some general and some specific to the various claimants. The appellant claimed under these assignments that the sum of $101,636 was the property of an Indian on a reserve. He further held, applying a liberal interpretation of s. 89(1) of the Act that assignments of books, both general and specific, were included within the wording of the Indian Act. HELD: The appeal was allowed with costs. 1)The Court held that registration under the Assignment of Book Debts Act did nothing more than prevent an Indian from entering into normal financing agreements in conjunction with the operation of commercial business. The Act does not either expressly or impliedly confer any greater right upon an assignee of a chose in action that he had before. 2)The respondent is an Indian and most significantly he is in the construction business. He has preserved whatever rights it acquired by virtue of the assignment and no more. He could deal with his accounts receivable as any other Canadian businessperson.  3)The Act is intended to insulate the property interests of Indians in their reserve lands from intrusions and interference of the larger society so as to ensure that Indians are not dispossessed of their entitlement.

THE COURT: Appeal allowed per reasons for judgment of Hallett, J.A.; Bateman and Flinn, JJ.A. concurring. This is an appeal from a decision of Mr. Justice Edwards arising out of an interpleader application by the Shubenacadie Band Council to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owing by the Shubenacadie Band under a construction contract entered into by the Shubenacadie Band with the respondent Paul Kenneth Francis for the construction of residential homes on the Shubenacadie Reserve. Mr. Francis is an Indian, a member of the Eskasoni Band, and resides on the Eskasoni Reserve in Cape Breton. Section 89(1) states:

"89. (1) Subject to this Act, the real and personal property of an Indian or a band situated on a reserve is not subject to charge, pledge, mortgage, attachment, levy, seizure, distress or execution in favour or at the instance of any person other than an Indian or a band." The learned trial judge concluded that the sum of $101,636.33 owing by the Shubenacadie Band to Mr. Francis and held at the Council office in the form of a bank draft payable to the Band in trust was the property of an Indian on a reserve. He further held, applying a liberal interpretation of the Indian Act that assignments of book debts, both general and specific, were included within the wording of s. 89(1) of the Act. On the appeal L. Martin (1984) Inc. asserts that Justice Edwards misinterpreted s. 89(1) of the Act and that it is entitled to $70,000 of this fund by reason of a letter of direction from Francis to his solicitor instructing his solicitor to pay to Martin funds which were due to Mr. Francis from the Shubenacadie Band to the maximum amount of $70,000. I am, however, of the opinion that the Eskasoni Band is entitled to the fund by reason of having obtained the first general assignment of book debts from Francis and having registered it prior to Francis making further assignments notwithstanding that the holders of the subsequent assignments or directions to pay (which the parties agreed were assignments in the Agreed Statement of Facts) gave notice of the assignments they held to the debtor, the Shubenacadie Band, prior to the Eskasoni Band giving notice to the Shubenacadie Band of its prior registered general assignment of book debts. Conclusion Martin's appeal was successful on the issue raised under the Indian Act but it failed on the priorities issue.
column17: This was an appeal from a Supreme Court decision on an interpleader application by the respondent Shubenacadie Band to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owed by the Band to the respondent Francis, an Indian residing on the Eskasoni Reserve in Cape Breton, for the construction of residential homes on the Shubenacadie Reserve. Francis had made a number of assignments of book debts, some general and some specific, to the various claimants. The trial judge concluded that he was bound by s.89(1) of the Indian Act, which holds that the real and personal property of an Indian or a band situated on a reserve is not subject to charge, pledge, mortgage, attachment, levy, seizure, distress or execution in favour of or at the instance of any person other than an Indian or a band. He concluded that the money owed Francis by the Shubenacadie band was the property of an Indian on a reserve, and that assignment of book debts, both general and specific, were included within the meaning of s.89(1). He found that the respondent Eskasoni Band was the only Indian entity among the several claimants and ordered the money paid to them. The appellants appealed. Allowing the appeal on the issue of the Indian Act, that s.89(1) does not prevent an Indian from assigning book debts of his construction business to secure business loans. When Indians are in business they hold and deal with their business property in the commercial mainstream on terms no different than those applicable to all Canadians. Nevertheless, the Eskasoni Band is still entitled to the money owed to Francis by reason of having obtained the first general assignment of book debts from him and having registered it prior to Francis making further assignments. The registration of a general assignment of book debts is constructive notice of the assignment to subsequent assignees falling within the provisions of s.3 of the Assignment of Book Debts Act.
column18: An interpleader application by the Shubenacadie Band Council to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owing by the Band under a construction contract entered into by the respondent for the construction of residential homes on the reserve. The respondent was an Indian, a member of the Eskasoni Band and resided on the Reserve in Cape Breton. He made a number of assignments of book debts, some general and some specified to the various claimants. He also made a bank draft payable to the Band in trust. The bank draft was registered under the Act and was the property of the respondent. The appeal was allowed on the simple ground that it was never in the contemplation of the parties to the August assignment that the conditional sales agreements covered, as the parties knew, by the previous contract between Fagel and the defendant [the finance company], should be affected by the subsequent assignment of the book debts.

column27: This was an appeal from a decision of the Chief Justice of the Shubenacadie Band Council to determine which of several parties was entitled to be paid a sum of money owing by the respondent under a construction contract entered into by the Band with the respondent for the construction of residential homes on the Reserve. The respondent was an Indian, a member of the Eskasoni Band, and resided on the reserve in Cape Breton. He had made a number of assignments of book debts, some general and some specific to the various claimants. The appellant claimed under these assignments that the sum of $101,636 was the property of an Indian on a reserve. He further held, applying a liberal interpretation of s. 89(1) of the Act that assignments of books, both general and specific, were included within the wording of the Indian Act. HELD: The appeal was allowed with costs. 1)The Court held that registration under the Assignment of Book Debts Act did nothing more than prevent an Indian from entering into normal financing agreements in conjunction with the operation of commercial business. The Act does not either expressly or impliedly confer any greater right upon an assignee of a chose in action that he had before. 2)The respondent is an Indian and most significantly he is in the construction business. He has preserved whatever rights it acquired by virtue of the assignment and no more. He could deal with his accounts receivable as any other Canadian businessperson.  3)The Act is intended to insulate the property interests of Indians in their reserve lands from intrusions and interference of the larger society so as to ensure that Indians are not dispossessed of their entitlement.

column2: FIAT. The applicant sought an order pursuant to s.87 and s.251 of the Land Titles Act cancelling the existing certificate of Title in the names of the deceased and herself as tenants in common and directing the Land Titles Registrar to issue a new title in their joint names with right of survivorship. The deceased and applicant who had been living together purchased residential property in 1997. Their lawyer prepared a written agreement for the sellers and purchasers as well as the mortgage describing the purchasers as joint tenants. The sellers, unrepresented by legal counsel, prepared the transfer of the property and title issued without the words 'joint tenants'. The error describing the purchasers went unnoticed by their lawyer. The respondent had been married to the deceased when he died intestate in 1998. As the title stood an undivided one-half interest was owned by the estate and would devolve to the respondent pursuant to the Intestate Succession Act. HELD: The Land Titles Office Registrar was to amend the existing certificate of title by inserting 'joint tenants' after the names of the registered owners. 1)The requirements set out in Bank of Nova Scotia v. Rochon were satisfied. There was an obvious mistake which required rectification. The deceased and the applicant intended to purchase the property as joint tenants and instructed their lawyer accordingly. The lawyer acknowledged that it was a mistake that the title issued as it did. 2)Although the applicant had an alternate remedy of seeking damages for any loss from her conveyance lawyer, damages were not a reasonably convenient remedy in this case as title would remain registered in the names of strangers, neither of whom could be compelled to sell to the other.
column3: FIAT. The applicant sought an order pursuant to ss.87 and s. 251 of the Land Titles Act, cancelling the existing Certificate of Title in the name of the applicant and directing the Registrar of Land Title at Battleford to issue a new title in their joint names with right of survivorship. HELD: An order was made directing the registrar to cancel the existing title and issue a replacement certificate in the names of the purchasers. Damages in the circumstances were not a reasonably convenient remedy or procedure for giving relief. The application was dismissed.
column4: [1] Maureen Janette Rodh (Rodh) seeks an order pursuant to ss.87 and 251 of The Land Titles Act R.S.S. 1978 c.L-15 as amended, cancelling the existing Certificate of Title in the name of John Roman Sarauer (Sarauer) and herself as tenants in common and directing the Registrar of Land Titles at Battleford to issue a new title in their joint names with right of survivorship. Based on those facts, I am also satisfied that Rodh and Sarauer intended to purchase the property as joint tenants and instructed their lawyer accordingly. The lawyer acknowledged that it was a mistake that the title issued as it did and that the mistake was not noticed by him when he reviewed the documents. Not a remedy that would correct the mistake, but could provide compensation in the form of damages from the lawyer for any loss suffered as a result of the mistake. Damages in the circumstances of this case are not, in my opinion, a reasonably convenient remedy or procedure for giving relief. [14] There will be an order that the Registrar of the Battleford Land Titles Office amend existing Certificate of Title #97B13424 containing a portion of SE¼ 27-47-26-W3M by inserting after the names of the registered owners, John Roman Sarauer and Maureen Janette Rodh the words, “as joint tenants”.

column2: The 18 year old, charged with the second degree murder of two individuals, applied for release from custody. HELD: The accused was released on his own undertakings under a set of strict conditions, including participation in an electronic monitoring program. The onus is on the accused to show cause why his detention in custody is not justified. Criminal Code s.515(10) now permits detention on three grounds. His detention was not necessary to ensure his attendance at court nor for the protection or safety of the public. There was no evidence he posed a substantial likelihood of committing further offences or that he would interfere with the administration of justice if released. There was no other just cause, including maintenance of confidence in the administration of justice.
column3: The accused was charged with second degree murder and second degree assault. The accused was released on an undertaking that he would participate in the Electronic Monitoring Program and that his detention was necessary to maintain confidence in the administration of justice. HELD: The accused will be released on a set of strict conditions. 1)The accused had been involved in school, sports and community activities. He had strong roots in the First Nation. He was involved in the community where he was involved with the youth and was involved as a youth. 2)The Court was satisfied in all of the circumstances that the continued detention of the accused was necessary for the protection or safety of the public. The detention was not necessary to ensure his attendance at court.  3)The detention was unnecessary to maintain a sense of confidence in administration of the justice system.
column4: [15] I am not satisfied that the detention of the accused is necessary to ensure his attendance at court. [16] I am not satisfied that the detention of the accused is necessary for the protection or safety of the public. There is no evidence that [A.R.S.] poses a substantial likelihood of committing further offences or that he will, if released, interfere with the administration of justice. The accused will be released on his own undertaking on a set of strict conditions. (4) He shall participate in the Electronic Monitoring Program, and shall comply with all Program rules.
column7: The 18 year old, charged with the second degree murder of two individuals, applied for release from custody. HELD: The accused was released on his own undertakings under a set of strict conditions, including participation in an electronic monitoring program. The onus is on the accused to show cause why his detention in custody is not justified. Criminal Code s.515(10) now permits detention on three grounds. His detention was not necessary to ensure his attendance at court nor for the protection or safety of the public. There was no evidence he posed a substantial likelihood of committing further offences or that he would interfere with the administration of justice if released. There was no other just cause, including maintenance of confidence in the administration of justice.

column2: The Credit Union loaned $37,700 upon security, inter alia, of a 1999 Chevrolet Blazer owned by McMillan. A security agreement was registered at the Personal Property Security Registry in September 2000 and re-registered in November 2001. After McMillan died in June 2001, payments fell into arrears and a demand was made for possession of the Blazer. His widow, the respondent, was shown as co-buyer on the purchase agreement but was never the registered owner until she acquired it from her husband's estate. She sought to defeat the security interest on the grounds she was the real owner at all times, made the payments and was always in possession. At issue was whether the registered owner of a vehicle has the power to grant a security interest enforceable in priority to the interest of a person whose claim, though substantial, is not registered or otherwise of record in any place where the lender has or should have notice of it. HELD: The claim of the Credit Union was enforceable. Judicial notice was taken of the fact there is no title registry in Saskatchewan other than that maintained by Saskatchewan Government Insurance. The licensing function was assigned to SGI under the Vehicle Administration Act. That Act and the Highway Traffic Act are clear the person named in a registration certificate is regarded as the owner of the vehicle. Motor vehicles are unique in that their registration creates a presumption of ownership and follows a declaration of ownership by the registry. Reliance upon the registration system is an important facet of our commerce and would create chaos if reliance is taken away. Ownership does not depend upon registration. However, once a vehicle is registered following a declaration of ownership, a presumption arises in favour of the holder of the registration certificate and as a matter of commercial efficacy lenders, the police, insurers, repairmen, etc. are justified in relying upon the certificate as proof of ownership. A transfer of ownership would defeat the Credit Union's claim only if it were undertaken for value and with notice. No costs were awarded on either motion.
column3: The applicant bank loaned the respondent $37,700 upon a security of a 1999 Chevrolet Blazer. The vehicle was not sold or charged in favour of a third party during the period of September 11, 2001 to November 14, 2001 when the security interest was unperfected. The wife of the lender had apparently been the person who used the vehicle under the security agreement but she was never the registered owner of the vehicle until she acquired it from her husband's estate. The applicant argued that the Credit Union's claim was based on his being one of the named purchasers in the original agreement and being the registered Owner of the Vehicle. All other indicia of ownership were in her favour. The issue was whether the registered owners of a vehicle have the power to grant a security interest enforceable in priority to the interest of a person whose claim, though substantial, is not registered or otherwise of record in any place where the lender has or should have notice of it. HELD: The claim of the Credit union was enforceable as against the conflicting claim of Ms. Clayton.  1)The claim of Credit Union was enforceABLE. 2)The applicant's claim of transfer of ownership was enforceably. The Credit Union claim was enforceability as against a conflicting claim.

column2: The accused was charged with driving while her ability to do so was impaired contrary to s. 253(a) and s. 255(1) of the Criminal Code and driving while over .08 contrary to s. 253(b) and s.255(1) of the Criminal Code. At the conclusion of the trial, the defence brought a motion to exclude the certificate of analysis as the demand flowed from an invalid approved screening device demand. HELD: The defence application to exclude the certificate of analysis based on a breach of s. 8 and s. 9 of the Charter was granted. There being no evidence upon which to convict in regard to the .08 charge, it was dismissed.  1) The Court found a distinction between 'had consumed alcohol' and 'has alcohol in the person's body'. The Court found the words 'had consumed alcohol' to be insufficient for the Court to conclude that the officer had a reasonable suspicion there was alcohol in the accused's body at the time of the demand. 2) There was no objective basis upon which a reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body could be made. The evidence of alcohol on the breath was not reliable in the circumstances of this case. The admission of having had her last drink was possibly made after the demand and could not be relied on to formulate the required reasonable suspicion. The evidence of bloodshot eyes, empty beer bottles in a plastic bag with three persons in the car and the smell of alcohol coming from the vehicle could not alone support a reasonable conclusion of reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body of the motorist.
column3: The accused was charged with impaired driving and operating a motor vehicle contrary to s. 253(a) and s. 255(1) of the Criminal Code. The accused was also charged with operating a stolen vehicle contrary s. 254(2) of The Charter. HELD: The accused's application to exclude the Certificate of Analysis was dismissed. 1)The evidence of speeding, bloodshot eyes, empty beer bottles in a plastic bag with three persons in the car and smell of alcohol coming from the vehicle was insufficient to justify the demand. 2)The defence application to include the Certificate was granted pursuant to s24(2). 3)The words 'had consumed alcohol' were insufficient for the court to conclude that the officer had a reasonable suspicion that the accused had alcohol in his body. 4)The Court was persuaded that the words 'consumed alcohol' did not constitute insufficient evidence to conclude the officer's reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body. 5)The court found that the defence application was not supported by the evidence of speed, blood, empty bottles in plastic bag, empty beers bottles in the plastic bag and smell alcohol coming out the vehicle. 6)The accused's admission that she had consumed alcohol was not sufficient to justify a demand for a breath sample which was not made pursuant to the Charter. 7)The issue of whether the words had consumed was not raised. 8)The Crown conceded that if such Charter breaches were found, the appropriate remedy would be to exclude a Certificate ofalyses based upon a breach of ss8 and 9 of the Charter pursuant to ss24(1). 8)On reflection, and having given careful consideration to the cases cited, I am persuaded the words "had consumed" are indeed insufficient for conviction to conclude. The words 'alcohol' are indeed sufficient for the Court to conclude on the evidence that the police officer had reasonable suspicion there was alcohol in her body at the time of the ASD demand.
column4:
Background [1] The accused stands charged that on or about the 16th day of July 2001, at Manitou Beach, in the Province of Saskatchewan, did ...
"while her ability to drive a motor vehicle was impaired by alcohol or a drug, operate a motor vehicle contrary to section 253(a) and section 255(1) of the Criminal Code
And
having consumed alcohol in such quantity that the concentration thereof in her blood exceeded eighty milligrams of alcohol in one hundred millilitres of blood, operate a motor vehicle contrary to section 253(b) and 255(1) of the Criminal Code." [3] At the conclusion of the Crown's case, the defence brought a motion to exclude the Certificate of Analyses, such evidence flowing from an invalid approved screening device demand, which infringed the accused's s.8 and s.9 Charter rights. Upon reflection, and having given careful consideration to the cases cited, I am persuaded that the words "had consumed alcohol" are indeed insufficient for the court to conclude that the officer had a reasonable suspicion there was alcohol in her body at the time of the ASD demand. [29] Although this determination is unnecessary given my conclusion on the previous point raised, on the evidence before me I would clearly find there was no objective basis upon which a reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body could be made. [31] This then leaves only the evidence of speeding, bloodshot eyes, empty beer bottles in a plastic bag with three persons in the car, and smell of alcohol coming from the vehicle. Objectively, these grounds alone cannot support a conclusion of reasonable suspicion of alcohol in the body of the motorist. [32] For all of the foregoing reasons, the defence application to exclude the Certificate of Analyses based upon a breach of ss. 8 and 9 of the Charter is granted, pursuant to s. 24(2). [33] Accordingly, there being no evidence upon which to convict in regard to the second count, same is dismissed against the accused.

column2: The son of unmarried parents, who had graduated from high school, was working part-time, living with his mother and had not made a final decision on a further course of study sustained a serious brain injury just a few months after his 19th birthday. He required extensive rehabilitation and would not regain his pre-accident physical and intellectual capacity. The mother successfully applied for a reinstatement of child support which had been discontinued by consent, pre-accident, when the son was residing with the father. The son, now 23 years old, was upgrading his high school marks at the time of the hearing and hoped to be admitted to a community college program. The father appealed. Appeal dismissed; the judge's decision to award support was not premised upon a finding that, pre-accident, the son had made a clear decision to pursue a further course of study but on the fact that the son intended to pursue his education and had not withdrawn from parental charge at the time of the accident. There was no evidence to support the allegation that the usual Guideline amount was 'inappropriate' in this case; the Act prohibited the consideration of public income assistance when fixing child support; given the uncertainty about the son's future, this was not an appropriate case for a time-limited order.
column3: The appellant father appealed an order made pursuant to the Maintenance and Custody Act requiring him to pay maintenance for his son. The appellant had a brief relationship in 1981 when the child was 16 years old. He had recently completed grade 12 at Millwood High School. He was in receipt of income assistance. The parties had separated in early 2001. The father had been working full-time jobs and had made arrangements to move out of the mother's home. The child had been in receipt for support for four years. The court found that the appellant had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw from his parent's charge at the time of the accident. The order for support was not premised on the appellant's continuing dependency as a result of his pursuit of post-secondary studies. The evidence supported the appellant father's finding that the child had not withdraw and was not unable to withdrawn from his charge at that time.
column4: Held: Appeal dismissed, with costs payable by Mr. Hill to Ms. Davis in the amount of $2,000.00 together with disbursements as taxed or agreed, as per reasons for judgment of Bateman, J.A.; Roscoe and Cromwell, JJ.A. concurring [1] This is an appeal from an order made pursuant to the Maintenance and Custody Act, S.N.S. 1989, c. 160 as amended, requiring the appellant father, Gilbert Roland Hill to pay maintenance for his son James Anthony Davis. On the basis of the outlined circumstances, I find that James, at the time he attained the age of 19 years, had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw from the charge of his parents, since it was his intention at that time, and still is his intention, to further his education at a post-secondary educational institution. I am not persuaded that the judge erred in concluding James had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw from his parent’s charge at the time of the accident. I have concluded the order for support was not premised on James’ continuing dependency as a result of his pursuit of post-secondary studies. It is not an appropriate case for a time-limited order. [35] In summary, I am not persuaded there was any evidentiary basis upon which the judge could conclude that the Guideline amount was “inappropriate” and therefore depart from it. [36] I would dismiss the appeal with costs payable by Mr. Hill to Ms. Davis in the amount of $2,000.00 together with disbursements as taxed or agreed.

column18: This was an appeal from an order made pursuant to the Maintenance and Custody Act requiring the appellant father, Gilbert Hill, to pay maintenance for his son. The respondent was the father of the child. At the time of the accident, the appellant had completed grade 12 at Millwood High School and was re-enrolling in Grade 12 in order to improve his marks for university entrance. Following his discharge from the Nova Scotia Rehabilitation Centre in December 2001, the respondent returned to live with his mother. Although the respondent had some contact with his father after that time, he was abusing drugs and alcohol which was of concern to both parents. HELD: The appeal was dismissed with costs payable by Mr. Hill to Ms. Davis in the amount of $2,000 together with disbursements as taxed or agreed.  1) Section 2(c) of the Act provides that a child may remain dependent even where over the age of majority, if unable, by reason of illness, disability or other cause, to withdraw from the charge of the parents or provide himself with reasonable needs. It is not an appropriate case for a time-limited order. 2) On the basis of the outlined circumstances, I am not persuaded that the judge erred in concluding that at the time, at 19 years of age, the child had not withdrawn and was unable to withdraw. It was his intention at that time to further his education at a post-secondary educational institution.

column2: The appellant was convicted of sexual assault. The court disbelieved his evidence, principally because it was found to be internally inconsistent. The court found that the appellant had attempted to portray himself as being good to the children but had admitted on cross-examination that the children had been removed from the home due to allegations of physical abuse and lack of food. There was no evidence before the court as to the truth of these allegations and the appellant had stated in his evidence that everyone thought that he treated the children badly. The appellant appealed. Appeal allowed; conviction set aside; new trial ordered. The trial judge misapprehended the evidence because she attributed to it a relevance that it could not have in law or in logic. The appellants evidence about the involvement of Childrens Services did not permit the judge to draw any inference that the children had, in fact, been badly treated or that the appellant was responsible for such treatment.
