column2: The plaintiff, who was injured in a rear-end motor vehicle accident, applied for summary judgment and an interim payment of damages. Application for summary judgment granted; application for interim payment dismissed. There was no 'air of reality' to the defendant's defence; whether or not the plaintiff's brake lights were working, to strike her vehicle from behind on these facts meant that the defendant was either travelling too close or didn't have enough care and control of his vehicle. The plaintiff was making a significant claim for damages but she suffered from numerous previous injuries and conditions relating to her health; any damage assessment would depend largely upon credibility and the medical evidence at trial; to assess interim damages in this case would be a most difficult task and would only be a haphazard guess. The plaintiff's claim was also complicated by the fact that it could possibly be subject to the 'minor injury' cap on damages.
column3: The plaintiff applied for an order for summary judgment pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 13.01 and an interim payment under Civil Procedure Rules 31.01. The defendant argued that there was a significant amount of other factors relating to the plaintiff's health including a pre-existing condition, a mental health condition, depression and other problems that resulted from the accident. The plaintiff also claimed damages for injuries suffered in a motor vehicle accident. HELD: The application was allowed. 1)The plaintiff was making a significant claim yet when one listens to defendant's counsel and reads the material attached to the defendant's affidavit, one concludes there is a significant number of other things relating to her health. 2)The defendant argued there was an 'air of realty' to the claim. 3)The evidence submitted by way of the plaintiff’s affidavits caused the court difficulty. 4)Costs were to be determined by the Court.
column4: [1] This is an application for an Order for summary judgement pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 13 and an interim payment under Civil Procedure Rule 31.01. We must accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of His Honour Judge Burke dated June 14, 1976. [6] In this particular application involving a rear-end collision, there is a heavier burden upon the Defendant. I am satisfied there has to be an “air of realty” to the defendant’s argument. In any event, I am satisfied when you read the material there was no “air of reality” to the defendant’s argument. [15] I am not satisfied the defendant has met the required burden and I allow the application. Judgement is entered against the respondent/defendant as to liability with damages to be assessed. The plaintiff is making a significant claim yet when one listens to defendant’s counsel and reads the material attached to the defendant’s affidavit, one concludes there is a significant amount of other factors relating to the health of the plaintiff. I am satisfied any amount of assessed damages which might be arrived at will depend largely upon credibility and medical evidence at trial. In my opinion to assess any amount in this case at this point in time would be a most difficult task and would only be a haphazard guess. [23] The plaintiff’s damage claim is further complicated in this particular matter as a result of the recent amendments in 2003 to the Insurance Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, C-23, especially as it would relate to non-pecuniary general damages. [25] On a review of the material supplied for this application, I am not satisfied that this is an appropriate case to order an interim payment at this point in time and I decline to do so. [26] However, as I said before, I would order summary judgment be entered against the defendant with damages to be assessed.

[23] The plaintiff’s damage claim is further complicated in this particular matter as a result of the recent amendments in 2003 to the Insurance Act, R.S.N.S. 1989, C-23, especially as it would relate to non-pecuniary general damages. [25] On a review of the material supplied for this application, I am not satisfied that this is an appropriate case to order an interim payment at this point in time and I decline to do so. [26] However, as I said before, I would order summary judgment be entered against the defendant with damages to be assessed.
column27: This was an application for an order for summary judgment pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 13.01 and an interim payment under Civil Procedure Rules 31.01. The plaintiff was operating her motor vehicle at the time of the accident and said in her affidavit that she was struck from behind by one of the defendants named in the action. The defendant argued that there was a significant amount of other factors relating to the plaintiff's health and that there should be an 'air of realty' to the defendant's argument. HELD: The application was allowed and the costs of this appeal and application before Judge Burke were set aside. 1)The plaintiff was making a significant claim yet when one listens to defendant's counsel and reads the material attached to his affidavit, one concludes there are a significant number of other things relating to her health. 2)The defendant argued there was an 'asse of realy' to his argument. 3)The evidence submitted by way of the plaintiff’s affidavits caused the court difficulty. 4)There was no air of reality to the defendants’ argument. 5)The court was not satisfied that the plaintiff had met the required burden and allowed the application. 6)Judgment was entered against the respondent/defendant as to liability with damages to be determined. 7)Costs in the cause of the action would be in the amount of $23,000.

column2: The accused successfully challenged the sufficiency of the grounds to issue a search warrant that was used to search her residence. Although the Information to Obtain was based on information from an anonymous, unproven source, the source's information was corroborated by independent information as to the accused's employment and residence. The only corroboration of the presence of a crime (a suspected marijuana grow operation) was from a FLIR test. The court found that the evidence did not rise above the level of suspicion, albeit strong suspicion. Corroboration of the employment and residence of the accused did not provide particular support for the informant's credibility; neither were results of the FLIR test and the presence of covered windows sufficient corroboration. The Crown appealed. Appeal allowed; new trial ordered. Although the trial judge articulated the proper test and began by analyzing whether the warrant could have been issued, the issue was later mistakenly transformed into whether he, himself, would have issued it. By weighing the probative evidence, the trial judge effectively substituted his views for those of the issuing justice and wrongly required the issuing justice to draw proper inferences as opposed to reasonable inferences.
column3: The Crown appealed the decision of the Provincial Court Judge quashing a search warrant issued by the RCMP. The judge found that the warrant could have been issued had it been properly quashed, that the evidence obtained by the search was wrongly excluded and that the judge applied the proper test. The appeal was allowed and a new trial ordered. HELD: The appeal is allowed and the trial ordered as well as the reasons for the decision. 1)The judge was to consider whether the warrant was valid, the search could have occurred, the evidence was properly excluded and the judge properly applied the test. 2)The court substituted his view of the evidence for that of the issuing JP. The court found that in a review of the warrant, the judge had properly considered whether he would have issued it. 3)The Court found that a reasonable and probable ground for issuing a search was found. The Court substituted its view of what the issuing judge could have done. 4)The evidence obtained as a result of the search did not prove that there was a violation of the accused's rights under s. 11 of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act. The evidence obtained was wrongly included. 5)The judicial standard of review was an objective one. The warrant was issued and the search would have been lawful. The officer who reviewed the warrant had a duty to consider the evidence of the person who had provided the tipster with the relevant information. The judicial standard was not appropriate. The issue was whether reasonable and reasonable grounds could have issued a search based on the information obtained from the tip. The Judge substituted his opinion of the issue for that held by the issuing Judge. 6)The appeal was granted and a fresh trial ordered on the grounds that the Judge had applied the appropriate standard of reviewing. The Appeal Court found the following: 1)There was no evidence of a violation by the police of the right to search. The search was lawful and there was no allegation that it was otherwise unreasonable. The decision of a judge to quash a search is a matter of fact. The trial judge was required to consider all of the factors that could be considered in a decision such as the factors set out in R. v. Garofoli for the review of an information to obtain search. In this case, the officer who examined the respondent's house by police with the Forward Looking Infrared (FLIR) imaging device was not satisfied with the information provided by the respondent. The result of that review was not a finding of a reasonable or probable ground.
column4: Held: The appeal is allowed and a new trial is ordered, as per reasons for judgment of MacDonald, C.J.N.S.; Cromwell and Fichaud, JJ.A. concurring. Therefore, I would allow the appeal and order a new trial. [21] In a thorough and careful analysis, the judge unquestionably articulated the appropriate legal principles. In reviewing his judgment as a whole, regrettably, I believe that what began as an analysis of whether the warrant could have been issued became transformed into an exercise where the judge ultimately considered whether he would have issued it. In other words, respectfully, the judge in the end substituted his view of the evidence for that of the issuing JP. It follows that the appeal should be allowed and a new trial ordered. [32] I would allow the appeal and order a new trial.

column8: The Crown appealed the decision of the Provincial Court Judge to quash a search warrant issued against the respondent. The judge found that the warrant could have been issued had it been properly quashed, that the evidence obtained as a result of the search was wrongly excluded, and that the judge substituted her discretion for that of the issuing judge. HELD: The appeal was allowed and a new trial ordered. 1)The judge clearly acknowledged that there was a reasonable and probable grounds to believe that a controlled substance, something in which it was contained or concealed, or any thing that would afford evidence of an offence under the CDSA was in the respondent's apartment. 2)In a thorough and careful analysis, the judge unquestionably articulated the appropriate legal principles. He acknowledged that the search warrant could not have been executed if there had been more evidence available. 3)The evidence obtained by the search did not prove that the respondent had committed an offence. The court substituted its view of the evidence for that held by the issuing JP. 4)The court was not required to substitute its opinion of the judge's standard of review for the one held by its own Justice of the Peace.

column2: This is an appeal by the landlord pursuant to s. 49 of The Residential Tenancies Act from a decision of the Deputy Rentalsman who, pursuant to s. 47 of the Act dismissed an application by the landlord for a writ of possession. HELD: The matter will be remitted to the Rentalsman for a rehearing upon proof of service of the Notice of Hearing on all of the tenants.  1) The tenants who are named in the decision are Vernon and Ivy. There is no reference to Richie whose name appears on the tenancy agreement. 2) Even though the decision states that the Notice of Hearing was properly served, that cannot be the end of the matter given that there is nothing in the file which would indicate any directions having been given to the landlord with respect to service other than personal service. Ivy and Richie did not appear at the hearing and the decision does not even identify Richie as being one of the tenants. More is required to ensure service of and notice to all the tenants. 3) There are no notes nor is there anything in the decision which would permit the Court to conclude that the issue of service on Ivy and Richie was ever considered by the Rentalsman. The matter must be returned to the Rentalsman for a rehearing upon proof of service of the hearing on all of the tenants.
column3: This was an appeal by Rich-Prop Investments Ltd. pursuant to s. 49 of The Residential Tenancies Act. The issues were whether all tenants had proper notice of the termination of the tenancy and the hearing, whether the landlord could give notice of termination of a tenancy without any cause, and whether the Rentalsman could refuse to grant writ of possession when there was an outstanding order of the Rentalman. HELD: The matter was remitted to the Rentersman for rehearing upon proof of service of the Notice of Hearing on all of the tenants. There was no order as to costs.

column23: This is an appeal by Rich-Prop Investments Ltd. pursuant to s. 49 of The Residential Tenancies Act. The issues are whether all the tenants had proper notice of the termination of the tenancy and the hearing, whether the landlord could give notice of termination without any cause, and whether the Rentalsman could refuse to grant a writ of possession when there was an outstanding order of the landlord. HELD: The matter was remitted to the landlord for rehearing upon proof of service of the Notice of Hearing on all of the tenants. There will be no order as to costs.  1) Section 49 of the Act permits either landlord or tenant to terminate monthly tenancy. Section 47(2)(c) permits the landlord to give notice to terminate a monthly tenancy without cause. 2) Section 48(3) permits a landlord to order a hearing on a tenant, served in compliance with directions, or served in accordance with the provisions of s. 47(1.1). 3) Section 50(2) of the act permits the rental authority to refuse to issue written notice of hearing to a landlord, relying on subsection 47(5.1) on the basis that the landlord is in contravention of an order made pursuant to the Act. Section 49(4) provides for a rehearing of the notice of hearings on all tenants.

column2: FIAT: The primary issue is whether the father should pay for tutoring expenses. HELD: 1) The father is not opposed to Kody receiving some additional educational assistance. However, he believes that the Sylvan Learning Center is too expensive. The father did not present any evidence with regard to other possible educational programs for the summer. It is clear that he has not researched alternatives to the Sylvan program. On the evidence, the expense is necessary for Kody. The real issue is whether the father has the means to contribute given his child support payments. If the father pays $472 per month for the Sylvan program, in addition to his s. 3 child support payments, the father's total child support payable would be $1,315 per month. The father would have a net monthly cash flow in the sum of $1,066 while the mother with four children would have available cash flow in the sum of $2,700 per month. Although the father will be stretched, the Sylvan program is necessary and reasonable.  2) Although the mother has an entitlement to spousal support, the father does not have the ability to pay. 3) The father shall pay costs in the sum of $400.
column3: FIAT: The matter was before the court on July 20, 2007. On that date, the court made a number of orders regarding child support as well as an order regarding summer access. The mother had provided the court with a letter from a teacher at the Westmount Community School. The letter disclosed that both children were in need of specialized educational programs. The father was to contribute $8 per month. The court ordered that the childcare costs be paid in full. The childcare costs were necessary and reasonable. The school fees were also necessary and were reasonable.
column4: [7] I am satisfied on the evidence before me that the expense in question is a necessary expense for Kody. The real issue is whether the father has the means to contribute to this expense given the child support I have ordered him to pay pursuant to my fiat of July 20, 2007. [11] Although I recognize the father will be stretched, I believe that the Sylvan Learning Centre expenses are necessary and reasonable.

column8: FIAT: The matter was before the Court on July 20, 2007. On that date, the Court made a number of orders regarding child support as well as an order regarding summer access. The remaining issues to be resolved were: 1) what, if any, should the father pay to the mother for extraordinary expenses relating to tutoring for one or both children? 2) whether the Sylvan Learning Centre expenses were necessary and reasonable. The father shall contribute his proportionate share of the costs to the total cost. 3) if the father paid this amount in addition to his s. child support amount, the father's total child support payment would be $1,315.00 per month until Sylvan fees are paid in full. 4) the father was ordered to contribute his portion of both childcare costs and Sylvan learning centre costs. 5) the mother's claim for interim spousal support was made pursuant to s. 7(1)(d) of the Federal Child Support Guidelines. Section 7(2) provides for an amount to cover all or any portion of the following expenses, taking into account the necessity of the expense in relation to the child's best interests and the reasonableness of expense. 6) that the child care costs were necessary, reasonable, and that Sylvan lessons were necessary. 7) that Sylvanian Learning Centre costs were reasonable. 8) that there was a conflict on the evidence regarding the payment of loans by the father during this period of time and the issue of whether or not the mother refused to accept payments being offered. If the mother wishes to pursue the issue regarding retroactive support she may do so when and if this matter proceeds further to pre-trial.
column9: [7] I am satisfied on the evidence before me that the expense in question is a necessary expense for Kody. The real issue is whether the father has the means to contribute to this expense given the child support I have ordered him to pay pursuant to my fiat of July 20, 2007. [11] Although I recognize the father will be stretched, I believe that the Sylvan Learning Centre expenses are necessary and reasonable.
column12: FIAT: The primary issue is whether the father should pay for tutoring expenses. HELD: 1) The father is not opposed to Kody receiving some additional educational assistance. However, he believes that the Sylvan Learning Center is too expensive. The father did not present any evidence with regard to other possible educational programs for the summer. It is clear that he has not researched alternatives to the Sylvan program. On the evidence, the expense is necessary for Kody. The real issue is whether the father has the means to contribute given his child support payments. If the father pays $472 per month for the Sylvan program, in addition to his s. 3 child support payments, the father's total child support payable would be $1,315 per month. The father would have a net monthly cash flow in the sum of $1,066 while the mother with four children would have available cash flow in the sum of $2,700 per month. Although the father will be stretched, the Sylvan program is necessary and reasonable.  2) Although the mother has an entitlement to spousal support, the father does not have the ability to pay. 3) The father shall pay costs in the sum of $400.
column13: FIAT: The matter was before me in Chambers on July 20, 2007. On that date made a number of orders regarding child support as well as an order regarding summer access. The mother's evidence disclosed that both children were in need of specialized educational programs given their current educational difficulties. HELD: 1)The father was to contribute $8 per month to the child support application although he will be stretched. The Sylvan Learning Centre expenses were necessary and reasonable. The father shall pay his proportionate share of the costs to the mother. 2)The mother's claim for the father's assistance is made pursuant to s. 7(1)(d) of the Federal Child Support Guidelines (the “Guidelines”). 3)Although the father is stretched, I believe the Sylvan learning centre expenses are necessary and are reasonable. 4)The costs of child care and the cost of child support for one or both children would be equal to 71% of the total cost. 5)The cost of childcare and the costs of the childview program would be approximately $7,800 per year. The childcare costs would be $1,261 per month until Sylvan fees are paid in full. 6)Costs of the childcare would be reasonable. If the father paid this amount in addition to his s. child support amount, the father would have net monthly cash flow in the sum of $2,700 per month. 7)The Sylvan costs were necessary, reasonable and should not affect the mother's right to pursue spousal support in the future.

column2: The tenant's year-to-year lease ran from September 1 to August 31. Four months before it was set to automatically renew, he notified the landlord he wished to convert to a month-to-month tenancy. The landlord refused, saying vacancies were hard to fill at any time other than September 1st. The three bedroom rental was in an area with a large university student population and was targeted at individuals sharing not families. It was a high-end rental, and would not necessarily appeal to students. The landlord provided evidence that the last time it was on the market in winter, it was vacant for several months. After a Residential Tenancies Board hearing, an officer declared the tenant successful. The written decision did not mention the landlord's reasons for refusing consent, nor did it say they were arbitrary or unreasonable. The landlord appealed, but offered to compromise by allowing the tenant to terminate the lease any time between May 31 and August 31 without penalty. The officer erred in law. The Act allows the landlord some discretion to refuse a request to convert to month-to-month, providing the refusal is made reasonably. The landlord's reasons were neither unreasonable nor arbitrary, given the reality of the market and his past experiences with a winter vacancy. There may be other situations where consent could reasonably be withheld. The tenancy is declared to have been renewed for another year (with the understanding the landlord will allow the tenant to terminate at any point after May 31). Both parties acted in good faith and, while it might seem unfair to lock the tenant into a lease he believed had converted to month-to-month, the court must make the order the officer should have made in the first place.
column3: This was an appeal by the Landlord from an order of the Director of Residential Tenancies. That order effectively permitted the tenant to convert what had been a year to year lease into a month to month tenancy. The landlord refused to renew for another year. The tenant appealed. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the tenancy had not been converted into a monthly to month. The Landlord refused to consent, giving his reasons why he believed it was not in his interest to have a month-to-month tenancy. He refused to grant an earlier date. The appeal allowed and declared the tenancy to have remained month to year. It was not unreasonable for the Landlords to refuse to grant the tenant's request that the lease be changed from a year-to‑year lease to a month.
column4: [2] This is an appeal by the Landlord from an order of the Director dated August 31, 2009. That order effectively permitted the Tenant to convert what had been a year to year lease into a month to month one. About four months before the expiry of the second year, the Tenant gave a proper notice that he wished to convert the tenancy into a month to month tenancy, pursuant to the provisions of s.10A of the Residential Tenancies Act, which provides: [5] The Landlord responded within thirty days and refused to consent, giving his reasons why he believed that it was not in his interest to have a month to month tenancy. [7] The Residential Tenancies Officer stated in his reasons that based upon his reading of the Residential Tenancies Act, the Landlord “may not deny the tenant’s request that the lease be changed from a year to year lease to a month to month effective September 1, 2009.” In so failing to consider the Landlord’s reasons, I believe that the Residential Tenancy Officer erred in law. It places the Landlord in the centre of a consenting process and allows the Landlord to exercise some judgment, with the constraint that it not be arbitrary or unreasonable. [13] The reasons of the Landlord here are that, in his experience, this particular flat is much more difficult to lease out at any time of the year other than September 1, which has become almost a standard moving day in south end Halifax, in part because that is the start day for most student apartments. [17] In the result, I allow the appeal and declare that the tenancy has not been converted into a month to month tenancy, because the Landlord refused his consent in a timely manner, for reasons that were neither arbitrary or unreasonable. [22] The Landlord wants the lease to terminate on August 31, 2010, but to alleviate hardship he has unconditionally undertaken to accept an early termination on any date from May 31, 2010 (his undertaking refers to 2009, but I believe that is a typo) until August 31, 2010.

That order effectively permitted the tenant to convert what had been a year to year lease into a month to month tenancy. The landlord refused to renew for another year. The tenant appealed. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the tenancy was declared to have been converted from a one year to a month tenancy because the landlord refused his consent in a timely manner. The Landlord refused to consent, giving his reasons why he believed it was not in his interest to have a month-to-month tenancy. This was an appeal of an order that effectively allowed the tenant's request that the lease be changed from a 1 year to 1 year lease to a 2 year lease. It was found that the tenancy had not been terminated because the tenant refused to give his reasons for withholding consent. 1)The Landlord's appeal of the original lease was allowed. 2)The landlord's request for an earlier date was met with no finding that the reasons were either arbitrary or unreasonable. 3)The Court was unable to adjudicate a dispute over whether the withholding of consent to sublet was unreasonably or unreasonable, given the current view of the law and the modern approach is for court to put itself into the position of the landlord and, having regard to the surrounding circumstances, the commercial realities of the marketplace and the economic impact of the sublease on the landlord, determine whether a reasonable landlord would consent to the conversion of year to month to year tenancy.

It also denied the tenant's request that the tenancy be deemed to have terminated because the landlord refused to renew for another year. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the tenancy was declared to have been converted from a year-to-year lease to a month-to‑month tenancy. The Landlord refused to consent, giving his reasons why he believed it was not in his interest to have the lease change from a one year to a year lease. The Residential Tenancies Officer stated in his reasons that based upon his reading of the Act, the landlord may not deny the tenant’s request to the lease be changed from a new year to month to a new lease effective September 1. He accordingly declared the tenancy had not been terminated, as the tenant contended.

column18: This is an appeal by the Landlord from an order of the Director dated August 31, 2009. That order effectively permitted the tenant to convert what had been a year to year lease into a month to month tenancy. It also denied the tenant's request that the tenancy be deemed to have terminated because the landlord refused to renew for another year. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the tenancy was declared to have been converted from a year-to-year lease to a month-to‑month tenancy. The Landlord refused to consent, giving his reasons why he believed it was not in his interest to have a monthly tenancy. This was a case where the withholding of consent by landlord had to be connected to the personality of the intended sublessee or with his probable user of the property: Houlder Bros. Co. Ltd. v. Gibbs, [1925] Ch. 575 (C.A.) This view of the law has fallen into disfavour and the modern approach is for court to put itself into the position of the landlord and, having regard to the surrounding circumstances, the commercial realities of the marketplace and the economic impact of the sublease on the landlord, determine whether a reasonable landlord would consent to the conversion of year to month to year tenancy. In this case, the landlord wants the lease to terminate on August 31/2010 but to alleviate hardship he has unconditionally undertaken to accept an early termination on any date from May/2010 until August/2010. The tenant asks that an earlier date be set, given that he has acted in good faith and had no way of knowing that his effort to convert the tenancy into month a month would be thwarted by the landlord. The landlord has been directed not to withhold consent in an arbitrary or unreasonable manner. This case raises an interesting and perhaps important issue under residential tenancy law and in particular what it means when a landlord has been ordered to withhold a month from a tenancy. An arbitrary decision would be one that is random or based on purely personal whim. An unreasonable one would have no credible rationale behind it.

column24: [2] This is an appeal by the Landlord from an order of the Director dated August 31, 2009. That order effectively permitted the Tenant to convert what had been a year to year lease into a month to month one. About four months before the expiry of the second year, the Tenant gave a proper notice that he wished to convert the tenancy into a month to month tenancy, pursuant to the provisions of s.10A of the Residential Tenancies Act, which provides: [5] The Landlord responded within thirty days and refused to consent, giving his reasons why he believed that it was not in his interest to have a month to month tenancy. [7] The Residential Tenancies Officer stated in his reasons that based upon his reading of the Residential Tenancies Act, the Landlord “may not deny the tenant’s request that the lease be changed from a year to year lease to a month to month effective September 1, 2009.” In so failing to consider the Landlord’s reasons, I believe that the Residential Tenancy Officer erred in law. It places the Landlord in the centre of a consenting process and allows the Landlord to exercise some judgment, with the constraint that it not be arbitrary or unreasonable. [13] The reasons of the Landlord here are that, in his experience, this particular flat is much more difficult to lease out at any time of the year other than September 1, which has become almost a standard moving day in south end Halifax, in part because that is the start day for most student apartments. [17] In the result, I allow the appeal and declare that the tenancy has not been converted into a month to month tenancy, because the Landlord refused his consent in a timely manner, for reasons that were neither arbitrary or unreasonable. [22] The Landlord wants the lease to terminate on August 31, 2010, but to alleviate hardship he has unconditionally undertaken to accept an early termination on any date from May 31, 2010 (his undertaking refers to 2009, but I believe that is a typo) until August 31, 2010.
column27: This is an appeal by the Landlord from an order of the Director dated August 31, 2009. That order effectively permitted the tenant to convert what had been a year to year lease into a month to month tenancy. It also denied the tenant's request that the tenancy be deemed to have terminated because the landlord refused to renew for another year. HELD: The appeal was allowed and the tenancy was declared to have been converted from a year-to-year lease to a month-to‑month tenancy. The Landlord refused to consent, giving his reasons why he believed it was not in his interest to have the lease change from a one year to a year lease. The Residential Tenancies Officer stated in his reasons that based upon his reading of the Act, the landlord may not deny the tenant’s request to the lease be changed from a new year to month to a new lease effective September 1. He accordingly declared the tenancy had not been terminated, as the tenant contended.

column2: The accused was charged with committing a common assault against his step-sister being the complainant. The question was whether the Crown's evidence was sufficiently credible to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the only physical contact he had on the complainant was for the purpose of defending himself from the alleged aggression of the complainant and whether the Crown was able to prove non-consent beyond a reasonable doubt. While a dismissal of the criminal appeal is a serious remedy, since it means it will never be heard on its merits, the appellant has made it clear that she cannot provide certified transcripts unless the court orders the respondents to pay. column3: The appellant appealed the June 2011 decision of the Provincial Court which found that she had committed the act of public mischief under s. 140 of the Criminal Code, R.S.C. 1985, when she reported an offence of assault with weapon to an RCMP officer, causing him to enter an investigation, when the alleged offence had not been committed and she was not criminally responsible. The respondents were to pay the cost of certifying the 1,700 pages of transcript she had typed herself. The appellant applied for an extension of time to dismiss both appeals on the basis that she could not provide certified transcripts. The respondent motion was granted. The court dismissed the appellant's appeal of the June 2010 decision. The Court dismissed the respondent motion for a stay of time and ordered the respondents to pay to certify the transcript. The appeal of CAC 341990 was dismissed for failure to perfect. The motion to consolidate both appeals was granted for failure by the appellant to provide certified transcript. Allowing the appeal for failure and ordering the respondents pay to certify transcripts, that the appellant cannot provide certified copies, because she cannot provide them unless I order the respondents of pay. The appellants' motion to have the respondents paid to certify transcripts is dismissed for failing to perfect as the appellant has not provided certified transcripts in accordance with the Nova Scotia Civil Procedure Rules. The applicants' motions to dismiss her Criminal and Civil Appeal are granted.
column4: Held: The appellant’s motion to consolidate both appeals and to have the respondents pay to certify the transcript is dismissed. The appellant’s appeals, CAC 341990 and CA 352311, are hereby dismissed for failure to perfect. I am convinced there is no merit to this, given Ms. Cummings’ position that she cannot provide certified transcripts, unless I order the respondents to pay, which I have indicated I am not prepared to do. [22] I dismiss her Criminal Appeal for failure to perfect. [23] I also dismiss Ms. Cummings’ Civil Appeal for failure to perfect. [24] In summary, Ms. Cummings’ motions to consolidate her two appeals and to have the respondents pay to certify the transcripts are dismissed The respondents’ motions to dismiss her Criminal and Civil Appeals are granted.

HELD: The appellant's appeal was dismissed for failure to perfect.  1)The Court dismissed both of her Criminal appeals. 2)The appellant's motions to consolidate both appeals were dismissed. 3)Rule 90.40(2) provides for the respondents to pay the cost of certifying the 1,700 pages of transcript she wants to put before the Court on her appeals. The Court dismissed her Criminal Appeal for failure. 4)The court dismissed the appellant's Civil Appeal. 5)Rule 91.20 provides that a single judge of this court in Chambers can dismiss a criminal appeal if the appellant fails to perfect it in compliance with Rule 91. This may occur if the Court's function was to conduct an inquiry into and adjudicate her many allegations of miscarriage of justice, abuse of process, violation of the Code and the general wrongdoing of participants in the justice system with whom she has been involved from 2006 to the present.  6)The respondents' motion to dismiss the Criminal Appeal is granted.

The Information was uncontrotverted and was a matter for the court's record.

column2: HELD: The application was dismissed. The court found that the 51 months between the charges and the scheduled trial was sufficiently long to warrant an inquiry into the reasonableness of the delay. As the accused had specifically and voluntarily waived almost five months of the delay, the court deducted that amount, leaving 46 months to be considered. The various types of delay were considered by the court: 11.5 for inherent delay; 15.5 months to be attributed to the actions of the accused; 10 months to be attributed to the Crown; and 10 months to institutional delay. The court found that the accused had not suffered prejudice and as most of the delay was attributable to adjournments sought on his behalf, the court found that the overall delay in this case was not unreasonable.
column3: The accused was charged with 56 offences set out in eight Informations. Six of the eight Informants were sworn against the accused. The accused was to reside in Alberta and was to have no contact with the co-accused. The Court dismissed the application for a stay of proceedings alleging that the accused had not established on a balance of probabilities that there had been a breach of his right to be tried within reasonable time. The Chambers were to be held in the Provincial Court in Regina. The Charter application was adjourned to April 2016. The court dismissed the applications for a judicial stay of proceeding. The reasons for the delay were the following: 1) the inherent time requirements of the case, such as the time involved with processing the charges, retaining counsel, pre-trial procedures (bail applications, pre‐trial conferences, police administrative work, Crown disclosure, and disclosure delays; 2) the respondent had not proven on a trial date that there was a breach in his right of free and due process; 3) the accused was not entitled to a stay on the Charter application. The Chamber was to be served with a Charter application pursuant to s. 11(b) and a Charter Application was to commence in the provincial court in Regina on April 6, 2016. 4) the Chambers were adjourned for a further hearing on June 12, 2016 and a preliminary hearing was scheduled for April 4, 2016 in the Federal Court in the same city. The chambers were to meet on June 16, 2016 to discuss the Charter Application. The matters were adjourn to June 12 and the Chambers are to be read to on June 17, 2016 with the preliminary hearing to be set in the federal court in the next city over. The matter was adjournED for a third hearing on July 19, 2016 for additional disclosure. The issues were adjournment to June 16 and the preliminary hearings to be scheduled in the province in April 2016 and June 17 in the following city over the next two months. The chamber was to meet in the fall of 2016.

The various types of delay were considered by the court: 11.5 for inherent delay; 15.5 months to be attributed to the actions of the accused; 10 months to be attributed to the Crown; and 10 months to institutional delay. The court found that the accused had not suffered prejudice and as most of the delay was attributable to adjournments sought on his behalf, the court found that the overall delay in this case was not unreasonable.

column3: The Law Society of Saskatchewan applied for an order that the respondents be prohibited from further proceedings or actions in relation to a formal complaint against the applicant dated December 15, 1988 as amended, alleging that he is guilty of conduct unbecoming a solicitor. The applicant was convicted of one count of theft and two counts of fraud on September 6, 1991. On October 10, 1991, he was sentenced to 18 months imprisonment and ordered to pay compensation to the victims of his crimes. Although stay of proceedings was ordered for the period from August 1989 until January 1993, the applicant was granted an inactive membership in the Law Society. The appeal was dismissed by the Supreme Court of Canada on March 21, 1995 and the Hearing Committee set August 8, 1995 as the date for a hearing. Leave was granted to the applicant to proceed further. HELD: The application was dismissed and the matter was set aside for a future hearing. The court found that the word'shall' in s. 53(1) of The Legal Profession Act, 1990 must be interpreted as imperative. It is mandatory. It has not been done in the past. The purpose of s.53(1)(a) of the Act, 1995 is to provide the chairperson of the Discipline Committee with a decision of the Hearing committee within 45 days so that disciplinary matters against its members may be dealt with in timely manner. The process must be completed without undue delay and thus protect the member's interest.

column13: The Law Society of Saskatchewan applied for an order that the respondents be prohibited from any further proceedings or actions in relation to the formal complaint against the applicant dated December 15, 1988 as amended, alleging that he is guilty of conduct unbecoming a barrister and solicitor. HELD: The appeal was dismissed by the Supreme Court of Canada on March 21, 1995 and the Hearing Committee set August 8, 1995 as the date for a hearing. Leave was given to the applicant to speak to costs. 1)The court dealt with a rule which provided that the Secretary shall promptly notify the respondent in writing of referral to the Benchers. 2)The Court did not deal with statutory requirement, as is the case before me. The court has the jurisdiction to waive rules but does not have jurisdiction to waive statutory requirements. 3)The applicant was a paid-up practising member of the Law Society. Although stay of proceedings was ordered for the period from August 1989 until January 1990, it was incumbent upon the respondents to move without delay before the stay was granted and after it was lifted on the application of the respondents. 4)The appellant may apply to the Court of Appeal for stay pending the decision of the appeal.

column2: The Minister of Social Services sought an order under s.37(2) of the Child and Family Services Act to permanently commit all three children to the Minister. The Department of Social Services had been involved with the family since the birth of the oldest child. The children had been in the care of the Minister at various times and parent aides provided help to the parents when there was child or children at home. The Minister called 18 witnesses. HELD: All three children were committed permanently to the Minister. 1)The mother appeared to be more anxious about excusing the father, who was an abusive alcoholic, than about protecting the children. The mother was unable to parent any of the children on her own. It was concluded under s.11(b) of the Act that there was no adult person able and willing to provide for the children's needs and physical or emotional harm may come to the children if it had not already. 2)The father had recently pleaded guilty to sexual assault on an eight year old girl which could, depending on the facts be a ground under s.11(a)(iii) of the Act for a finding of need for protection.
column3: The Minister of Social Services sought an order under s.37(2) of the Child and Family Services Act permanently committing all three children to the Minister. The Department had been very much involved in the child protection effort. The oldest child, who had been diagnosed as having Attention Deficit Disorder (ADD), had been attending classes with the idea of getting her grade and eventual grade XII. She apparently exhibited symptoms of ADD and was referred for medical diagnosis which found there to be an ADD. The Minister had been advised that the children could be returned to or L. The mother had pleaded guilty to sexual assault and was sentenced to 12 months imprisonment. The father had been drinking and had been in a relationship with the mother for eight years. The parties had been living together for six years. HELD: The application was reserved. 1)The mother was found guilty of sexual assault. 2)The father had not been drinking. 3)The court was told that the mother had been relying on others. She did not have the competency to parent the children on her own. 4)The evidence was that the father had physically abused the mother. 5)The child had been exposed to domestic disharmony and domestic violence that had been part of the ongoing pattern of living of and L. 6)The Court was told by that the child had not had a lawyer for six months. The court was ordered that all three of the children be permanently committed to the father.
column4: The Minister of Social Services ("the Minister") seeks an order under s. 37(2) of The Child and Family Services Act, S.S. 1989-90, c. C-7.2 (the “Act”), permanently committing to the Minister all three children. It is now ordered, pursuant to s. 37(2) of the Act that all three children be permanently committed to the Minister, for the reasons that follow. The behaviour of both C and L in relation to the hearing could, itself, be enough to support a conclusion under s. 11(b) of the Act that there is no adult person able and willing to provide for the children's needs and physical or emotional harm may come to the children if it has not already. Something else which I should specifically mention is the fact that L has recently pleaded guilty to a sexual assault on an eight year old girl. I do not have enough of the facts to be able to act on it but it could, of course, depending on the facts, be a ground under s. 11(a)(iii) of the Act for a finding of need for protection. Of course if C remains separated from L the domestic disharmony, at least between those two, would in the future not be a factor, but then C simply does not have the competency to parent one of the three let alone all three children on her own.

Something else which I should specifically mention is the fact that L has recently pleaded guilty to a sexual assault on an eight year old girl. I do not have enough of the facts to be able to act on it but it could, of course, depending on the facts, be a ground under s. 11(a)(iii) of the Act for a finding of need for protection. Of course if C remains separated from L the domestic disharmony, at least between those two, would in the future not be a factor, but then C simply does not have the competency to parent one of the three let alone all three children on her own.
column27: The Minister of Social Services sought an order under s.37(2) of the Child and Family Services Act permanently committing to the Minister all three children of and L. The Department had been very much involved in the adoption of the three children. The mother had been diagnosed as having Attention Deficit Disorder (ADD). She had been attending classes with the idea of getting her grade and eventual grade XII. She had exhibited symptoms of ADD and was referred for medical diagnosis which found there to be ADD. Since the birth of the children, they had been in the care of the Minister under various orders or agreements. During one of these occasions, the mother pleaded guilty to sexual assault and was sentenced to two years' imprisonment. She was also sentenced to one year's imprisonment for sexual assault. HELD: The application was reserved.  1)The mother was found guilty of sexual assault with the intent to protect the children from exposure to domestic disharmony and domestic violence that had been part of the ongoing pattern of living of and and L for six years.  2)The Court was told that if the mother remained separated from L she would not be able and willing to parent the children on her own. 3)The father was found to be incapable of caring for the children. She did not have the competency to care for all three of them. 4)The Department was ordered to permanently commit the children to their father.  5)The court was not satisfied that the mother was incapable of protecting the children physically or emotionally. 6)The evidence was that the foster parents had failed to properly supervise or protect them. The children were in need of protection as provided by s.11(a)(ii) and (vi). 7)The children were to remain in the Minister's custody for the foreseeable future.

column2: The appellant was granted release pending appeal, on conditions. The Crown applied for a review. The Crown contended that the Chambers judge misinterpreted the definition of custody in granting the application, as the appellant was on day parole at the time of the application. Dismissing the application, that day parole with a requirement to return to a halfway house each night is a form of custody which allows for an application and release under s. 679 of the Code.
column3: The Crown applied for a review under s. 680(1) of the Criminal Code. Following an application for release pending appeal pursuant to s. 679(1), the Crown applied to the chief justice or acting chief justice of the court of appeal for direction that the decision be reviewed by the court's court of appeals. The original order was dated October 1999 and an amended order changing several of the conditions was dated November 8, 1999. The Crown applied on the same date as the amended order. Following the application for a release pending application pursuant to section 679 of the Code, the Crown granted the release with conditions pending the respondent's appeal scheduled to be heard January 26, 2000. column4: [1] Following an application for release pending appeal pursuant to section 679(1) of the Criminal Code, Justice Cromwell issued a written decision on October 19, 1999, granting the release with conditions, pending Mr. Wood’s appeal scheduled to be heard January 26, 2000. column2: The accused was charged with four offences relating to a twelve year old girl, including sexual assault and uttering a threat. He was released on bail with a surety. The accused is paraplegic. He moved to British Columbia after his release. He did not appear for trial, and a Canada wide warrant was issued for his arrest. He was arrested and returned to stand trial. The Crown applied to have bail and the surety forfeited. It took the position that the accused had deliberately left the province to avoid trial, and therefore should be responsible for the full $1,000. It also contended that the sureties had a responsibility to ensure the accused's attendance at trial, and that they should also be responsible for the full $1,000. The surety testified that the conditions of the recognizance were not explained to him, and he did not understand the potential consequences of default. Dismissing the applications for forfeiture, that the surety had no concept of his obligations under the recognizance, and was not made aware of those obligations by the authorities. In these circumstances, it would not be just to order forfeiture. With respect to the accused, he is impecunious. His failure to pay any amount ordered against him could lead to imprisonment. As the accused already faces the prospect of imprisonment for failing to attend trial, this would create the potential of double liability for what is in essence the same offence.
column3: The accused was charged with four offences with respect to a twelve year old girl. The accused had been released from prison on a promise to appear in court on a charge of sexual assault. He had been injured and was unable to walk. He was remanded in custody pending posting of bail. The surety visited the accused at the prison and agreed to be surety. The sentence for failure to appear was set aside. The court found that the accused had no concept of his obligations under the recognizance and mistakenly believed that his responsibilities or liability ended with his first appearance in Court following his release. The judge found that because the surety had no idea of his obligation under the condition that he continue to reside at his residence when required to do so, he should have had an opportunity to read the recognizer before signing it. The defendant had no interest in returning to Nova Scotia and had no intention of returning to the province. The fact that he had a disability and was not able to drive made it clear that forfeiture should not be ordered against him.
column4: Hall, J. [1] The Crown has applied pursuant to s. 771 for an order forfeiting the amount of bail set out in a recognizance entered into by the accused, Lloyd Eugene Bailey, and the surety, Reverend Wrenford Bryant, in the amount of $1,000.00, which was given to secure the release of the accused pending his trial on a number of criminal charges. [3] The accused was charged with four offences with respect to a twelve year old girl which allegedly occurred during the month of December, 1997. The offences include sexual assault under s. 271(1)(a) of the Criminal Code, uttering a threat, s. 264.1(1)(a), sexual touching under s. 151 and unlawfully having a weapon contrary to s. 87. [4] It appears that the accused was arrested in December of 1997 and remanded in custody at the Halifax Correction Centre pending posting of bail which was set at $1,000.00 with a surety. [7] The accused did not appear for trial on March 6, 2000 and a Canada wide warrant for his arrest was issued. As to the surety, the Crown submitted that under s. 771(2) of the Criminal Code sureties have a responsibility to ensure the attendance at trial of the person for whom they go bail and are responsible for getting out of prison and, therefore, the surety should be responsible for the full $1,000.00. [19] I conclude that Mr. Bryant had no concept of his obligations under the recognizance. In these circumstances I am satisfied that it would not be just nor appropriate to order forfeiture on the part of Mr. Bryant. [22] Turning next to the case of the accused, for very different reasons I have concluded as well that forfeiture ought not to be ordered against him. The accused is impecunious; he has no income and no assets other than an apparatus worth a few dollars that enables him to drive a motor vehicle. Thus, the accused would potentially be liable for a double punishment for his failure to appear for trial which is not acceptable in our system of criminal justice. [25] Accordingly, the applications for forfeiture are dismissed.

[22] Turning next to the case of the accused, for very different reasons I have concluded as well that forfeiture ought not to be ordered against him. The accused is impecunious; he has no income and no assets other than an apparatus worth a few dollars that enables him to drive a motor vehicle. Thus, the accused would potentially be liable for a double punishment for his failure to appear for trial which is not acceptable in our system of criminal justice. [25] Accordingly, the applications for forfeiture are dismissed.
column27: The Crown applied pursuant to s. 771 for an order forfeiting the amount of bail set out in a recognizance entered into the accused. The accused was charged with four offences with respect to a twelve year old girl who allegedly occurred during the month of December 1997. HELD: The applications for forfeiture were dismissed. 1)The accused had no concept of his obligations under the recognizizance. He mistakenly believed that his responsibilities or liability ended with his first appearance in Court following his release. Certainly he was not aware that he himself could be subject to imprisonment under s.773 in the event of default and was not made aware of that fact.  2)Although the accused may be considered blameworthy or reckless if one accepts his version and deserving of some sanction, in the circumstances the Crown submitted that under s771(2) of the Code sureties have a responsibility to ensure the attendance at trial of the person for whom they go bail and are responsible for getting out of prison and, therefore, the surety should be responsible for the full $1,000.  3)The court found that the accused was not in a position to be liable for a double punishment for his failure to appear for trial which was not acceptable in our system of criminal justice.

column2: The Crown applied for an order forfeiting a vehicle pursuant to s.16(1) of the Controlled Drug and Substances Act. The registered owner applied for an order declaring her interest in the vehicle was not affected by any forfeiture order. The owner was passenger when 28.3 pounds of marijuana was discovered in the trunk of her Lincoln. She was found not guilty of trafficking and possession of marijuana for the purpose of trafficking. The driver was found guilty of possession for the purpose of trafficking. The trafficking charge against him was judicially stayed. HELD: An order of forfeiture issued pursuant to s.16(1). The application for relief was dismissed. 1)It was not necessary to address the Charter submissions with respect to s.19(3) because Crown counsel consented to the respondent's application being viewed as an application for relief from forfeiture under s.20. 2)It was impossible to conclude the respondent 'appeared innocent of any complicity' in the offence for which the driver was convicted and that she 'exercised all reasonable care to be satisfied' that the Lincoln was not likely to be used in the commission of the offence. 3)Section 11 of the Charter applies only when person has been charged with an offence. There was no charge against the respondent at this time. 4)The Act distinguishes between three types of persons who might own, or have an interest in, conveyance which is 'offence-related property': the interest of person convicted of the offence is forfeitable pursuant to s.16(1); if the person has been neither convicted nor charged and appears innocent of any complicity in the offence; someone charged with the offence which gave rise to the forfeiture application (as here). The forfeiture is not, except with respect to an offender, arbitrary. In view of the provisions available under the Act to obtain relief from forfeiture it cannot be concluded that empowering a court to grant an order of forfeiture constitutes cruel or unusual punishment.
column3: The Crown applied pursuant to s.16(1) of the Controlled Drug and Substances Act for an order forfeiting the Lincoln to Her Majesty in Right of Canada. The Crown alleged that the Lincoln was used to transport drugs and that the registered owner of the vehicle consented to the seizure of the car. The accused applied pursuant pursuant to ss.19(4) of s.C. 1996 for an ordered declaring her interest in the Lincoln not affected by any forfeiture order. The court found that the accused was not guilty of any trafficking offence, nor of any conspiracy to obtain or use controlled substances, and that there was no evidence that she consented or consented either to the possession of the marihuana being in the possession her co-accused. The Court dismissed the charges.

column8: The Crown applied pursuant to s.16(1) of the Controlled Drug and Substances Act for an order forfeiting the Lincoln to Her Majesty in Right of Canada. The Crown argued that the Lincoln was a 'offence-related property' and that the owner of the vehicle had not consented to the marihuana being in the possession of her co-accused. The accused applied for relief from forfeiture under s.19(4) of The Controlled Drug Act. The court found that the accused was innocent of any involvement in the offence and that her interest in the Lincoln had not been affected by any forfeiture order. However, the accused applied to have her interest declared as 'offensive property' pursuant to ss.20(4), 19(3) and 20(4 of the Act. HELD: The accused was found guilty of trafficking and possession of marijuana for the purpose of trafficking. The charges against the accused were dismissed. The Court found that s. 19(2) contravenes the guarantees contained in s. 11(d) of s.11(d), being Schedule to the Canada Act 1982. The provisions related to the forfeiture of property were found to violate s.12 of the Charter.

column13: The Crown applied pursuant to s.16(1) of the Controlled Drug and Substances Act for an order forfeiting the Lincoln to Her Majesty in Right of Canada. The Crown alleged that the Lincoln belonged to a person who had been convicted of trafficking and possession of marihuana for the purpose of trafficking, and that she had exercised all reasonable care to be satisfied that the vehicle was not likely to be used in the commission of the offence. The accused applied under s.20(4) of s.19(4)(a) to an order declaring that her interest in the Lincoln was not affected by any forfeiture order. HELD: The accused was found not guilty on both counts. The court applied pursuant pursuant to ss.20 and 19(4(a) of ss.19 (the "Act") for an application for relief from forfeiture. The charges against the accused were dismissed.  1) The court must first consider the gravity of an offence, the personal characteristics of the offender and the nature and extent of the interest. 2) The Court must consider whether there is any evidence that she consented to the purchase of the vehicle. 3) It is not necessary to address the Charter submissions with respect to s19(3), however, because Crown counsel consented. 4) The societal purpose of the Act, and the provisions related to the forfeiture of property, was alluded to by Whitman J.A. in R. v. Gisby. 5) Section 20(3) provides the court with the authority for the court to make an order of relief from forfeiting. Section 19(3)(b) provides that the court can make an application under s18 and 19, where a person is convicted of a designated substance offence and, on application of the Attorney General, the court is satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, that the interest of the applicant is not affected. The Court cannot decide whether a sentence is disproportionately disproportionate that it violates the provisions of s12 of the Charter.

column2: The applicants applied for an order in the nature of certiorari to quash the decision of the school board to close two schools. The applicants were parents of children who attended one of the two closed schools., application allowed in part; certiorari granted in respect of the decision to close the school which the applicants' children attended; the applicants had no standing to challenge the closure of the second school as they were not directly affected by its closure. The School Board breached its general duty to act fairly in allowing a Board member to vote when he had not attended the public meetings on the issue. The Board did not meet the onus on it to show that the member had appropriate firsthand knowledge of the evidence and submission of the applicants.
column3: This was an application for an order pursuant to Civil Procedure Rule 56 in the nature of certiorari to quash the decision of the Board to close the two schools. All seven applicants are parents of children attending the schools. The applicant has shown that there has been a decline in enrollment in the area of the former cities and that the declining use of classroom space is costly with respect to maintenance expense. The Board developed a strategy for the purpose of a review of the schools and recommended that the schools be transferred to Northbrook. The applicants raise the issue of whether the duty of fairness has been breached when a member of the board, who failed to attend relevant meetings, voted for closure of the two school systems. The board also recommended that Northbrook be transferred. The application for certiorar quash was granted.

column2: The plaintiff sought damages for personal injuries to her lower back, right knee and left ankle sustained when she slipped and fell while grocery shopping in March 2000. The defendant acknowledged the plaintiff fell in its produce department, but did not concede the water on the floor caused her to slip; the cause was, in part, her worn running shoes without laces. Liability and degree of personal injury were in issue. The claim proceeded under the simplified procedure under Part Forty of the Queen's Bench Rules. HELD: The claim was dismissed with costs. 1)The defendant had a duty of care to the plaintiff as owner and occupier. The courts have most often based the duty of care on the invitor/invitee standard. Maxay v. Ramsay Drugs proposed four-part inquiry to determine whether or not an occupier has breached its duty of care. 2)The plaintiff established on a balance of probabilities that she slipped because of water on the floor. The evidence did not support an inference that her footwear caused the slip or was a contributing factor. 3)An adverse inference was not drawn from the defendant's failure to adduce evidence confirming its employee had in fact cleaned the floor. The employee was no longer employed by the defendant. Neither party was able to locate him. 4)Some of her injuries were, in part, the aggravation of pre-existing conditions. The most significant injury was sprain to her left ankle, which had not been resolved primarily because the plaintiff declined to accept available treatment and failed to follow medical advice. The inconsistencies in her affidavit and the physician notes or medical reports respecting her injuries and treatment were not relevant to this decision. 5)A 'sweep log' was kept for each department and employees made regular inspections of the sales floor area in every department. The plaintiff slipped and fell about an hour after the last sweeping. A regular program of maintenance was conducted in the area. The overall policies and practices of regular maintenance and responsibility of each employee were substantially the same if not identical to those considered in the Mollenhauer and Libel group of cases. The defendant met the legal standard of care imposed in the circumstances and was not liable for the plaintiff's injuries. To find otherwise would be to impose a standard that is inconsistent with that previously imposed by this court in almost identical circumstances.
column3: The plaintiff sought damages for personal injuries sustained when she slipped and fell while grocery shopping in the defendant's Superstore. The defendant placed in issue whether it was liable to the plaintiff for the injuries she sustained in the slip and fall and whether it would be liable to its employees for the damage caused. The plaintiff was wearing running shoes without laces at the time of the incident. The defendants claimed that the plaintiff slipped on a puddle of water on the floor of the store and fell heavily to the ground. The plaintiffs claim dismissed with costs. The court reviewed the history of the Superstore and determined that the defendant met the legal standard of care imposed upon it in the circumstances and was not liable for the injury suffered. The evidence of the employees who had worked in the store prior to the accident was inconsistent with the standard set out in the Mollenhauer and Leibel cases. The Court also reviewed the defendant employees' affidavits and the sweep log. The affidavits of the two assistant managers employed at the store confirmed the cleaning regimen in place. The judge concluded that the defendants met the standard of caring imposed upon them in the situation and was therefore not liable. The claim was dismissed with the costs of the plaintiff's claim. The Defendant met the statutory standard of maintenance imposed upon the plaintiff and was held liable for injuries suffered by the plaintiff. The pre-existing conditions were aggravating factors. The Defendants did not contest the presence of water in the vicinity of where the plaintiff fell although it did not concede that it was the water which caused the plaintiff to slip. There have been many cases that have found slippery substance such as water on a floor of grocery store to constitute an unusual danger. The injuries were at least in part aggravation of pre- existing conditions.

column2: The police observed the appellant's vehicle rub another vehicle and followed him to where he parked without difficulty. While taking the appellant to where the incident occurred, the officer noted slight smell of alcohol and bloodshot eyes. The appellant failed the ALERT test and refused the breathalyzer. The refusal charge was dismissed and the appellant was convicted of impaired driving. The appellant appealed. Appeal allowed; conviction quashed. The evidence of impairment was too weak to convict the appellant. The officer told the accused that if he passed the ALERT test, he would be sent on his way. Thus, she must not have thought that the appellant's ability to operate a motor vehicle was impaired. Failure to act cannot be considered by the trial judge as part of the reasonable and probable grounds.
column3: The appellant was convicted of impaired driving on the ground that his vehicle rubbed against a parked vehicle. The evidence was weak to the point where there was virtually no choice but to acquit. The appeal was allowed and the conviction quashed.

[17] I have concluded that the evidence was weak to the point where there was virtually no choice but to acquit, and accordingly the appeal is allowed and the conviction quashed.

[17] I have concluded that the evidence was weak to the point where there was virtually no choice but to acquit, and accordingly the appeal is allowed and the conviction quashed.
column27: The appellant was convicted of impaired driving on the ground that his vehicle rubbed against a parked vehicle. The evidence was weak to the point where there was virtually no choice but to acquit. The appeal was allowed and the conviction quashed.

column2: FIAT. At issue was whether there a change of circumstances, which would warrant a variation of the 2002 child support order; whether the 18 year old continued to be a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act; does the father have an obligation to contribute to his daughter's riding lessons; the father's income for child support purposes; should the 17 year old son's s.7 expenses be increased; costs. HELD: 1)The daughter had ceased to be a child of the marriage within the meaning of the Divorce Act and the father's obligation to provide on-going support and his contribution for s.7 expenses relating to her riding lesson terminated in March 2003. 2)The father shall pay $308 per month for support of his son commencing April 1, 2003 and every month thereafter so long as he remains a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act. 3)The mother's application to increase the father's contribution for the son's extracurricular activities was dismissed. The father shall pay $54 per month for hockey expenses commencing June 2003 and every month thereafter. 4)The mother was to forthwith pay costs of the application fixed at $250.
column3: FIAT. The parties' oldest child, Jasmine, was no longer a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act. The father argued that a variation of the support order was warranted because his income had decreased as a result of his being laid off from his employment, that the parties' youngest child, who was born in November 2002, was living with the father, and that her s. 7 expenses (hockey, golf and baseball) had not been incurred for more than a year. The mother argued that the father's layoff was only temporary and that the child's plans and ability to contribute to the cost of any post-secondary education she decides to pursue were not being met. HELD: Jasmine ceased to be a child of the marriage within the definition of the Act effective March 31, 2003. 1) The father's obligation to contribute was terminated effective March 30, 2003 and the child had not commenced any post partum activities within the Meaning of the Agreement. 2) The mother's obligation was terminated for the child to contribute for the parties oldest child's hockey, golf, baseball and hockey expenses were not met. 3) The court found that the mother's proportionate share of the father’s s.7 expenses (bingo, golf) was reduced to 55.57% from 55.56% as the father had not withdrawn from SGI. The child’d be able to commence post-primary education in September 2003. 4) Costs were warranted in this situation because of the unreasonableness of the mother’ s.8 activities. The unreasoneness of her position warrants an assessment of costs. Costs provided some relief to the father.
column4: 1. Has there been a change of circumstance since May 17, 2002 which would warrant variation of the support order? 2. Is Jasmine a child of the marriage within the meaning of the Divorce Act? 5. Should Sloane’s s. 7 expenses (hockey, golf and baseball) be increased? I find that Jasmine ceased to be a child of the marriage within the meaning of the Divorce Act effective March 31, 2003. [25] As Jasmine is no longer a child of the marriage, Mr. Harder has no obligation to contribute towards the costs of her riding lessons pursuant to s. 7(f) of the Guidelines. Mr. Harder’s obligation to contribute to Jasmine’s riding lessons is terminated effective March 31, 2003. It is hereby ordered that Mr. Harder shall pay to Ms. Harder for the support of their son, Sloane Allan Harder, born April 8, 1986, the sum of $308 per month commencing April 1, 2003 and continuing on the first day of each and every month thereafter so long as Sloane remains a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act. In light of the parties’ current incomes, Mr. Harder’s proportionate share of Sloane’s s. 7(f) hockey expenses should be reduced to 55.57%. [35] Mr. Harder shall pay to Ms. Harder for Sloane’s s. 7(f) hockey expenses the sum of $54 commencing June 1, 2003 and continuing on the first day of each and every month thereafter so long as that expense is incurred by Sloane. 1. That Jasmine ceased to be a child of the marriage within the meaning of the Divorce Act effective March 31, 2003. Mr. Harder’s obligation to provide ongoing support to Jasmine and his contribution for s. 7 expenses relating to her riding lessons shall terminate as of that date. Mr. Harder shall pay to Ms. Harder for the support of Sloane Allan Harder, born April 8, 1986, the sum of $308 per month commencing April 1, 2003 and continuing on the first day of each and every month thereafter so long as Sloane remains a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act. 3. Ms. Harder’s application to increase Mr. Harder’s contribution for Sloane’s extracurricular activities is dismissed. 4. I find that Sloane’s current hockey expense is approximately $1,161.29 per annum.

column8: FIAT. The parties' oldest child, Jasmine, was no longer a child within the meaning of the Divorce Act. HELD: The child was to continue to receive child support from the parties' father for the sum of $308 per month commencing June 1, 2003 and continuing on the first day of each and every month thereafter so long as she remains a child under the meaning. 1)The child ceased to be an 'adult child' within the Meaning of the Act effective March 31, 2003. 2)Costs were warranted in this situation because of Ms. Harder's refusal to terminate the father's s. 7(f) contribution for Jasmine's riding lessons even though he was laid off his employment. column2: The defendant applied for a stay of proceedings on the basis of a violation of his right to be tried in a reasonable time. There had been delay of approximately 14.5 months from the time that he was charged with exceeding the breathalyzer and impaired driving to the date of his trial. Stay of proceedings granted. At his first court appearance the defendant requested the first available trial date and there was no evidence to suggest that an institutional delay of 13 months was the norm in other metro provincial courts. Given the nature of the charges, the technical nature of breathalyzer law and the defendant's stated intention to raise ss. 8 and 9 of the Charter, prejudice could be inferred on the basis that the length of delay was likely to interfere with the quality of evidence tendered.
column3: The accused was charged with impaired driving contrary to s. 253(b) and s.253(a) of the Criminal Code. He was arraigned on the information and requested a date for trial. The accused waived his right to a stay of proceedings on the basis that the information was sworn less than a day before the date set for commencement of trial. HELD: The application was granted and the matter was set for trial December 18, 2003. The court found that the length of the delay was likely to interfere with the quality of evidence tendered given the passage of time that the charges were filed. The length of delay was not unreasonable and the accused waived a significant portion of it such that the matter would not be more difficult to resolve. The applicant waived a substantial portion of the remaining delay which was not reasonable.
column4: [1] This is an application for a stay of proceedings based on a violation of the right to be tried within a reasonable time pursuant to s. 11(b) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. At his first court appearance Mr. Abbass requested the first available date for trial and was given a date over 13 months in the future. Given the nature of the charges and the technical nature of Breathalyzer law, the fact that the Defense has verbalized an intention to raise s. 8 and s.9 Charter motions and lead evidence to the contrary, I find that prejudice can be, and is, inferred on the basis that the length of the delay is likely to interfere with the quality of evidence tendered, given the passage of time that has occurred since the circumstances giving rise to the charges. Accordingly, the proceedings are stayed.

column24: [1] This is an application for a stay of proceedings based on a violation of the right to be tried within a reasonable time pursuant to s. 11(b) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. At his first court appearance Mr. Abbass requested the first available date for trial and was given a date over 13 months in the future. Given the nature of the charges and the technical nature of Breathalyzer law, the fact that the Defense has verbalized an intention to raise s. 8 and s.9 Charter motions and lead evidence to the contrary, I find that prejudice can be, and is, inferred on the basis that the length of the delay is likely to interfere with the quality of evidence tendered, given the passage of time that has occurred since the circumstances giving rise to the charges.
